review:
Since people don't know what the PC Gaming Wiki is, here are 3 essential files you need to download and apply to the game to get the best experience out of SimCity 4 on modern operating systems:

Large Address Hardware - improves the games performance by removing the 2gb limit on how much RAM SimCity 4 is allowed to use:
https://www.techpowerup.com/forums/threads/large-address-aware.112556/

SC4Fix - a .dll file that fixes bugs unpatched by Maxis, crash issues and the infamous prop pox glitch, which in general gradually removes props from the player's city, breaking the game: 
https://community.simtropolis.com/files/file/30883-sc4fix-third-party-patches-for-sc4/

SimCity 4 Launcher - a launcher for the game that includes options for autosave, choices between 3 renderers, CPU improvements, widescreen resolutions, borderless or not borderless windows, a mod manager, a tick to disable intro movies and an improvement that forces the game to render as the player scrolls (primarily for AMD users):
https://community.simtropolis.com/forums/topic/54082-simcity-4-launcher-updated-100915-154b-r12/

Install all three files (directions included in each link) and you'll be good to play SimCity 4 without any issues.

EDIT: Almost forgot - if the game refuses to launch, set SimCity3.exe's compatibility to Windows XP and run as administrator.

Doesn't require a constant internet connection
Doesn't randomly wipe cities
Doesn't prevent you from using mods
Doesn't restrict control over regions
Doesn't confine you to a 10x10 city grid

It does however put a game that is 10 years newer to shame. If you want SimCity, look no further.

I played this game a lot when i was 12 or 13 or whatever which explains why i didn't have a girlfriend for a long time but I played it recently and it's still a hell of a lot of fun. I built a city with two motorways going out of the city but also a toll road and then a subway system and this gave me a hell of a lot of money and so i spent it on health and education and i felt really good about myself for 5 or 10 minutes. i still don't have a girlfriend though

If modded this game even though its ten years old, in my opinion its much better than the new version. I bought this one again after finding out how bad the new one was. You should mod this game for sure though, with larger regions, the NAM and CAM and whatever else you want on the great modding sites for this game. 

Currently im playing on a very detailed  sat. map of the US with over 500 of the largest city tiles in one single region. Just one of my city tiles from what i heard is four times bigger than a city tile on the new version and i have over 500 of them, all are connected to and interact with each other. Building the entire country with things so spread out leaves tons of open land adding to the realism that the region system in this game creates.  

HANDS DOWN THE BEST CITY SIM IN THE WORLD AND THIS GAME IS OVER 10 YEARS OLD!!!!!     C,MON EA??? WHAT HAPPENED?!?!

Here are some videos showing my current region :) Its much higher quality on youtube itself though

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9wbl0jRrCEk

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Men_A_D_azY

You can also check out my region journal here.
http://sc4devotion.com/forums/index.php?topic=16817.0

Everyone is right, it really is still the best city building game, even now in 2023 there's nothing better.  It still has a huge community over at https://community.simtropolis.com/  This game has more mods then you could ever have the time to try.  

It does need some tweaking to run well on modern pc's.  This is what was recommended to me to add to the game's Steam Launch Options command line which help optimize the game:

-intro:off -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -CPUCount:1 -CPUPriority:high -Cursors:fullcolor

Just copy and paste the whole line into the Launch Options, where it says -r1920x1080x32 you can just change to your monitor's resolution size so you can play full screen.

Another helpful tweak is using the 4GB Patch tool here https://ntcore.com/?page_id=371 It allows old 32 bit games to use more memory to run.  Run the 4GB_Patch.exe file, it will open Windows Explorer.  Navigate to the game's install folder ...SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition\Apps and choose the file called SimCity 4.exe,  It will replace the file and make a backup of it.

Also make sure in the game's graphics options to set the Rendering Mode to Software, not Hardware.  Doing these steps allows the game to run smooth.  There's other tweaks you can learn as well that may help.

Looking for City Building Fun? Look no further!

Pros 
- Not Sim City 2013
- Looks very good for a game from 2004
- Gritty, Realistic, Approach to City Design 
- Large Selection of Terrains
- Easily Adjustable Settings
- Amazing Soundtrack
- Modding Kit makes for a longer game

Cons 
- Terrible System Optimization for Newer PCs
- Borderline Broken Demands on Easy and Medium Difficulties without Mods

I have been playing this game for years, picked it up on Steam last Summer. I have to say, the biggest issue I have with it now is Optimization on my PC. You cannot run the game past 1600x1080 without massive screen tearing and Region View Issues and Terrain Glitches (Purely Cosmetic.) Overall I would say the only other noticable issue, after 10 years (10 year old game better than a game made in 2013, who the fuck knew?!) is the broken system demands on Easy and Medium. Both difficulties will eventually go in complete negative demand, with no possible way to recover, unless you install mods, which leads to my next point. Even after all these years the modding community is still huge, so much effort goes into so many mods. Honestly I see no reason not to buy this game.

9/10 - Great game if you like City Planning and Building games.

THE city simulator. It's old but it's the best one out there if you ask me. Even though the graphics aren't full 3D they are still surprisingly high definition and it is fun to zoom in close just to look at the buildings. The graphics really do still hold up. I was honestly surprised.

The gameplay is fantastic if you're into this genre although there are a few problems. Some of those can be fixed with mods, which there are plenty of. There's nothing that would ruin the experience, just some nit-picky things that would make a couple of things easier in the long run. The modding community is great and popular mods are totally worth getting even if some of them change the game mechanics quite a bit. If you new to the genre I would recommend you first play a city or two without mods to get the vanilla experience. For the fans of the genre: mod to your hearts content. You can pull a lot of extra depth out of the game with the right mods.

Depending on how you play once you reach that final stage with your city where everything runs like a finely oiled machine it might feel like you've reached the end. Some may continue to micromanage every little aspect for days to come but I recommend starting a new city. I personally prefer going for a visually impressive city rather than the most efficient one. Sim City becomes more of an information management/puzzle game if you aim for the most productive city. It is more enjoyable to create something visually pleasing.

You will waste days managing your city once you get sucked in. Prepare your calendar accordingly. This among my favorite games of all time.

(I have probably played SimCity a hundred hours back in the day. I still have the disc!)

----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----

Story: -/5 (There isn't one.)
Gameplay: 5/5
Challenge: 3.5/5 (Depends on individual styles of play.)
Discovery: 1.5/5
Replayability: 5/5
Aesthetics: 4/5
Visuals: 4/5
Atmosphere: 2/5
Music: 5/5

[h1] Here is a direct comparison to Cities Skylines: [/h1]

[b]Population limit:[/b]
Cities: Skylines: 1 million
Simcity 4: Unlimited

[b]Max playable area size:[/b]
Cities: Skylines: 9.6x9.6km
Simcity 4: Technically unlimited, although very large maps take a lot of effort to make. (Biggest maps currently downloadable as mods include the entirety of Luxembourg on a 1:1 scale, and also the main Hawaiian island on a real life scale as well.)

[b]Wealth Classes:[/b]
Cities: Skylines: there are no wealth classes, every citizen has the same wealth and the same types of houses get built in every area of the city.
Simcity 4: People are of different wealth, gentrification and urban blight are a thing, and you won't see mansions and middle class villas in polluted areas of the city with bad education access etc.

[b]Skewed population numbers:[/b]
Cities: Skylines: Have you ever noticed how there are ~20 people living in a skyscraper? Well now you do.
Simcity 4: Skyscrapers provide jobs to thousands of people and put a heavy toll on the roads around them as it draws commuters towards it.

[b]Price:[/b]
Cities: Skylines: $320 with all dlc
Simcity 4: $20 with all expansions included (often goes on sale for $5)

While you cannot build crazy windy roads, SimCity 4 is perfect for building a city with grid street plan and you'll get everything you didn't get in SimCity 2013: huge maps, multiple entrances, zoning lots, detailed statistics/graphs/budgets, multiple transportation options from subway, elevated train, freeway, toll gates... the list goes on.

SimCity 4 is rather old game so bear in mind that the software is not optimized for computers with multiple CPU cores/threads (will only take up one core instead of x cores you have on your system).

Thumbs up for the game itself that Maxis (not EA) created.

Thumbs down for the fact that EA drove Maxis into the dirt, and for the fact that they are selling a 20 year old game for $20 which doesn't even work on modern PC's without 3rd party .dll patches... which is basically tantamount to fraud (faulty product/false advertising).  Whatever, EA is trash.

Note: To any newbies attempting to play this, it's a good game but it was designed prior to multi-core CPU technology and will crash constantly unless you isolate the game to running on a single core.  Also, the game has not been updated to support any of the current GPU's/Widescreen resolutions.  Rather than trying to fix these issues via startup commands/options, it's much more convenient to just download the handful of driver files that effortlessly correct these issues from Simtropolis. That is all. https://community.simtropolis.com/forums/topic/762953-performance-and-graphics-list-index-of-all-critical-mods-to-install/

Even now in 2017, 13 years after my first time playing this game, Sim City 4 still stands as one of the best games I own. The UI feels a little dated at this point, but the gameplay and even graphics have held up beautifully. EA should slap a new skin over the UI, redo the models, add in some of the functionality players have been modding in to the game since Rush Hour (NAM, etc.), and rerelease it as SimCity 5. A whole new generation of gamers need to experience one of the best simulation games ever released.

First off I will say that my hour count is not correct, I played this for hundreds more hours on the disc version of the game. I caved in for the Steam version so I don't need my optical drive installed.

This game is my all time favorite game, nothing has come close to beating it. This game released more than 10 years ago still holds up very well thanks to the modders and the community of this game. If you don't like something about the game then search Simtropolis for a mod to fix it. 

As a beginner the modding might seem a bit scary. Tons of dependencies! What do I do?!? I started by installing the mods slowly. First the NAM mod which is essential, then other things such as added trees, buildings, etc. You don't need to install every mod at once to have fun in this game. Just be sure you install all the dependencies to the mods your installing, or else you'll get dreaded brown boxes all over your city (no fun!).

If you need to compare this to modern city builders such as Cities Skylines or Simcity 5 I still think that it beats it. Maybe it's just because I have a great nostalgia about this game. Cities Skylines is an excellent successor to this, but it just can't replace this game in my heart. Compared to Simcity 5, this game is amazing. Bigger cities, doesn't need Origin, and no major Agent problems. 

Whether you want to build an uber realistic city or just a casual city this game is definitely for you. It goes on sale for $5 during the sales, so if you can wait then I would recommend it. If you want a 3D city builder with easy to install mods Cities Skylines is probably for you. 

Also, before running this game check out the guides on Steam on how to run this on modern hardware. My system only needed some tweaks, but yours might need more. My system specs: AMD FX 6300, 8gb DDR3 RAM, AMD Radeon HD 7870, MSI 970a-g43 AM3+ motherboard.

Get ready to waste hours of your life creating the perfect interchange!

Update: Since this review I've upgraded my PC to a i5 4690k, 24gb DDR3 RAM, MSI Gaming 6G GTX 980ti, and MSI Gaming 5 motherboard plus Windows 10 and the game still works great.

After 18 years and hard work of the community this is arguably still the best city builder out there. After buying and installing the game, you need to take a few essential steps to fix bugs and enhance gameplay. Do not play this game without following all the steps in this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ftBJMYHWqns

Most of the negitive reviews are due to improper launch settings on current machines. I've played 45 hours so far and had no crashes. To fix the crash problem on most systems right click on simcity 4> Properties> General> Set launch options> then copy and paste  -intro:off -CPUCount:1 -CPUPriority:high  and click ok.

I put some big time hours into this game when it first came out and loved it then. Now I've put a fair amount in after starting to play again and its as good as ever. IMO this is the best city builder simulation made to date; the modern ones just don't have the same level of complexity or customization.

SimCity 4 is simply the Gold Standard for city builders. Nearly 20 years since the initial release and any new city builder is still compared to SimCity 4. Stability issues can be cured with SC4 Launcher and some fine tuning, the mod community is bottomless as the game has never really lost its following. The isometric views and semi-2D graphics are still pleasant to look at. The graphics have aged like NeoGeo graphics, not N64 graphics. Maybe I'm biased because I brought it home from the Scholastic Book Fair in 4th grade, but maybe, just maybe, it's the greatest city builder of all time.

The game itself is a classic, I love it and have no complaints about it. 
However, Steam upgraded it without warning me about incompatibility issues and now the game isn't compatible with my OS version, so all the cities that took me hundreds of hours to build are unusable and I can't play it anymore. 
If you're going to update the product to a new version that makes it incompatible with older systems, you should at least let users know about it so they can make an informed choice. 
Not to mention that there's basically no customer support.  
Very disappointed.

An absolute classic of the city builder genre. The fact that I - and many others - still enjoy it 20 years after its initial release is a testament to that. There's been numerous games in this genre since then, of course, but I still feel that this is the best game of its type. Plenty of mod/custom content support on sites like simtropolis.com, but it's perfectly playable as is. 

One tip though. Boot up the game, bring up the task manager, go to 'details,' find and right click 'simcity4.exe,' click 'set affinity' and uncheck all of the boxes except for one of the CPU listings; otherwise the game will crash to desktop after a few minutes of play.

[b]I definitely recommend this game to every single person reading this. Such eternal classics as this is certainly a must-play for everyone, regardless of experience with PC gaming.[/b]

Briefly, SimCity 4 is, in my humble opinion, the best modern city building game even up to now. It can offer a lot both to casual players who want to spend their time on a relaxing city-building tycoon with nice visuals and music, and to hardcore players, that may find tons of deep and well hidden mechanics that - if used properly - can get your town sprawling into a huge metropolis in no time. 

And if you still somehow think that this is not enough - there are gazillion mods out there that add anything from new gameplay mechanics to new graphics and sounds. You can alter SimCity however you'd like and that's surely one of the game's major advantages over the majority of other city builders. 

Regarding Cities Skylines - of course it's a much newer and visually better game with tons of new simulation capabilities and new gameplay systems. However, SimCity makes up for it with smart and powerful region mechanics and lots of hidden detail that surely makes SC4, at least in my opinion, both more complex and more interesting than CS. 

If you're deciding what game is better to buy, I would, no doubt, say SimCity4 - but only because its much cheaper than Cities Skylines with all of it's money-grabbing DLCs. If you don't care about the price - buy both, neither of these two games should be ignored.

I spent years playing this game for PC. The CD is still in my laptop right now. For those that don't know, SimCity is the originator of being a mayor, placing down your roads, zoning area for buildings, watching them grow and balancing the budget. This isn't for everyone, but to a lot of us, this is huge fun and SimCity 4 is probably the best in the series.

This is all single player, instead of the more current SimCity 2013 that is focused on multi-player. The game can cycle from night to day, but its just a look and doesn't seem to do anything special. You have terrain control like previous versions of SimCity before you start each game.

You start out in a region map of dozens of land plots. Large, medium and small. You pick a plot of land and make your city. You can then save that city, load the region and start up a new city on a different plot of land or go to a previous city. Why does this matter? Because you can trade between cities, you can export and import water, garbage, energy and so on. Not just that, but the sims / citizens can travel back and forth. Such as living in one town and going to another for work. You'll also have pollution effects that seep into other towns as well. This is all single player, so you need to jump between cities. Because two or more towns can thrive off of one another, you can put your heavy polluting industries in an extremely profitable town on their own with no residents living there to complain about how awful it is. There is no need for police, hospitals or schools if no one is living in your industrial city. Then just make some mass transit system for them to get to and from work.

When you play, you have full control from the start with only a few things locked away unlike Cities XL that requires your city to grow before it unlocks things for you. Because you have full control, that may set you up for failure quickly. Highways, big hospitals, deluxe police stations and so on cost big money and until your city is big, you should keep it small. Once your city grows, the game has ways to tell you that your hospital is too small, such as your staff workers will go on strike. How do you know if its too small? Sadly you can't just hold shift and click the building, you need to click the ? and then the building. It seems tedious, but you'll see what the building can handle and adjust its budget. If you can't adjust the budget high enough, its time to make a bigger version of the building or just plop down another building to do the same thing.

You need to keep your budget balanced, everything will cost monthly money, so you either need to cut spending from places like roads, schools, utilities or raise taxes, which might make some businesses, commerce and residents run to away from your city. When you lower taxes, of course people move in, but then your hospitals, schools and so on will be overcrowded, your buildings will grow larger. Its beautiful.

The game will tell you what kind of zones you'll need, such as low, medium and high density residential, commercial, industry and even agricultural. Its your job to plop them down. It has a graph to show you if you need more and less. If you need less, raise taxes for them, or replace the zone with a new zone. Luckily the game makes it easy to replace zones.

There are all sorts of charts and maps, such as pollution, both water and air. Crime, fire safety, land value and so on. If you want to raise land value, put down police, fire, schools and so on. Then add parks and various things to drive value up. Replace dirty industries that pollute with cleaner industries like medium density manufacturing.

You can also click on zoned buildings to see the crime, water, power, pollutants, and even the driving pattern of where the residents go and where the employees come from. Its a very nice feature. Especially if you're trying to reduce traffic. You have control over roads, avenues, streets, highways, trains, subways, busses and so on. Its fun to see just how far people will ride a bus to work. The game has plenty of charts too, in order to demonstrate how far the average drive is, how much garbage you have, the age and education of your population. Its all a lot of information.

On top of that, you have advisers that will tell you what's good and bad about your city. The game sadly uses pop up windows to tell you what's up, but thankfully there is a setting to turn it off, or else before you know it, you'll have nothing but popups. Instead you can look at the ticker at the bottom of the screen and even go into the advisers section to see their specific needs.

After all is said and done, you can then summon a natural disaster (or truckasaurus) to come and destroy your town. Why you'd want to? Just for the laughs I guess. 

Because this is the deluxe edition, it comes with Rush Hour expansion pack, which gives you the ability to take over vehicles and drive them on the road. Not first person, but still from the normal almost top down perspective. This content gives you missions that will give you cash and other rewards, but really, it doesn't feel like a great addition. Its just there.

This game is a classic, but after 10+ years, I don't think that its aged very well. After months of playing Tropico and Cities XL, those games just seem to run smoother control wise and have explanation to them. Having a hot key for pause would have been nice. Fires break out in your town extremely frequently, no matter how good your fire coverage is. It just breaks the flow of the game, you need to send your fire fighters out to stop the fire and wait while they put it out. That's just not fun.

There are also a few minor bugs, but some that will crash the game. Since there is no autosave, you can lose an hour's worth of progress if not an entire city.

It is still an enjoyable game and I can recommend it more than SimCity 2013. Is it worth the $10 - $20? No and yes. If you enjoy mayoring sims, you can sink days and months into this game, then its worth it, but you should wait for a $5 sale if not cheaper.

Took me a while to be able to play longer than 20 minutes without crashing. But my launch settings are as follows and seems to work for now:

-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -CPUCount:1 -intro:off -gl

put -intro:off -CPUCount:1 -f -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 in launch options and the game runs smooth as heck! one of my favourite city building games out there, some minor flaws but still fun as hell. would advise to download a program that autosaves the game each 10 minutes or so .. saves you alot of anger

Cities skylines is a city painter with no real simulation. It's paint a city and watch the traffic ai go bananas

Simcity 4 on the other hand has more realistic and lifelike simulation elements and in general the events and details in the city really make it feel life like.

One of my favorite games of all time, I can't stop playing. SimCity 4 is one of the best city building games, IMHO.

It runs great on Windows 10, but crashes upon startup. To fix this and play in modern resolution (1920x1080), you need to enter the following in the launch options:

-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -f -intro:off -CPUCount:1 -d:DirectX -CPUPriority:high

SimCity BestCity

aight, Cities:Skylines is probs the best city designer game out there. With a yuuuge modding community and dedicated studio, CO have made a game where it's totally possible to build a realistic looking city.

you want to design the best looking city in a city building game, Cities:Skylines lets you put together a city with skyscrapers and extensive highway and mass transit networks carefully designed to the terrain's elevation and slope, with consideration to the aesthetic build of the land around you. You'll peel back and be very satisfied with your city of barely 40,000 people chugging your 8x quadcore beast. Then you'll load it up again and wait for 37 minutes as all of the assets take their time to load up. Then you play the best game of Traffic Management Simulator ever, take screenshots of road layouts that look like photos from a Real Estate brochure, it's amazing!

After 1600 hours of C:S gameplay I find there's something that SimCity 4 does better.

The simulation part of city building.

SimCity 4 takes moments to load up a city of nearly a million inhabitants. You deal in a more abstracted simulation, which helps to immerse you in managing the expansion of your city, improving services, and designing interesting layouts within the limitations offered by the grid layout. And even those limitations can be worked around if you bother getting mods.

SC4's biggest weakness is the lack of modding support from EA, but here they shine in an unusual way, and that's the community support. EA is garbage, but the SC community is great. It's much smaller but very dedicated. You find mods and an active community of people with a great attitude.

The CS community is weaker in this sense. There are a heap of modders and asset creators in CS who make amazing things, and I use them, but you also find many more gatekeepers in the Paradox/CS forums who tell you your ideas are garbage, and admins who are triggerhappy and also tell you that your ideas are garbage.

In one way, the limitations of a game designed over 10 years ago do hold SimCity 4 back, and it's a testament to how great this game is as a city building simulator that it's still so replayable and fun.

Imagine if we could get the old Maxis team back, get them to forget the last two iterations of the SimCity franchise (that weird SimCity Societies, which was bad, and SimCity 2013, which was also bad), give them 2020 game making tools, and just imagine how cool SimCIty could become.

WARNING: To fix crashing, go to right click Simcity 4 - > Properties -> General and add '-CPUCount:1'

The game was and is the best city simulation game. I highly recommend to everyone.

EA's app ruins the experience of any of their games. Valve needs to use their position to force EA's hand and get EA games purchase via Steam to be playable without having to launch via EA app. I can no longer play many games I paid money for and just had to refund another game because EA's garbage app cannot launch any of them. Truly the worst company, and I cannot recommend players purchase ANY of their games on PC (or at all, if you can manage). Unfortunate because I loved this game and wish I could play it again. Thanks EA.

Since I won't touch SimCity 2013 (and Origin in general) due to all the problems and irritants those bring to the table, SimCity 4 is the most recent choice of SimCity games that I can really play. It is dated and has some issues such as lack of widescreen support and the other usual issues older games have with newer OS's, but that can be fixed. And despite that, from what I have heard, this game is [i]still[/i] better than the recent remake even without all those online issues that game had, with more features and larger maps to build cities on. Also this game has a strong modding community (Simtropolis) with an insane amount of new buildings and stuff to add to your game. Ideally you want a good PC if you plan on making super-big cities and don't want your game to lag like crazy, but even my poo PC can more or less handle this fine despite having built cities more densely populated than any currently existing on Earth.

So if you feel the sudden urge to build cities, and yet realize that so many city building games of the past few years have a host of glaring issues, then SimCity 4 is your best choice. Have fun! :D

Pretty solid part of the SimCity family. Probably my favorite SimCIty after the SNES version of the original. If you're after a good city simulator and your computer can't handle City Skylines (like mine, lol), I'd say go for this.

Sim City 4 Deluxe score
8 / 10

So, you bought into SimCity 5 as a young person wondering why everybody was so excited. Played it for a few hours, days maybe and wondered if those that were excited were completely nuts. 

I can't blame you if you are described in the above statement. I hate SimCity 5, the terrible Origin thing, the dreadful online experience, the stupid limitations to what you can and can't do. But if you use SimCity 5 as an excuse for not getting your hands on this classic, than you are destined to fail in life. Heed my warning, spend some cash on this, particularly if it is on offer. You will not regret it.

Do this to keep from crashing...

Open your task manager, go to details, and on SimCity4 set affinity 

This game can not run on a multi core processor, you need to set affinity to only one of the CPU cores

Never crash again

You can look how many hours I played.And I can easily say that this game is the Da Vinci of the city-builder games. And modding is incredible.. Mod community is like Louvre Museum. You can find any kind of great, oustanding, authentic mod -buildings, road networks, maps in the community. 

Do you want to create masterpieces ? Then, you should play Simcity 4

SimCity 4 WAS a great game but unfortunately in 2021 on Windows 10 it is no longer optimized and is not running well with constant crashes taking away from my experience. In a nutshell I would always recommend SimCity 4 (and the older entries before 4) to anyone but given the lack of updates and lack of optimization it isn't worth buying in 2021.

Sad to see but hopefully the series makes a modern day return with the successes of Cities: Skylines and more.
Still a good game after over 20 years. To improve the experience, install the mods recommended by Rob's Red Hot Spot on YouTube in Rob's Guide to SimCity 4 - 8 Essential Mods, Tools and Bugfixes.

People honestly trying to review a 16 year old game is just sad, tbh. And like it or not, SC4 is still the most nuanced entry in the genre, and is the most extensively mod-friendly; still maintaining an active modding community on Simtropolis and SC4 Devotion *to this day*.

There are even people who have been working on the same region for over a decade. When you look at modern games, and how depreciated the value and content is, potentially having a decade's worth of enjoyment from a game simply isn't possible in this day and age. You'd be lucky to get *months* out of modern live service products, before getting bored.

Whining about how dated the game is falls flat to me, because there are countless mods that help bring the game up to date. The communities are still active, friendly and welcoming to newcomers, and the game isn't that hard to customize. Sure, there are some hard-coded problems like no multi-core support, but they're not crippling problems as often claimed.

Some people have devoted many years of their lives to keeping this game thriving. And in my eyes, Sim City 4 isn't a mere game. It's more like a hobby or passion. And the industry (especially EA) just doesn't make games like this anymore. That's what you're getting from this game; a look into a bygone era; the golden age of simulation games on PC.

Q: Oh? Then why do you only have 96 hours played, if it means so much to you? I am very intelligent. Check and mate, millennial!
A: Because most of my hours played are on a WELL worn Deluxe Edition CD, my dude. That SC4 is on Steam at all is a blessing, because I wouldn't have been able to keep the CD working for much longer.

It took me too long to recognize the beauty and depth of this game. The possibilities are endless and it really makes you feel like you're designing a city. Traffic vs population density, easy money vs pollution, jobs vs population. Everything is interrelated. For me, it helped me appreciate the complexity of city planning in the real world and almost makes me wish I had done it in college. As for now, I'll stick with designing cities in the fake world of SimCity 4.

Ever thought you could make a better city? Pah, I could be a better Mayor; well now you can! SimCity 4 is just that and offers this opportunity and lets you sit in the chair titled mayor. I've definitely clocked up more hours in the days I installed this on ME and XP. 

SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is another one of those games that has been created by EA... EA? Not again you say - except this time.. EA has really created a game and has polished it up to its standards. SC4 is one of the older prequels to 'Societies' and the 2013 SimCity relaunch; released after Sim City 3000, it showed off superb graphic capabilities at the time and invented new ways to enjoy building a simulated city, where you play as the city's major, managing the: finances, housing stock, roads, ports, resident satisfaction, transit, and employment.

You start off with the tutorial scenario which are all in-game. It forces you try things out as you go along, completing objectives which teaches you how to build, manage power/water supplies, landscaping, and the rest. After you complete that (or can't be bothered to and skip it), you can either build in that same region or start building cities in one of the few preset regions that have already been created.

Running your 'regions' as a Mayor is all about understanding what generates tax and increases monthly cost. In between all that, there are no objectives, and as your revenue rises, so does your population, which means a bigger list of demands which requires more expenditure. Building cleaner buildings (i.e. renewable energy) or schools can benefit the city's future pathway, but will have a serious hit on your monthly expense, expect to raise your taxes, lose reputation, and lower management costs should you fall in debt. If you do fall in debt, the game does offer a few short-term resolutions. You start to unlock buildings that generate a small amount of income which normally take a few hours to do so normally; you will also be able to take out a loan from the bank, or you can carry on raising taxes or just destroy your schools and hospitals (unwise!!). 

When starting a city you will decide on a Mayor's name and city name. There are three difficulty settings to pick from which affects the costs, starting money and the levels of income. You first steps is to create power, then allocate three different zones, these are: Residential Zones, Commercial Zones, and Industrial Zones. You then sit back and watch development take place as cement trucks, family cars, and trucks move in to take up the zones. You cannot choose exactly what buildings you want to be build there, as it is dependant on a 'building style' option, and factors including its surroundings, population of the city, education and health levels etc. You can, however, limit the construction style to Low Density, Medium Density, or High Density. Low Density forces the houses being built to house small families or mansions; whilst High Density houses towering skyscrapers which can be an overwhelming sight to look at. The Commercial zones offers offices, retail stores, and local diners; and lastly the Industrial Zone creates factories, from dirty industry, manufacturers, to high-tech research buildings. A good combination of all 3 makes a good city; which makes good profit, which gives you lots of money to re-invest into your (unlucky) citizens.

After creating your zones you also need to think about your increasing demands for water, power, and waste collection. A city will not work efficiently without power and water. You will need to think about the education of your citizens, placing schools, colleges and libraries help enhance their knowledge which in-turn, create better jobs, provide places for wealthier people, which all contribute to making a great city.

Safety is also another priority in the game. You also have to build Police Stations, Fire Departments, Hospitals in key locations where they will help make your city a safer place which attracts wealthier citizens moving into your city, and again, creates a better city.

Lastly, another factor you have to remember when creating your city is Environment. You will, in some point later on in the game, have to build parks, flower gardens, fields of greens and eventually reduce the level of water and air pollution your city, from the early game where you had factories and unskilled workers. This is because you need good land to attract wealthier Sims who have educated to run more profitable office and tech businesses. In addition to building green space, you will also have to plant trees, or (one of my favourites) raise taxes on Dirty Industry to keep them away from producing in your city. Trading is also a valuable way to generate income, by connecting roads and rail with neighbouring cities. It's an automated process so you don't need to worry about it later on. 

The expansion pack Sim City 4 Rush Hour adds a whole new dimension of gameplay to it, introducing a new method of gaining income and unlocking structures more easily. You can compete in missions which lets you drive literally cars, planes, boats in a top-side view similar to to an RTS setting, except only by using the arrow keys or WASD Keys. 

Overall, Sim City was a huge leap in City designing simulations and is probably used as a template for recent games. It doesn't need as much micromanaging as SimCity Societies nor SimCity, but is still an entertainign classic to own. Regardless of your experience with City Life, Cities In Motion, Tropico, CivCity, SimCity Societies (or even SimCity), SimCity 4 is still a fun and enjoying experience, and should be classed as a landmark in its genre.

Important: 

C:\Program Files\Steam\steamapps\common\SimCity 4 Deluxe\Apps\SimCity 4.exe -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -intro:off -CPUCount:1

Write this into the shortcut for Sim City, in the Target section. You will get the highest resolution possible, no intro and the game will only use 1 Core, which should eliminate any crashes. (Use your personal steam path and then add:  -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -intro:off -CPUCount:1)

If you feel disturbed by the doorbells and knocks when clicking on a building, download Silent Doorbells and Knocks.dat. from community dot Simtropolis dot com posted by CorinaMarie and put it into the plugins folder (...\Steam\steamapps\common\SimCity 4 Deluxe\Plugins).

For retro gamers I also recommend to use custom music from the SNES and NES versions of the game. All you have to do is to put the MP3's into the Music folder of Sim City 4: ...\Steam\steamapps\common\SimCity 4 Deluxe\Radio\Stations\Mayor\Music and enable custom music inside the game.

Even after 21 years, and three major modern attempts at creating a new pure city-building game, nothing comes close to touching SC 4. And I'm not saying that just simply out of nostalgia. The only bad quality to SC 4, is its infamous instability issues, which can be controlled if you learn what causes CTDs and how to prevent them. 

The biggest reasons why SC 2013, CS1, and CS2 doesnt touch this game:

1) Realistic city sizes. SC 2013 city squares are childishly way too tiny. Not even a modern American village IRL could realistically fit on them. Nevermind, a city of over 10,000. 

Meanwhile, CS1 and CS2 becomes so bogged down with the AI trying to control tens of thousands of different agents, that most people's hardware cannot get much above 100,000 in population.

2) Graphics. The graphics of SC 4 is realistically gritty. It inst this weird cartoon-ey plastic look that Colossus Order STILL insisted on making for CS2! Especially the vehicles! Like. Come ON! This is now the 2020s. The idiotic and weirdly childish cartoon graphics trend of the 2010s should FINALLY be over! I'm a grown adult who wants to build a REALISTIC city! NOT in the environment of Paw Patrol!

SC 4 graphics have a more realistic gritty feeling to them compared to the 3 year old child-level Paw Patrol 3D graphics of SC 2013, CS1 and CS2. 

Those are the two biggest issues that would launch a modern city-builder to new heights.

Simply the best city simulator out there and a serious challenge to boot. Not without its flaws of course, but with 18+ years of community mods and addons that are still expanding, it just never gets old.

Ignore the naysayers, the game when setup right is totally rock-solid, Steam don't help though, since all modern machines need you to add the command -CPUCount:1 under Set Launch Options. This is because the game crashes if you have a multi-core system, which as I write this in 2021, let's face we pretty much all do. Why this isn't there by default is beyond me.

Just add the NAM (Network Addon Mod) to transform the number of Transport networks and options. Although I'd highly recommend looking into other mods too, but the NAM is really a must.

The real beauty of SC4 however comes from being a 2.5D or Isometric view, rather than the fully 3D games of today. This means the game uses pre-rendered assets, rather than having to render every model (3D) on the fly. In practical terms, it means the models can be highly detailed with no polygon limits whatsoever, because the game only has to 'wallpaper' a 2D texture onto a simple 3D box. That makes for some astounding visuals, without melting your PC, in fact this game doesn't need a particularly powerful PC to play its best. However, being an older game your hardware needs good support for DirectX 7 legacy modes, something newer GPUs are starting to eschew. Even that can be bypassed these days by using something called a Wrapper.

But really what makes it the ultimate game of its genre, is the hidden complexity of the simulator. There is so much going on and you as mayor need to keep everything under control to succeed. Unlike the modern 3D equivalents like SimCity (2013) and Cities Skylines, you can't just play the game on auto-pilot. I get the feeling because the simulators of the newer titles don't properly work and to compensate, you can get away with letting things go bad for a long time before it actually harms your progress. Whereas SC4 demands your attention at all times, especially during the later stages of development. If you prefer a detailed simulation, there really is no comparison between them. Start slow, take things step by step and realise this is a reactive experience and you should remain in control of things. There is a bit of a steep learning curve, but the game is also very rewarding for those who stick with it. I certainly wouldn't recommend it for the more casual player, Cities Skylines is likely to be more enjoyable in that case. Maxis pushed the limits of what was possible in the early 21st century and their creation has stood the test of time because they just don't make games like this anymore.

So recently, I've seen many people complaining about the crashes the game faces. This is a problem I have as well; however, there is a simple fix.

1. Open Task Manager.

2. Go to the Processes bar.

3. Find the process for SimCity 4 (not hard to find).

4. Right click the process, and then click Set affinity.

5. Deselect all processors and then select just CPU 0.

6. Save and exit.

Congratulations, you have just fixed any and all crashes due to your system being too powerful. Stop complaining about your crashes and a) save often and b) find the fix online yourself. I found it on some forums from 2008, you had 10 years to work this out.

Probably my one most played game in all my life. The possible scale of cities and mods makes this an infinite source of fun. While the hraphics may be a bit dated you can still create buitiful and lively cities that feels more real then any other city building game I've played.

SimCity 4 was my first city builder game. That statement is not nostalgic - I first played SimCity 4 this year rather than 20 years ago, and I am very happy to say that this game is awesome! There is a lot to like.

First of all, I've had no technical problems or annoyances. I play the game through Steam with no mods, no EA account and no crashes! The controls are largely intuitive to me, even though the game is 20 years old and I've never played a city builder before.

The music is fantastic. In my opinion it strikes just the right balance of being lively and engaging whilst remaining backgrounded enough to not distract you from the gameplay or get irritating even when you play for hours at a time (and it's difficult not to!).

The artstyle is cute and fun. It's obviously not modern but that doesn't stop it from being a treat for the eyes!

The challenging gameplay is both good and bad. It's great to have to think about how to manage your city's growth and how to add new facilities without going bankrupt. I enjoy the difficulty when I understand it or when there is enough information to figure it out. However, some things are left unexplained which makes the gameplay feel frustrating at times. I've played for over 100 hours and still feel at a loss as to how to deal with certain problems that arise. When I've paid attention to the various graphs and data views and still can't understand the source of a problem, I had hoped the team of city advisors would offer guidance or at least nudge me in the right direction, especially considering that I've been playing on easy difficulty. I even read the digital manual that comes with the game and couldn't see any tips in there either. I'm not so keen on challenges that are hard because information is unavailable. Still, I keep learning as I play, so it may be that experience is the best teacher for SimCity 4.

I think the thing that has me so invested in SimCity 4 is the attention to detail that creates a sense of activity and of life occupying the cities. There are Sims spraying graffiti on the walls of commercial properties, farmers on ladders picking apples in the fields, zombies roaming the graveyards. When you look closely, you can see that even duplicates of the same item, such as the bus stops, actually differ. For example, one bus stop may have a hedge, a phone booth and newspaper vending machines, while another may have a fence, a post box and a drinks machine. I really appreciate these little touches; it's adorable <3 The sound effects that correspond to each building, such as the 'shh' when you click on the library, are also great fun. The sense of life is supported by the continuous change and development seen in the buildings. A building can be reconstructed to house more Sims as demand increases in your city, and the architecture changes over the years (if you choose) which gives the city a feeling of history. Similarly, problems in the cities are shown through buildings falling into disrepair or rubbish piling up on the streets. The game does an amazing job of demonstrating your influence.

SimCity 4 is challenging, vibrant, satisfying and so much fun.

Actual review (yes, cities skylines taken into comparison):

This is the supreme reigning king of city builders. While in time it will likely be beaten by Cities: Skylines, as of now this is still the best in terms of purely easy to use UI, fun things to do (the TL;DR is easily possible ingame), sheer number of mods, and customizability. I have thousands of hours in on the simcity series as a whole and only bought this on steam as another version (I still use disc/GoG versions more). The majority of the hours went into either 3000/unlimited or this version, both pre-and post-rush hour expansion (included in this one).

Keep in mind this is also the HARDEST of the simcity games, and even on easy it is very possible to screw yourself over several hours in with a chronicly failing city that slowly decays into destruction on its' own. It's also one of the most fun, however, as SimCity 3000 did away with the terraforming (mostly) of simcity 2000, and this was the first (of 2) in the series to introduce regional gameplay with multiple cities interacting on a massive map. Big difference between this and the latest simcity, however, is that in addition to preset regions, YOU create them. You can terraform them, modify their size, city layouts/sizes literally using microsoft paint, plop the cities, set up the city interactions, etc. The only thing missing is the multiplayer, but with the city sizes in this being arguably 16 times larger than simcity 2013, that more than makes up for it as you will sink dozens of hours into filling up a map and customizing it the way you want to with what is also the best UI in the series, doing a lot of the work for you and letting you optimize where and when needed.

So, why would I even recommend this over Cities: Skylines?

AS OF RIGHT NOW. As of the time of this review, Cities: Skylines is a fantastic city builder with a mass modding community and...that's it. There is no regional play, terraforming has to be modded in to be performed mid-game, the art style is VERY bland and probably has less than 100 buildings the game can call upon to place down in zones, the UI when placing roads and such has a lot of issues that make it much harder to use than it should be, there's a lot of missing features that have to be modded in, and the ability to truly customize the city is significantly lower than in this game. While I will continue to play cities skylines, I have the game heavily - and I mean HEAVILY - modded to even begin to replicate the magic of SimCity 4 and its' predecessors. I feel like the game was designed around being better than SimCity 2013 which in some aspects (art, soundtrack, pure...fun things to do, customizability) it isn't, but the major missing things in SimCity 2013 (city sizes, DRM, lack of map editing) were what drew people in. That, and the game expected it so it would have a large modding scene to fix what the developers didn't add. That's understandable, as the dev team is VERY small for Cities Skylines, but the thing is that SimCity 2013 lowered the bar of city builders to a point where Cities: Skylines was no longer just below it, but far above it.

Understand this: I WILL continue to play cities skylines. And I believe it is a great game. But it is going to take a monster that can do what Cities Skylines did to fix the SimCity 2013 formula, and also take the time to add in what SimCity does RIGHT, before there will be a city builder capable of dethroning this one. It has to look and play the part, and give the user the ability to have FUN above all with customizability, destruction, and other random things that occur (like piloting a military chopper guns blazing into your own house...like you can in this game).

If you do NOT own this game and are a fan of city builders, I highly encourage you to get it now. At a price of $20 for the base AND its expansion, the only downside is compatibility with modern OS systems, and it is still possible to make it work with a bit of stuff done. What you're ultimately getting is the definitive city builder, and what remains the king of city builders that many of us fondly remember from our childhoods and will continue to remember. This is a timeless game in ways others simply cannot and likely will not ever live up to.

The simulation genre wouldn't be what it is without the venerable SimCity series. Since 1989, the many entries in the line have allowed people to become virtual mayors and design cities of just about any shape and size, limited only by the contents of the game itself. They've come a long way from the original and branched out in many different ways across platforms, and not every installment has been a success. SimCity 4 is often described as the last great SimCity, and with that and my own remembered fondness for it I decided to see how it's held up over the last 13 years.

Honestly I find it a little difficult to describe the nature of SimCity, because it is such an elemental part of the genre. You lay down roads, outline zones for development of homes and businesses, build power plants and fire stations, balance your taxes against your utility expenditures, and grow your little town as large as it will go. These are all core concepts pioneered by the series, but 4 presents them with greater refinement. Each individual service building like police stations and hospitals can have their funding adjusted to meet local demand, so you can build expensive services and then scale them back to what you can afford until you need more. Zone density can also be scaled up or down without destroying existing buildings, allowing them to grow or shrink as needed.

It's one of the purest and accessible presentations of the city-building formula out there, with no production chains or unlockables to concern yourself with. You build what you want, where you want, with the only limitations being space and money. SimCity 4 is far more generous than its predecessors with the latter, allowing you to start with enough money to cover most of a map right from the outset. And with control of individual building funding, it's a simple task to keep your budget in the green. The maps remain plenty large enough for bustling metropolises, but they're also connected by regions, allowing you to get a grand overview of your cities, granting your people the option of commuting to other areas, and creating massive metro areas with interconnected cities and neighborhoods.

The end result is a robust and expansive city-builder limited only by its age. SimCity 4 is still a 2D game, despite some voxel trickery to make it look deeper and more dynamic than it is. You're laying everything out on a grid, which makes building at anything other than right angles either cumbersome in the case of roads and rails, or impossible in the case of buildings. The terrain is deformable and conforms to your constructions to a point, but if your landscape is very hilly at all you'll end up with houses built on soaring foundations larger than the dwelling itself, and beaches and piers plunging off of your coastlines into the deep. The detailed pixel art of the buildings is impressive, and each is rendered from four directions so you can rotate the camera, but they look chunky at max zoom and indistinct at a distance.

Despite these shortcomings, SimCity 4 remains one of the finest city-builders you can lose yourself in. The steady pace of construction matched with the enormous variety of buildings and services to work towards means you can spend hours crafting a single city without having to wait for long periods or growing bored. The data displays show you everything you need to understand how your city operates, from pollution and traffic overlays to the actual routes your citizens take daily. There are even optional driving missions you can take in your own city and Sims you can move in to get more personal feedback. It might not be the prettiest or slickest offering anymore, but SimCity 4 has stood the test of time and remains one of the most addictive and comprehensive city-builders on the market.

There has not been a better city builder in over two decades.

I played hundreds of hours of this game as a child.  When taking of the rose-colored glasses in 2020 I don't really think it holds up against the likes of Cities: Skylines, but it's still enjoyable to visit now and again.

Pros:
*  Lots of interesting structures to unlock.  After 16 years I still feel live I've not seen everything this game has to offer.
*  Absolutely fantastic music.  Very few games come close to the quality seen here.
*  Region scale, and the interplay between cities, can yield some very interesting results.
*  Per-structure funding is a lot better than what's in C:S
*  The Maxis personality (mostly their quirky sense of humor) is infectious to this day.

Cons:
*  To get it running on modern resolutions without graphical glitches you've got to play around with launch options
*  Runs poorly due to the single-threaded back end.  This doesn't really matter too much since you're usually playing from a locked camera perspective, though.
*  The grid layout vs C:S' open-form means of construction feels really limiting.
*  Some UX, like that used in placing elevated rail, can be really cumbersome to work with.
*  Mass transit can be a mess.  Route management in C:S has spoiled me, so coming back to this and placing a subway station just to see it overwhelmed with little I can do to fix it (aside from building a 2nd) is annoying.
*  Buildings seem to drop in wealth levels for no apparent reason (building information shows everything's fine)
*  Cars disappearing on the road all the time makes the city a lot less interesting to look at than what I remember.

Cons aside, this is a must-play if you're in to city builders / management games.  Every modern game in the genre has looked to this for inspiration, and even though I don't think it's the king any more it's still a legend.

This game is the bomb diggity, even after 13+ years.
PROS:
++Great, mostly balanced gameplay
++Good looking 2.5D graphics
++Endless amount of mods and assets
++Has full 1080p support, in a *13 year old game!*
++Runs pretty well on nearly anything
CONS:
--Hard to get working properly (I suggest looking for the SC4Launcher and 4GB patch if you want to really boost how the game works)
--Can crash a lot without the right settings
--Mods are difficult to install w/o Steam Workshop support
--The simulation is often finicky, but granted, there was only so much devs could do back then (pickup the Network Addon Mod for improved traffic simulation)
--The tutorial isn't super-helpful in helping you understand how the regional simulation works

Overall, if you're looking at this vs Cities: Skylines (and have a PC that can run C:S), go pick up Cities. It's a newer game with generally a more powerful and realistic simulation. However, I highly suggest dropping this into your wishlist and waiting for a sale, which is quite often on this title, because this game has a certain charm that I don't think any city builder has or ever will replicate.
After playing Cities Skylines I was impressed but I was still constantly itching to play this. 12 years old and it continues to be the greatest city builder in my opinion.

fantastic game... unfortunately choppy on newer systems. also no connection anymore to addional content. I wish steam would somehow work a deal with Origins for more games and content, as I prefer the Steam site to Origins.

This is the last good Simcity game, the other Simcity game should never be mentioned unless the word 'delete' is used in the same sentence. I will say sure this game is outdated graphics wise and the highest resolution option is 1600x1200. But with a few tweaks using Steam launch option commands, its good to go for most setups. The nicer little details are more the things that happen in the world you build in. Like animals in the forests/oceans that make it hard to justify building over their habitats. Driving missions to earn money while your city develops. The point is it just feels nice to watch and play with things as they progress.

However I recommend anyone reading this during *ANY* sale to atleast buy it/try it for an hour or two then refund it if you dont like it. $15 for a game this old and slightly unsupported was way too high for me.

SimCity 4 is all about quality. In my opinion gameplay is excellent (perfect timekiller), mods (it is still has a huge community of players) work superb. It is a joy to play. Even after many years SimCity 4 runs almost like a dream with mods and there are no microtransactions. So impressive for modern gaming industry. Maybe in distant future we will get refreshed SC4 with renewed graphics and sound.

This game is hands down the best city simulator, but it requires the Network Add-on Mod (NAM) and a few other plug-ins that can be downloaded from places like Simtropolis.com or SC4fanatic.com to be a great sim game. The mods add things like rural highways, bridges, and better route finding and capacities on the road network. As a civil engineer, I love this game to this day even though I have been playing it for over a decade. I work on my region daily and find the simulation with the addons is pretty close to real world dynamics as far as transportation, sanitation, and water works. Huge regions can run on todays computers with downloadable real maps and terrain available- you can build in real locations, build Seattle with a world class waterfront or maybe download the Alsek Bay area of Alaska and build a series of mountain towns between the towering mountains and long beaches along a river with alpine lakes. A whole digital world is available to rule over!

Having lived through the Maxis downfall of the late 90s and eventual handover to EA, and having played every Sim City but the newest one, having loved different things about all of them and having realised I'd spent more time on Sim City 4 Deluxe than any other, I felt I owed it to this game to give it my retroactive review.

Like most of us city-builder fans I tried out and fell in love with Cities Skylines shortly after it came to the limelight and like all new and improved game interfaces and technology, my expectations for a City Builder have increased along side them. So it's hard for me to appreciate the Sim Cities now as much as I did then but SC4D, despite having many annoyances with UI and a lack of some modern freedoms does still offer an unprecedented amount of control in the Sim City range.
Small things like different zoning densities and diagonal roads don't seem like a big deal, but because Maxis was basically the only big company doing these titles, it was a game-changer for the time and playing around with those limited complexities is still incredibly satisfying in 2017.
The other thing SC4 does better than many other games is the introduction and tutorial of the concepts and screens. Everything is intuitive, even to non city builders and I remember always loving Maxis' ability to produce fluid gameplay from start to finish, it's held up just as well today.

Ultimately most of the things I don't like about this game are because more modern titles have done them better, added more freedoms and removed small annoyances, but to criticise a game by comparing it to something that didn't exist at the time is a fools errand. Yes, I would recommend other titles above this now if you're new to the genre or have limited cash, but I would also very much recommend trying out some of the older Sim City titles because they're still engrossing and satisfying and stand up well today.

This is the most addictive game ever (as you can see from how many hours I've played it :P)
The mods that can be found for the game are fantastic and the boundaries of the cities are seamless, unlike the current Sim City (Sim*cough*Town)

after nearly two decades, it's still the best city builder out there

just be sure to install NAM, add -CPUCount:1 to the game's launch options, and save often to avoid losing progress whenever it CTDs [i](trust me; no matter what you do, it will.)[/i]

SimCity 4 > SimCity 5

The game is quite fun even though it is old. It IS IMPORTANT to note that you need to put a code (look it up online if you want) into the start up of the game on steam, since the game does not use your computers multi processors. This prevents your game from crashing *cry*. 

Pros:
-region view to see your cities. The game comes with London, San Francisco, Berlin, New York and two fantasy ones. 
- Development demand is based on your region, allowing specialization. 
- Lots of types of buildings that look old and new. 
- Famous American Landmarks and some international
- The game is challenging, even on easy. 
- Day and Night.
- Can name streets, rivers, land. (toggable)

Cons:
- No option to turn on Automatic disasters like in other games. (except for fire)
- Public transport is difficult to work with and sims really just prefer driving.

I have this strange feeling when I'm not playing this game that I'm wasting my life.

And when I do play it - there are people shouting at me and demanding more money.

But it is overall a really amazing simulator, I fully recommend it.

I've spent probably thousands of hours on this game before I even had a Steam account (big Sims fan in general). It wasn't until I got it a few months ago that I actually even had a clue on how to even properly play the game. But moving along from memory lane, this game is still amazing for being as old as it is.

Having been released in 2003 and made available on Steam in 2010, this game and even the game series itself can honestly be seen as revolutionary for the city-building and simulation games that have followed since the original simcity was released. This game was almost in a way ahead of its time and in my opinion STILL outshines many other city-building games (maybe I haven't played enough but who knows) that try to recreate in their own sense the management strategy that SimCity brought upon the world of gaming. The replay value of this game is beyond compare, for something different is always awaiting you, and the mods are endless to build off what the game originally provided.

The beauty about this particular game is that it can be both a place anything anywhere and watch what happens sort of game but it also can be a complex square by square city builder where you perfect every detail and the style of your houses to the taxes each individual industry and residential type pays. Many modern city builders try to play off this but say unlike City Skylines where you have to work your way up to get more land to begin with, there are countless areas and regions of all sizes for you to use and connect and even create to eventually have the ultimate city or state or nation or whatever you wish. Plus the music is pretty damn great as well. The game just allows you to almost settle down and lose yourself. SimCity 4 has to honestly be my FAVORITE city-builder out there, as it still is for many. But that's just a personal opinion. For it's current price of $19.99 and replay value that is seemingly endless, i'd say it's worth it.

11/10 would obliterate city again and restart when things start to get out of hand

This is [u]the[/u] definitive city building simulator. It is sitting on the top of the arc drawn by SimCity 2000 and SimCity 3000. In this game you can get bankrupt if you don't find the fine balance. In this game you can build anything from the start on - it is only limited by your money. Money, and not some artificial constraint, like metro building at a population barrier. Yes, the Cities series. Cities are no simulators. All hail SimCity, the mother of all city simulators!

It's crazy how 20 years later this is still the best City sim game out there.
I've put tons of hours into SC2013, and plenty of hours into C:S, but I definitely prefer this one. The attention to detail is unmatched. Cities: Skylines is more of a transportation sim, the management/financial tools are a joke compared to Sim City 4.

It's also impressive how well the graphics have aged. Sure, it's definitely 20 years old, but you can get some awesome scenery in this!

Oh, and if you have crashes, add this to the launch options: -CPUCount:1
Classic game - the way SimCity is meant to be (unlike their newer game which has failed in so many ways). Big maps, nice options - challenging, slightly dated but definitely still playable graphics.

Ah, SimCity 4, the best, in my opinion, of all of the SimCity games. The graphics are dated, being that this was released around fifteen years ago, but don't let that deter you. Play times depend on how much you enjoy city building games. I myself have spent 2-4 hours today playing it.

 The U-Drive-It mode is pretty cool, as it lets you drive through your transportation system with a variety of vehicles, but can get annoying over time with the other cars.

 The regions are a nice addition, as you can have cities depend on each other, plus some of the regions come in the shape of several real-life cities, albeit with no structures. In the same vein, importing and exporting cities & regions are useful. If you have a sprawling metropolis and want to share it with the world, you can! Have a police state with stations on every corner? You now can show it to your friends and family!

 On the game crashes, there are, apparently, mods to fix this, but a simple fix without the use of mods exists. Simply navigate to your Steam Library, right-click SimCity 4 (assuming you own it), click properties, and under the General Tab click Launch Options. In the box, paste -CPUCount:1 (without quotes.) I have done this myself, and haven't had a single crash since doing so. My OS is Windows 10 Home.

There is also a 3rd party launcher, made specially for SC4, with a nice 'n simple UI, and several QoL improvements, such as autosaving, and the ability to completely skip the opening videos entirely. Here's the official page; https://www.vitim.us/project/sim-city4-launcher/ Click on the Download now phrase at the bottom to, you've guessed it, download. I recommend this option.

The SimCity 4 playerbase is a very devoted one, with a website based around it, among a few other city builders. https://community.simtropolis.com They feature modifications for the game, plus a gallery, and forum. And city journals? Looks to be detailed diaries on people's cities. Huh. Anyway! Here's a good mod, if you'd like some diversity and/or complexity for your transit systems, try NAM, or the Network Addon Mod. https://community.simtropolis.com/files/file/26793-network-addon-mod-nam-cross-platform/
Got its own darn installer, its so complex.

 In conclusion, I believe SimCity 4 to be a great game, and holds up after 15 years. It has some good mods made for it, as well. My personal rating is 8/10.
Edit: Spelling Errors
Nowadays, Cities: Skyline might be better. But if you're on a budget, playing on a potato like my laptop, or just want some nostalgia factor, it's hard to beat Sim City 4: the last good Sim City.

The beauty of this game is that you can place a nuclear reactor, military facility, casino, and an elementary school right next to each other and people will still be unhappy for some reason.

All in all though, this game was my childhood and with a complex and old systems of mods, can still stand up to modern city simulators of today, albeit with isometric graphics. I most just come back to this every few years for the nostalgia. If you feel like spending a couple extra bucks you don't need on something, might as well be this and have a good evening or two building a simple town or sprawling metropolis.

What is there to say? It was the last great Sim City game, and absolutely my personal favorite. I love the regional stuff. This game has so many good mods too; a very active community. My only wish is that it wasn't so... visually Californian. Climate options would have been cool, but hey, it's a very old title now!

It's a shame EA utterly destroyed this franchise and we will never see another Sim City this good again. As much as I hate the idea of even a single 'nother cent going into EA's pockets I cannot recommend this game enough for sim lovers.

I have been playing SC4 since 2003, it has become a sort of zen meditation to me. It might scare people used to less demanding games since the latter simcity versions don't have such a deep management system, but once you get acquainted with that, it gets really funny and you can concentrate on creating wonderful cities, even by using plugins and mods. Possibilities are endless.
The only problem I have is that my old macbook gets really, really hot when I play.

This game is above all the most famous and classic single player city simulation game. Made by Maxis before being bought out by notorious EA, you can use pipes, tons of transit and road systems for travel, commercial, industries, and even missions within the game. Furthermore you can create not just on city, but a giant world by yourself for yourself. THIS IS WAY FUCKING BETTER THAN SIMCITY 5, the Half-life 3 For Sim-city players.

This is the definitive version of any SimCity. Much better than the sequel SimCity: Societies.

TL;DR: Even though it is 13 years old it is still one of the best examples of a city builder today. I'd rate it [b] 8/10 [/b]

This game was one of the major contributors to Cities:Skylines as it is Paradox's main inspiration for the game. The [i]U-Drive it[/i] Missions are unique to city builders wherein you can interact with your city on a much more indepth level. The economics aren't simplified and the advisors offer advise that can actually be used. For being a very fixed camera in an isometric setup, you get plenty of gorgeous angles and shots. The modding community for this game is still alive as far as I recall, although a lot of it is becoming harder to find certain things such as Network Addon Mod (NAM).  

The main drawbacks of the game are mainly due to its age. Unlike Cities it isn't based on both a free building and grid based snapping system. This is solely grid based and it has a very big drawback, bridges. You can only build bridges certain directions and in straight lines. The other main drawback is performance issues on certain new machines and crashes. But I believe you can find a patch around for a fix for the crashes. A minor more nit-picky issue with the Steam version is that unlike a box you don't get a pamphlet that gives good advice about RCI and how to increase and meet demand, but again you can probably find a picture of the RCI pamphlet on the internet.

Overall the game is excellent. Even though my hours on the Steam edition are lackluster, playing on the two-disk box version is where most of my hours really come from. As said above, [b] 8/10 [/b]

[h1]90 / 100[/h1]

This is still the best city simulator around! Might be going on 10yrs old, and have its limitations but just as addictive and fun to play. Decent mod community too and can run in 1920x1080 with some launch tweaks!

Have played this game on and off for years, long before I was using Steam for everything gaming. I have very fond memories of this game thanks to my dad, and his love for city builder games. Used to spend hours on end building cities with my dad, well mostly sitting next to him and he did most things because I was a little to young to play it properly. But even after all these years I still come back to it, even though we have a modern version of this thanks to Cities: Skylines. So yes, it's worth every penny back then and now, plus you can get this game for dirt cheap nowadays.

I'm like a lot of people here - the hours we've played don't reflect the many more we've done on CD. In my mind there are only really two city building games: Cities Skylines and Sims City 4. Others have tried, and they all appear to have failed, including Sim City and EA who include this in the game pass but have buried Sim Cities Societies and Sim City (reboot) somewhere in a corn field. 

Part of the reason this game wins over a game like Cities Skylines and manages to keep relevant is because it's avoided getting into the minute modelling process that many other games have done. Rather than having real individual people that live their entire lives, SC4 keeps things a bit abstract. As it turns out, it makes it easier to manage as a city, avoiding a lot of the pitfalls from current generation games including C:S (like for example the traffic that never really works), whilst also removing the dry heaving even the most modern computer endure from playing modern games.

You are brilliant, you are loved. If someone could make a new version of this with updated graphics that'd be swell, but at the same time you still bring so much joy.

If there's one silver lining of covid19, it's that it has revitalized my interest in checking out old games while I'm escaping from quarantine depression. To my surprise, this game still holds up in 2020 (I played it long ago at release). I find myself going down the rabbit hole with mods (there are tons, and some of the big ones are still getting updates, i.e. NAM), and I see myself putting in a good chunk of hours letting my latest region develop naturally.

If you like city builders and never checked this out, this is a perfect game to play in these times.

The first three Sim City games will always have a special place in my heart haha.  I played these growing up a lot, mostly at stages of my life where I was friendless and sad.   SimCity was my distraction from my disappointing life.  I'd spend hours on it during summer and winter holiday when I was home alone everyday.   I come back to it every 5 years or so and immediately get hooked again.  It genuinely never gets boring for me and is probably my favorite game of all time.  If any of the devs happen to read this, thanks for making the dark times a little less bleak

Best SimCity bar none. Please DO NOT waste your money on SC13, this is the SC game to get.
