I played this game for years when I was little, and although I was too young to know how to play it well (I always went bankrupt), it was my favorite game.
Now I am old enough to play the right way and I love it even more than before. There is so much to do and the ability to create cities over a region and have them work together means I can create all kinds of scenarios. The city grows according to factors that you would have to consider when building in a real city. With mods, the game becomes even larger. I was reluctant to buy this game again because I remember it being too difficult for me but I am glad I did end up buying it. Seeing my cities grow and grow is so satisfying.

I purchased a physical copy back when SimCity 4 was first released and it remains my all time favorite city builders to this day.  I feel a lot more ownership  of the cities I cultivate in this game than I do in Cities XL or Skylines.  I'm not sure why this is exactly.  I imagine it's the engine under the hood and the way it responds to the city design.  It's probably a lot more simplistic than a modern city builder but for some reason I feel more connected to it.  This feeling is probably not why most people sit down with a sim game like this, but for me it's something like no other.  I'm still waiting for it's equal to be created.

I bought this game when it first came out on hard disc. I loved it then so I got this on steam, and started playing it again. I am having a great time playing this game again. It is worth the 20 bucks, and is a steal when it goes on sale. If you are bored and looking for a good casual game. This one is fun and challenging.

Heavily recommended, 

Sim city 4 is still competing nowadays  to be the 1st city builder (and in my opinion it is). You are here to build a city and cover all it needs, from garbage management, energy distribution, crime reduction, tourism... 

Basically Sim city 4 is a big map divided in squares. On each square you can build a city, and all those cities are working with each other. In other terms, build Factory city with its large industries to provide some jobs for the citizens of the neighboring city of SunnyTown. It's pretty funny to handle and requires good attention to keep your world balanced!

Graphically, the game is charming and the music is good. You can spend hours in it and it's rather addictive!

It's also possible to mod the game to improve the road system and add various buildings.

SimCity 4 is a fun simulation game as it give you a general sense of economics about taxes, supply, and demand. Here's some advice to note about playing this game: You want to run your city without over spending on irrelevant things you don't need, you don't want to over tax your citizens too much, because you'll lose your population, and if you tax the hell out businesses, you'll have no demand for businesses to establish in your city. Once you master supply and demand, and regulate taxes accordingly, you'll suceed to achieve what it takes to insure an auspicious society, and the posterity to come. The only flaws I have with this game, is it tends to crash evey half-hour or so, and there's no AutoSave to save all of your progress. Other than that, it's a fun simulation game that I would recommend.
Actually works in windows 10, unlike sim city 3000. it did crash 20 minutes in, but I forced it to only run on 1 cpu core and it hasnt crashed since

So, clearly by the hours, I love this game. However its gotta be said that this game non stop crashes over and over again. I've played the version on disk on this same exact system until I recently lost said copy, and now I'm stuck with a Steam version that repeatedly crashes the game, thus allowing me to make zero progress in game and pissing me off in the process. Good game, though I suggest you buy a hard copy if you can.

It's a great game. Previously I'd left a review that it randomly crashes on modern PCs, but then I learned why. The game was never designed to utilize more than one CPU core. You just have to set the SC4 process to only use a single core in order to get it working consistently. There are still some minor bugs, but they don't significantly impact gameplay.

I had to buy the Steam version because my CD version was no longer working with Windows 7, and I tried all the command line add ons, SC4Launcher, etc... Nothing worked but I read that this game still worked via Steam. So, I took a chance and bought and I'm sure glad I did! Nothing beats Sim City 4, it is still the best in the series and worlds better than the newer iterations of it. I am so sad that they ruined this game after Sim City 4. This is by far the only real Sim City and the last true work of art by those who created Sim City to begin with. It is so detailed, so complex, yet so easy to learn how to play and make amazing beautiful cities. I highly recommend this game to those looking for a classic that was the zenith of all city building games.

Playtime (with mods such as Network Addon Mod, and Colossal Addon Mod (NAM and CAM), is absolutely limiteless.  As a testament, I am still playing this game 10-11 years after it's release.  I don't feel compelled to move to the always-gotta-be-online new simcity.  I don't need snazzy 3d for a casual game when I get all the feedback and playability this way.  There are so many different ways to set things up.  Totally flat worlds, or mountainous terrain, or even a city by the bay.  HUGE cities in this game, with proper modding as described above can support over FOUR MILLION people on a single CITY.  It's very reasonable to expect to have 50-100 million people in a large region if you devote time into this. 
With the NAM mod mentioned above, you can build absolutely breathtaking realistic freeways just like you use on your commute to work or commuting to a shopping spree (heh).  With CAM mod, you can build huge skyscrapers and zone denser than ever before and really have a reason for all those highways.
Build Seawalls, Docks, Highways and Raised Road Viaduct/byways, Mass transportation suched as raised rail/monorail/subways/ground light rail and connecting all these together (mods may be required for some of these, but they are very worth it).  Build photo-realistic cities that you yourself wouldn't mind lodging up in.  
The mods alone make this game easily worth it's 20 bucks (US $) without a doubt, and if it's on sale, you'd have to be a fool not to pick it up.  Simcity 2013 is like a graphically enhanced sample, of what this game is.  If you enjoy Simcity 2013 but would like to grow bigger, higher, more populous cities, and have complete control of the road network of your dreams, this game is for you!  
You can spend hours just trying to mod this, there are thousands and thousands of different ones to choose from.  Start with NAM and CAM as stated and start looking around for what peaks your interest - with one caveat:  Watch those dependancies!  
Simtropolis, Sc4Devotion, and Simpeg are all great places to go look for mods, free signup is available, may be required and is outside of Steam or EA service's control.

This game is great. Best city simulator out there, hands down.
With the capabilities of modding, game customisation and easy to use interfaces and game functions, this game is a must need for anyone. Plus the price is definitely a bargin when on sale. I love this game, it's like owning a vintage car or something, because you can just keep working at it and it'll get better with new technology and the better you understand how the whole thing works.
10/10 would recommend

Despite being fourteen years old at the time of this review, this game is still entertaining. I think a huge part of it is how well it ages - it came out in 2003, but there are no musical or UI or humor clues that would tie it to the early 2000s. It's still one of the best city simulators out there, and if you're willing to add these to your launch options (or Google platform specifics): 
[code] -CPUCount:1 -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -intro:off -w -d:software -CPUPriority:high [/code]
you won't experience any issues with the game crashing, plus you get to play it in HD. The modding community is still alive and well, somehow. 

But most of all, SC4 just looks [i]good[/i]. The art style is cohesive, the colors and day-night cycles are on point (mostly), and despite almost everything being 2D pixel graphics it looks beautiful, especially if you know how to arrange your city. 

My one issue is that the game, like any single-player simulation, feels a little lonely sometimes. And if you get creative with Dropbox you can play a sort-of multiplayer, but there's no true MP built into the game. It's a good thing for the most part, because there's none of the always-online bullshit that comes with a lot of single-player games these days.

Basically, if you like any of the tycoon games, Civ, or model railroads, this game's for you. You can raise the difficulty if you want a more hardcore planning-focused experience, or mod in some demand multipliers if just want to build some nice interchanges.

Even with Steam Community fixes it's just outright BSODs all three of my PCs after 10 minutes or so. The game is almost unplayable on modern systems in it's current form.

Avoid and wait for some sort of remaster or a patch. Especially funny since freshly released SC3000 works flawlessly even on Deck.

The hours played doesn't reflect my experience with this game, as I used to play the disc version of this wonderful game religiously, and I still feel this to be one of the best city builders ever created. There was a time when Maxis had true freedom of their games (from when they were independent, and even the early days of being under EA), and during these times they released banger after banger - From the very first SimCity (and all other Sim games, I miss SimFarm and SimTower) up to SimCity 4 and Rush Hour, the studio and publisher were on fire and their games were of top-notch quality, and SimCity 4 is the result of them putting everything they learned up to this point into their city-builder series. There are very few builders out there that stand up to SimCity 4, it was just so enjoyable to make any kind of city you could dream and the addition of fun side-missions that let you actually drive vehicles around your city, and the ability to inspect your residential areas as well as name them if you please, was such a fun and intuitive addition to the franchise. Of course 4 is not without its flaws, but I have a hard time remembering what any of them are. EA may have destroyed their own franchise by making a mockery of the franchise with Sim City 2013, and City Skylines may currently be the premium city builder on the market while we're absolutely spoiled with solid choices like Urbek, Tropico, Anno, and Theotown among many others, but once upon a time Sim City 4 was king, and even today it has no problem showing that it is still relevant and as enjoyable now as it was back then.

TL;DR - worth every penny; especially when it’s on sale because it has a ton of content. 

I can spend hours, if not days, playing this game because there is just so much content included. This is the last good SimCity game made. All the new simulators are improvements and re-iterations of this one. I have an i7-8700k, 32 gb ram, and a 1080ti; it runs flawlessly and it doesn’t crash.

Should you buy it? It’s honestly worth every penny they charge, sale or no sale. That means, if it’s on sale... you’d be a fool to NOT purchase this game.

Oldie but goldie. If u wanna try a classics in city bulding, this is it. And it still runs fairly good, possibly need some work(cant remember), but for me, runs 1920x1200 on Win10 normally. Yeah-and cause the Rush Hour datadisk is included, u can drive cars around your city. Even do some Police or Fire Department missions. Funny stuff, not for a long time, just few minutes of not building. Ive played this for ages before I bought it on Steam too as I couldnt be bothered with CDs.

Sims city 4 is a amazing game but sadly its far to old now and will buckle on modern PCs. I've spent a long time trying to get it working but with no success. Once your city starts getting big the game will run at about 10fps- 15fps. Sadly destroying what is a wonderful game this is.

I've purchased this game four times since the time of its release and still play from time to time.   Ages very well thanks to a still-active and amazing modding community (sc4devotion and simtropolis come to mind) and still worth your money.

Honestly this is probably my favorite game of all time. If you played the new SimCity and often thought Huh, that seems like a dumb feature, you'll probably find that SimCity 4 alleviates most of these complaints. In my mind, there are three key differences between this game and the newest SimCity:

1. Non-agent based simulation: SC4 instead opts for a big-picture, numbers-based simulation. You'll find that this opens up many features that are highly preferrable to the agent modelling in the new SimCity, while still maintaining an acceptable level of simulation. This leads into the next difference.

2. City / Region size: With the less intensive processing involved in all the population dynamics, cities and regions are MUCH larger than the new game. There are no bare spots between cities; the whole world is yours to control. Want to make a complex highway system, servicing key neighborhoods and moving high volumes of traffic? Go right ahead. Highways are woefully prebuilt in the new game. Would you instead like to focus on public transit? The options are all there and in greater depth than the new SimCity. As a result of the larger size, the game feels much more open to creativity despite the lack of curved roads.

3. Modding: While the newest game just recently announced support for offline mods, you'll find that SC4 is far better off in the modding community. Many overhaul mods are available to give more transit options, better modelling, more buildings, and other assorted features. If you don't like something about this game, it's likely there's a mod to fix it.

Those three features are the main reasons why SimCity 4 is a far more rewarding experience than the new SimCity will ever be. Considering all this, and that SC4 can be had for $5 very easily, why would you choose the new one? 

 I'm just now picking up a copy on Steam because who knows when my old CD will stop working from damage or something.

If you've never played a city sim this is a great starting point. Simply a timeless classic. (for crashing issues go to the launch settings and put -CPUCount:1) as the game wasn't intended to be ran on multiple cores. 


The Soundtrack had no business going as hard as it does. Jerry Martin is a mad man. 10/10



sidenote:It says i only have a few hours on this game but i used to play it all the time on a non steam version.

We still have yet to see a true successor to the immense scale offered by SimCity 4. It has everything from the peaceful zen of settling a farming village in rolling hills, carving out a bustling coastal metroplolis, or the dirty fun of managing the man-made mountains of your region's garbage city.

The modding community has really made this game shine. At the minimum I recommend the Network Addon Mod (NAM) because of the improved traffic simulator - even if you choose to not increase the road capacities or include new highway and rail components. A full NAM install will add a good bit of content, so choose carefully when doing a custom install if you dont want your menus to get too bloated.

I have also managed to get the game running smoothly on my modern hardware (3770k + Radeon 7850). This game is known to erroneously detect moden Radeon HD 7xxx series GPUs as the old non-HD 7000 series. In the game's GraphicsRules.sgr file I commented-out the entire section on radeon slow path for partial depth buffer copies and added a new rule for the AMD Radeon HD 7000 Slow-Down Fix posted in the simtropolis forums - this resolved choppy scrolling issues.

I also use the following launch options set in steam:
 -intro:off -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -d:directx  -w -CPUcount:1

These options: disable intro, enable and set custom resolution, directX video output, windowed mode, use only one cpu.

SimCity 4

Who doesn't know this feeling of nostalgia - the old games were better, gaming had real meaning when we first bought our desktop PCs and started installing games like SimCity. I had SimCity 3000 when I was a teenager. It had been such a hype and all I remember now is sucking at the game. I used to just load a random city and attempt to play it, ending up being bankrupt within half an hour. The feelings, though, when I found SimCity 4 on Steam was that longing. I had to buy it again. Surely, over the years, I would have improved my game knowledge so far that I would finally manage to build a city and lead it. Turns out that countless hours in Endless Legend, Northgard, and The Settlers has prepared me for nothing, because I still suck. 

This game is for players
- in love with the old Maxis interface. The blue interface is an homage to Sims 1 and is pure nostalgia
- looking for a tutorial. Trust me, you will need it
- who love city builders. This game has got it all and the randomly generated disasters are the key ingredient in any SimCity game
- who love everything old-school: graphics, open-ended scenarios, time vacuums

Look at the screenshots and tell me you do not feel the nostalgia oozing out of every picture. If you do not know what I am talking about, then go to the next title in your queue.

Who the hell doesn’t love a good city simulator? Just be nostalgic for a minute and remember your old middle school days spent huddled up in your room watching aliens destroy your precious creation that you were so proud of yet disappointing to your parents because you created something that couldn’t be taped to the fridge.  You get to be the oh so glorious mayor of Asshat-ville. Asshat-ville can become a glorious mecca if you, asshat, make it so. Create zones for industrial, commercial and residential buildings. Build roads and power lines and those train thingies no one ever uses. Although this game is for the glorious PC Master Race, the graphics aren’t all that glorious and the music will have you banging your head on your desk after a few solid hours. This classic SimCity rehash will have you happy to relive the good ole days, but if you’re looking for something a little more fancy, head over to Tropico for a more in depth gameplay. But if you’re just a fan boy looking for a nostalgia trip, then my dear asshat, this game is for you. 7/10

Cities: Skylines has surpassed the former king, the Sim City series, however... SC4 is still a wonderful game, and well worth the price, especially on sale. I bought this as a choice back in 2013 instead of Sim City 2013 and I don't regret it for a bit. Totally fun and the UI and graphics have aged very well. Plus.... the music by Jerry Martin is classic!

I grew up with this game :) I read some of the negative reviews of this game to be objective.

Most of the not recommended recviews are about new hardware and Windows 10. I do not exactly know if the game works well with high end graphics and operating systems but i will assume it works after some work arounds.

Because if you can run this game and if you are a fan of city managing, this game is the most detailed game i know. Considering Cities XXL, Cities Skylines and City Worls. I am kind of a City building veteran :)

This game is pretty hard and complicated. You will most probably bankrupt you first 4-5 cities. you have to master the income and outcome balance and peoples happiness. Every desicion counts. Every single unit on the map is important. Reources management and city planing is crucial.

The game has advisors if there is something urgent to be adressed. And they might have good ideas too but do not go for all their ideas :) For example there are fires in the game and you have to dispatch units with your own hands. Sıo the advisor pops up and goes crazy in the middle of the screen. :)

The game has terraforming, water and air and noise pollution, land value and desirability to guide you. Neighbouring cities can exchange resources for income. Schools and hospitals are covering an area, so you have to adjust and optimize residential and commercial ares acoording to these two. Fire and police stations are also effective within their reach. But you can dispatch fire truck from a corner of the city to another.

Patient is the key to success in this game. Do not think you can just install the game and rise skylines. And i hope you can run the game on new operating systems and hardware.

When I bought this game half a year ago, I wasn't familiar at all with city-building games, but it was on sale and SimCity was of course a known franchise, so I bought it. When I started up the game for the 1st time I saw that I sometimes suffered from unexplainable graphical issues (colored lines ramdomly appearing on the screen). I went on. Then I noticed that the game sometimes chrashes (it happened to me about 10% of the times that I play it). I went on. Then I saw that I had been playing for hours. I went on.

This game is just so good that I dont't really mind these issues that I have from time to time. It is just so nice to start from scratch and create the city of your dreams (or the City of Death, for that matter). But that's just the start. After you're done with one city you will want to start up another neighboring city and connect both. and then a third city. And a fouth. There is just so much replayability because every city has different terrain. And while I can say that it's definetely not easy to make (and keep) your city healthy , it's not too complex to handle.

Since I bought this I have played more than 140 hours in 5 months time. For someone who also plays numerous other games, that's quite something. So yes, I'd definetely recommend this game if you have only a remote interest in city planning/management. It's already quite cheap normally, but when it's on sale there should definetely be no excuse for not buying this game if you think you will like it. It'll be worth the money.

[h1][b]★★★★★[/b][/h1]
Bought the game day 1 on a disc, and played it for YEARS. This steam version is fine, but I strongly recommend you check out the forums/guides to find the program that lets you play this game in widescreen 1080.

But beware, once you start it....you'll lose hours of your day. You'll forget that you have a life.

I love this game, but it CONSTANTLY crashes and you lose everything. I try to remember to save every few minutes but it's easy to forget. Just know, if you play it you may have a mental breakdown when you lose everything and its been over an hour since you last remembered to save :,(
I am very glad I did not buy the latest Sim City because this is so much better. If you want it to be updated a bit more just add some mods. Brilliant game and I recommend it to every one!

Welcome to bankrupt simulator! 
Where you need to tightly manage your funds while keeping your city functional and chaos free.
Basically a updated simcity 3, now with updated graphics, starting levels, more god powers, buyable objects. Now with drivable cars, planes, ships, trains and ships; all which can destroy buildings and your game.

8.5/10 - The LAST Simcity that was actually good.  [Looking at you EA]

I strongly recommend not fixing the stability issues if you have a job and/or family. This game is seriously addictive, so it helps to have the crashes as an automatic reminder you need to get back to the real world.

I can't believe this still works flawlessly on Windows 8.1 and 10.. 
I love this game.. and have been playing it on different hardware for the past 15 years. 
This is honestly the best version, while the Origin version is OK.. it's no where near as good as this version. If you like the Sim City platform, and haven't played this version, you should just pay the couple bucks and pick it up..

I love this game. It's nostalgic for me. The moderate complexity of city planning is spectacularly interesting (no, it really is!).

HOWEVER... This game is not stable and often crashes without warning. I cannot recommend this game with this issue. I understand the game is coming up on two decades, but until someone fixes this issue, I won't recommend it.
I have been playing SimCity 4 Rush Hour Deluxe Edition when I bought them on a CD which came in a Box on the day of release. And now more than 10+ years on this is for me still the Best Game Ever.

Game has known bugs.  Will crash and you'll loose all progress since the last save.  Apparently it has to do with the program not dealing well with multiple-cpu machines and GPUs that use hardware acceleration.  A serious bug as many machines are multiple-cpu and GPUs are made with their own CPU...that's the PU...Processing Unit.  These bugs should have been fixed a long time ago.

I have put 19 hours total into the game and should of quit before that. The game just randomly closes without saving. So if you are smart you will keep saving the game manually while playing so you do not lose any progress. I love the game but the random closing makes it miserable.

I originally got SimCity 4 as soon as it came out in 2003 after being a huge fan of SimCity 3000. SC4 became one of my most played games at the time. Years later I've come back to it on Steam and it still has a certain look to it that draws me back.

There are some great mods on Simtropolis and SC4 Devotion for just about anything you can imagine. Mods add a lot of content to the base game and especially as far as the roads, they make it better.

SimCity 4 led the way with city simulators and for many it's a classic.
One of the best City Management simulators ever made. I've played this game on and off since 2003 and it is one of the most engrossing games I've ever played. The hours disappear like seconds.

Pretty good game, massive stability issues on new computers! Having followed all the advice here and still having crashes (I think it could be due to modern GFX cards apparently not using DX7 legacy support for older games, from some research) I've found a way to stabilise the game - Run software mode in options ingame (disappointing I know) and I'm running it in windowed mode for now (-w in command line) and it seems to work ok so far.

Updated: Works fine in hardware mode, but only windowed.

While this game is a bit old and it doesn't support Steam Cloud, I still bought and played it because it's less heavy than City Skylines (which I also owned). I love how complex it's, yet still simple as the city develops itself and not micro-manage like SimCity Societies. As other reviews stated, it only utilizes 1 CPU core and its sim traffic behavior is horrible.

If you like SimCity and your PC is aged, you should try this one. If you have an Android phone, you can download TheoTown, which is the clone of this game but no enegy-like s*** system like other City Building games on phones.

Here is the command line if you want to run this game without being crashed and corrupted save: -CPUCount:1 -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -intro:off

In SimCity 4, you are the mayor of a city. You build streets and roads, zone zones for people to build houses, corporations to build offices and services and industries to build factories on and you build public services like police and healthcare and parks and publictransportation. The game is really really good in itself, but what really makes it so good that I'd call it my favorite game of all times is the wide range of mods the community made over the years, and I'd certainly call it the greatest citybuilder still.

I have alot of unrecorded time from the CD, probably about to the tune of 200 hrs total. This is a blast if you love sim city. if you dont/never heard of it before, buy this before you get teh expensive 3d renditions. its not perfect, but its pretty good. oh and no online DRM.

Yes, you are able to import your sims, and yes you can observe their daily routine as they work their way up from the inner-city slums into a high-level corporate position. It's crushingly addictive, especially with the fascinating new possibilities offered by having your cities trade with each other for resources. Might be the last good SimCity game.

I've been playing this game since it's inception when it was just called Simcity. It's one of the most fascinating simulator games I can think of. Great for all ages and levels of gaming experience as it can be as simple or as complex as you like it depending on the many mods and plugins that are available for the game. Of course there or those that are going to tout City Skylines or the latest Simcity game which are great in their own right but definitely lacking in many ways when compared to SimCity 4 Deluxe edition with the updated NAM 43 mod.

I've had this game on disk ever since 2004 and I still enjoy this game today. The modding community really has expanded upon what Maxis sent out originally and it has managed to retain the excitement this game has. Forget Sim City (2013), Sim City 4 is the one you want!

Still one of the greatest city management games ever made. I've not even played that much of it and I can easily tell how amazing the game is. Still has a massive online modding community and an active fanbase. Great game, way better than SimCity 2013.

Still the best city simulator on the planet.

It isn't just the (stroooooong) nostalgia, it is a very solid game.

Cities Skylines comes close, but this one just has a lovable flair to it, plus I prefer the grid-based building over the overly free one in CS.

Oh and fuck EA sideways for holding this series hostage and butchering Maxis.

Best city building game of all time. Although Cities Skylines has better road construction and water simulation, Simcity 4 has the better simulation regarding zone usage and land values. It also has a better difficulty curve, as you are constantly challenged regardless of your city size by a multitude of interesting problems (e.g. low land values in new cities, lack of education/tax base when transitioning to high tech industry or insufficient low wealth workers in rich suburbs) while cities in Cities Skylines always devolve into solving traffic issues as the main gameplay loop.

The game was developed in 2003 and visually still looks fantastic. Buildings are consistently scaled and themed when compared to the inconsistent buildings of Cities Skylines. The game can be temperamental on modern systems however. It's a good idea to look at various guides to configure the game prior to running it and remembering to save often.

Benchmark for city building games that most havent come close to in comparison, it has its own graphics style that doesnt hurt the eyes even today. a real shame EA bought maxis and ruined sim city 5 and the possibility of better sim cities moving forward.

It's an old game - you definitely have to mod it to get the best experience. That being said, still the best city sim for those who are looking for a challenging, pseudo-realistic experience - in other words, for those looking for a city simulator, and not a city builder like Skylines.
Fun game. But becomes unplayable with newer computers. It crashes without warning. This would only be a slight annoyance if the game had autosave. But sadly that's not the case. It's a real shame.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#268 out of 612)... it's time for SimCity 4 Deluxe.

I'm fairly certain SimCity was the first video game I ever played. Back in gradeschool, it was one of the few acceptable titles for the compute lab due to its perceived educational value. I'm not sure what, exactly, we were meant to learn from it, but I have fond memories of fiddling around with power lines and hospitals and frustrating natural disasters all the same.

I'm not terribly keen on the simulation or city-building genres, so I can't speak much for the complexity of SimCity 4, or how well it lives up to or fails to live up to its predecessors, but I can say that it seems to play exactly as I remember, and is just as fun as I remember. One thing to note, however, is that it's very much an older PC game and it shows its age, most notably with the absence of tooltips. Honestly, going back to player older strategy games is kind of infuriating these days, due to the typical lack of tooltips. Conventional game design at the time seems to have revolved around abstract icons, which just... are never going to communicate a concept as clearly as proper text. So if you haven't played SimCity in a while, you're likely going to have to bludgeon your way through a fairly steep learning curve as you slowly decipher and memorize the game's arcane symbology.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

The game is 21 years old, but, it is still one of the best releases for simcity as I am sorry to say but the 2013 Simcity, which I do own, does not hold a candle to Simcity 4 Deluxe. Also, with all the mods and other downloads it has made the game still fun 2 decades later.

When I think of SimCity, I think back to the time with Benjamin showing me the first part of SimCity. I just loved SimCity and took turns playing with Benjamin on a city that grew and grew. Unfortunately we both had problems with unemployment in the city and so Benjamin decided to build a neighborhood with four dozen police stations. To give the citizens all a job. So anyone who became unemployed in our city was immediately given a police badge and put in a patrol car. That was how Benjamin had solved unemployment.

SimCity 4 was the last great SimCity. It was a real step up from its predecessors because the city had a main map that was divided into smaller distinct quarters. This is how districts, suburbs and villages came into being, all of which were interconnected. So it was the first part of SimCity, connected to a city complex with many districts.

Innovations in this part are the automatic building functions, with which one no longer has to worry about sewers and power lines. The mayor´s advisors are also beautifully presented and give advice. Of course, the graphics have also been polished.

If you want, you can let your own Sim citizen move into a house and watch him as he lives in the city. It´s a bit like a built-in function to make SimCity 4 to the game The Sims - light

Ultimately, SimCity 4 is the best SimCity ever made and a true classic.
Before Cities: Skylines was released, this was the best city-building and managing game in my opinion. The requirements are rather low so I enjoyed playing this game on my laptop.

now this game cost the same as Cyberpunk 2077 in my region. 
same happened to all EA games, prices are ridiculous. 
I do not recommend any of EA games till they maintain such predatory attitude towards their consumer base. ~20 years old game does not cost like AAA title from 2020.

10/10

Build your own city and see how far you can go, or you can build your city and destroy it!! Cool thing about this game is you can drive/fly helicoptors and cars in your own city. You can also create your very own sim!

SimCity 4 is a true masterpiece of city-building gaming that has stood the test of time. Its legacy is evident in the still-active modding community, even two decades after its launch, which speaks to the depth and richness of the game's history. The complexity of the simulation in SimCity 4 surpasses modern titles like Cities: Skylines and creates a fun and engaging challenge for players with each city they build that can last late into the game.
Playing SimCity 4 since Christmas 2003, I am still discovering new things about the game, like the fact that you can use the query tool on the wildlife and that they also run away from helicopters. The graphics may be dated now, but they haven't aged poorly due to the game's art style, which does a lot of heavy lifting. The richness of small details in SimCity 4 gives the game a warm and soulful feel that can be experienced in every play session.

The only downside to playing SimCity 4 is the realization of how EA could have gone so wrong with subsequent iterations of SimCity, when there was already a winning formula in front of them. Also, this isn't to say that Cities: Skylines is a bad game by comparison, as they are just two different types of games. While Cities: Skylines is a beautiful city diorama with a challenging traffic system, SimCity 4 is a complex urban simulator that requires strategic planning and balancing to get skyscrapers to develop.

The game's soundtrack is one of the best in gaming, with a range of tracks from the contemplative yet energetic No Gridlock, the absolute bangin sax action in Rush Hour, to the beautiful symphonies of Wheels of Progress and Morning Commute. As the pinnacle of city builders, SC4 has inspired a new generation of city planners/civil engineers and sparked a love of city design in me at the age of 7 that has lasted to this day. It is a must-play for any fan of city-builders.

With that being said, it is indeed possible to make this game somewhat stable on modern machines but you are going to HAVE TO install some mods (I-HT fix, 4GB patch and SC4Fix.dll) as well as set some startup parameters on the .exe

Game was built to run on a single-core CPU, and I'm running Sim City 4 on a Ryzen 2700.  To prevent crashes, set your game to only use a single core.  Had the game running for over 40 hours with no issues.  Even more fun than I remember micromanaging the education, health, and transit for my citizens.  At $19.99, this game is definitely worth it.

I have been playing this game off and on since it came out. I started back with SimCity 2000 Unlimited. SC4 through Steam doesn't run too well on my iMac. Works fine on my Windows 7. Great game though, have spent WAY too much time with this game over the years. I only play this and Civ5.

Ah sim city 4... the first game i played as a kid, even though back then every city i built went bankrupt.. but recently i brought it in steam because my disk copys have gone missing.. Now this game is fairly old, and doesnt like modern hardware so you will be finding yourself messing around with your settings to have a half decent frame rate, though this isnt much of an issue as theres ways to fix it.. Sim city 4 also has plenty of content includeing more then 15 map tiles to build a cities, we all know a game gave us a dismal amount. (Sim city 2013) Sim city 4 still has a fairly active modding community, with a 'f**k ton' of mods which has made the game constantly refreshing and intresting.. 

With that, sim city 4 is 14 years old and has its postive points and negitive points.. but is it worth it? Yes but also no. With the game 'not running at a friendly frame rate' due to modern hardware (includeing crashes) it may become quickly boring.. but dont let that over shadow how good this game is.. buy this at risk of knowing it may not work because of modern hardware.. but its worth it if you want a game that, you can sit down for hours on end buidling the city of your dreams

The first SimCity to really draw me in, SimCity 4 has more depth and complexity than any city building game before it, and even some made today!

This is one of the times I really lament the state of the Steam review system. It is difficult to give this game the rating it deserves based on a thumbs up and thumbs down alone. Skip the next two paragraphs for the TL;DR version.

The SimCity series used to be synonymous to the city simulator genre, kind of like Xerox and Kleenex are synonymous to photocopying and tissue paper respectively. This is an old game, so there will bound to be some minor issues running on relatively modern hardware, and back then, it was, at worst, tolerable, because nothing else came close. I had been playing this game even before Steam existed.

Then came the lackluster SimCity (2013) after years of waiting for its successor, and then a few years later, came the promising Cities: Skylines by a different company. This game was really good back then and aged gracefully way beyond any reasonable expectation largely thanks to its modding community, but ever since, I started playing Cities: Skylines two(?) years ago, I just never went back to SimCity 4.

In conclusion, any person new to the city simulator genre should probably skip SimCity 4 and go with Cities: Skylines instead. This game is really showing its age, modding it is a bit more involved, and the minor issues are still there. For anyone who is already into the genre but wants to have a more vintage experience or simply wants to go down memory lane, you cannot go wrong with this game. Given all that I have said, it is with an incredibly heavy heart that I no longer recommend this game for most.

This game is incredible. The Graphics are very detailed and realistic. You can build more than one city on the same map. Not to mention importing your own Sims from The Sims into the game. Your city just doesn't sleep like that of SimCity 3000. You see your people walking about and running their daily lives, like walking their dogs, Driving to the supermarket, Driving their kids to school even going to church!
The biggest improvement that I saw in SimCity 4 were the disasters. In SimCity 3000 you had like what? 4? In SimCity 4 you get over eight disasters. The best part is that you can control and decide where your Tornado goes. You also get Volcanoes that erupt, Erathquakes that bury houses and split open the earth, Meteor showers that leave everlasting craters and
Lightning Bolts, Fires, Riots, Floods, Mudslides, Bank Robberies and even Car chases. You get to choose you terrian styles. You can ahve an African style with Rhino's and Giraffes. Sometimes they can even stampede into your city.
The other great thing about SimCity 4 is the terrian tools. You can sculpt gorgeous, Lagoons, Cliffs, Craters, Valleys and even place galiciers. Then you have the time settings. A 1900's Chicago style, A 1950'S New York Style, And a 2000s Houston Style. Then there is the animations of the construction of buildings. When you build your buildings they just don't appear out of no where tou actually see your sims get into their work trucks and start to construct the building. And if the building is of no use anmore it decays and doesn't turn into a huge big purple borded up mess. Then if you want to destroy or knock down a building it just doesn't disappear, you can actually impload or expload your buildings from any side you wish. There are no old buildings from SimCity 3000, The're totally new realistic looking buildings in SimCity 4.
To me all this extra stuff makes this game totally anew. You won't get board if you like Simulation games.
fun game even in 2021. can run on basically anything nowadays.  as long as good graphics isn't what your looking for then it is overall a great experience and i 100% recommend picking it up,

works in win10, with 1920x1080 , i7 ROG GTX1060 gaming laptop bought in early 2017 and with the latest windows update with antivirus running. No compatibily issues, no crashes thus far. No strange Performance issues.

[i](Scroll down my review to see technical tips to get the game running smoothly on Windows 10)[/i]

[h1]Gameplay Review[/h1]
Just as I remember it! Not everything has aged well but it's still quite fun. It still feels more challenging and deep in many areas than Cities: Skylines. The fact that there are three density levels rather than two and that lower densities can develop on high density zones if demand doesn't exist yet makes for more variation, and the fact that zoning costs money means that you aren't incentivized to only zone high densities because higher density zones cost more money. In C:SL I always ended up with unrealistic cities full of nothing but skyscrapers because there was no reason to zone low density once higher density was unlocked.

The vehicle missions are a nice touch. There's something oddly fun about driving around the streets of your own city even if it's just from an overhead perspective.

I also love the graphics. The pseudo 3D style allows much more visible detail than in C:SL.

And the music. Easily one of the best video game soundtracks in existence.

Only annoyances I have are fiddly road, rail, etc. construction, and unrealistically steep and jagged roads unless you spend time leveling them by placing adjacent single road tiles. 

Transport and traffic management is also less deep than C:SL.

[h1]Rating[/h1]
8/10

[h1]Technical Tips[/h1]
If you're having trouble with crashes: close the game, and copy this line (including the dash): 
[i]-CPUCount:1[/i]
Then right click on the game in your library, click properties and in the window that pops up paste it into the box under where it says launch options. Since doing this I've yet to experience a single crash.

If you want to run it at 1920x1080 resolution then add this to that box as well:
[i]-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32[/i]
You can probably do this with any resolution you want, just replace [i]1920x1080[/i] with the resolution you wish to run it at.

If you own a disc copy that won't work on Windows 10, It's very possible that the Steam version will still work for you (apparently Win10 can have trouble with older discs).

If you have problems with low FPS, try setting shadows to low in the in-game settings. Shadows seem to be a performance hog in this game even though they don't add much visually.

Edit: Also be sure to never press the button to save and quit (either to region or desktop) as this can cause the game to freeze and your save to be corrupted. Always save your city, then exit without saving.

SimCity series are oldest city-building games, with the very first one released in 1989. The person who stands behind the idea is Will Right, a famous game designer who is also known for creating Sims series and Spore. By 2020s he left big industry for development of mobile projects but back in 2000s his name was often seen in videogame magazines. And since this man is one of most talented game developers of all time, all his games projects became either true hits in their genre or at least caused large discussions and attention. SimCity falls into first category. Unfortunately, by the time of writing this review the series are dead. And with SimCity reboot released in 2013 falling to achieve success this very game, SimCity 4, holds the title of the latest good SimCity game. I played it even back in 2000s and I must say that it's a true masterpiece. However, for newcomers it might look old, especially when there are such modern games like Cities Skylines exist. But for me this game means a lot and I personally think it's still fun to play.

#1: take Sim City 4, and add curved roads
#2: graciously accept your GOTY award

Seriously, that is all. Take a 12 year old game and add some curves. Why does everyone screw this up?  Man, I wish I had programming skills.

Growing up, I knew that I was destined to hold a position of power. As I was given the title of “mayor” I felt a great rumbling from deep within me. 

I dawned my 1950’s top hat and cane, using my servant to press the clicky clacky tippy typie on my mahogany desk. With a glass of scotch in one hand, and the bottled tears of a child in another, I raised land and oceans. I placed the poor far away from the city, giving them one school, which served as a labor camp for orphans who gave me sass. I chuckled, giddily, as each sip of alcoholic delight left me feeling more empowered. 

I raised taxes so high, even the rich began to cry. But I needed more. My mayoral hall and housing were surrounded by police who were paid handsomely, their salaries equivalent to the surgeons who worked at the privately constructed hospitals that were right next to my luscious abode. 

I chortled with glee as my advisors and secret police made sure everything fell in line. For the neighborhoods that tried to rise up against me, my board of shadowy figures and mother-in-law sacrificed several domesticated and localized goats to summon a space rock that decimated their homes and willingness to challenge me. 

I stood from my sitting device and performed a bodacious jig as I saw my profits double, my harvested uranium and potassium mines fueling my secret economy. My meals became more lavish, my attire woven from the flesh of the most endangered animals. 

Power is only a small descriptor. Godhood is a more accurate classification.

It is not, and probably won't be outdated, just like Mario Bros, Tetris, or Pac-Man.. Sim City is the very first initial applicaton of city building (both in terms of management mechanics and sandbox mode.), and Sim City 4 is the absolute peak of series. While even vanillia game is a very good experience, various mods which are still being created (After +10 years the game is released.)(Which on it's own is a proof of how well mechanics are made.) regularly, provides you anything you could ever wish for.

I almost can't find any possible upgrade ideas for Sim City 4 (While some mods are included.), except some graphical fidelity - and the fact that these 10 year old graphics are exceptionally good for its time (You can apply some recent HD texture packs, too!), it won't be bothering you at all. Actually, in my opinion, 2,5D graphics are pretty optimal for such game. There are some pretty obvious cases like Stronghold Crusader & Stronghold II / StarCraft:BW & StarCraft 2, where 2,5D to 3D transition actually killed the uniqueness of gameplay. Even in the case of SC, when I exclude the mechanical differences of SC5 with SC4, gameplay is also kind of degraded. Simcity 4 is an outstanding game. I have grown up all my life with Simcity, and by far, this is the best game in the series. Compared to Simcity 3000, this game is a huge step up. 
Clearly aimed at experienced, PC gaming, simulator loving gamers, Simcity can satisfy all of the requirements that are needed to make a great city simulator, and does so much more to interest the player. 

The game is orientated around grittier city building, or large gleaming metropolises, which, to a long term player, is a great change from the previous installments - where the design choices and city genres seemed somewhat limited. 

With so many buildings to choose from, you may expect a steep difficulty curve, which indeed is apparent as you play the game. However, there is a certain satisfaction as your first high-rises begin to develop! 

In my opinion, an important factor in gaming, is the music, as it creates most of the atmosphere. Simcity 4 does impress; it impresses a lot. The ambient music in the regional view, combined with the gritty, hard jazz in the mayor view, combine to create an incredible atmosphere, incomparable to previous entries in the series, despite the impressive jazz tracks in Simcity 3000. My favorite track in the game, known as ‘Zone System’ is an example of the perfection of ambient, gritty, depressing, but most of all, interesting, city-sounding music. It sets the atmosphere of the game perfectly, and captures the player’s and the sim’s emotions as you expand your corrupt city into a gleaming paradise. 

Another selling point of the game is the implementation of features from The Sims. While these features are not necessary, they add a certain charm to the game. They allow the player to drive cars, fly planes, ride boats, control trains, or even drive a tank whilst destroying buildings with missiles. 

An important part of gaming is certainly the graphics and aesthetics, and Simcity 4 does not disappoint. The graphics, while pixelated once zoomed in, are amazing. Loads of buildings have interesting features, even with customized gardens or small details such as cars. The view of the game is isometric, and the player can rotate the view by 90 degrees, in order to see parts of the map that may be hidden. This is an important feature, especially when working around hills. What I would have liked though is a feature where the player could view the map from birds-eye-view, but I can understand there may have been hardware limitations back in 2003 that may have made this impossible. 

Simcity 4 gives the player access to many natural disasters and scenarios. Meteorites, tornadoes and earthquakes can be summoned by the player at any time, along with many other disasters. An example of an interesting scenario is if a nuclear power plant explodes, causing a lot of radiation to be expelled into the city. This can be interesting if the player wants a challenge, or just fun to destroy a huge metropolis! 

Simcity 4 does have a few problems however, though not major if you know how to overcome them. The most prominent problem is the commute time being too difficult to manage. 

Another issue is the constant industrial demand, where the player would need to build huge cities dedicated only towards industrial. This can be rather boring, as industrial development is limited, but can be improved by adding a mod that quarters the industrial demand. 

Overall, an awesome game.

This game is a classic. Easily one of the most relaxing games I've ever played, building a city, making your land, basically everything you wanna do with making your own world is here.

+++++++++++++++ Review +++++++++++++++

This is THE greatest city builder of all time. Today's reiterations like Cities: Skylines can't touch the beauty and intricacy of this game. Its 2.5 Dimension style graphics style will probably never be seen again, and it's something you'll have to experience to appreciate. 

Note that there's a huge difference between 'SC4' and a 'heavily modded SC4' - the community is still very much so alive on Simtropolis and SC4 Devotion, making great free addons to this game with real world buildings, restaurants, road addons, landmarks, trees and everything else you can imagine. Hardcore players of SC4 are typically sandbox builders and don't care for the actual game aspect - you can create some pretty mind blowing scenery with this game and the right mods. With that being said, it's a game with an insane amount of replay value...not just beacuse it has no end, but it's a relaxing scenery builder that will give you a great deal of therapy through the years.

+++++++++++++++ About the Steam Version of Sim City 4 +++++++++++++++

If you're like me and have been playing SC4 from the original disc, it's worth re-purchasing it through a Steam sale to get this patched version, because SC4 does not work well from the get-go. You will need to do a little work to get the game to run on Windows 10, but this will simply take a couple minutes...here's what you need to know:

+++++++++++++++ Getting Sim City 4 To Run On Modern Day PCs +++++++++++++++

The version of Sim City 4 DX that you get from Steam is 1.1.641.0, which means that the old EP1 Update (UPDATE_SKU1_TO_P1.EXE) and SC4Update4BAT (SC4Update4BAT.EXE) are already included, and you won't have to hunt them down on the internet. These patches were necessary if you had the old CD version of the game; otherwise, buildings would not light up during the night time cycle.

Once you install the game, you'll have to edit its Steam launch options, which is pretty quick and easy:

- In Steam, click LIBRARY in the main menu.
- Next, right click SimCity 4 Deluxe in the right-side menu, and choose Properties
- Right within the GENERAL tab is a button called SET LAUNCH OPTIONS... - click it.
- In the field provided on this final pop-up, paste in the following variable string:

-w -intro:off -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1200x32 -CPUCount:1 -CPUPriority:high

(These variables are: -w (wide screen), -intro:off (skips past the annoying intro that runs every time the game opens, -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1200x32 (this tells the game to run at your monitor's resolution, change it if you have to), -CPUCount:1 -CPUPriority:high (this is the most important part...Sim City 4 cannot run on more than 1 core, so you have to force the program to run on only one. Otherwise, the game won't run).

+++++++++++++++ Getting Mods for Sim City 4 +++++++++++++++

Mods make this game what it is - you won't believe how different it will look once you've added some custom content. The two best sites on the internet for mods are Simtropolis and SC4Devotion. Even after all these years, the communities for SC4 are thriving on these sites. They'll also have plenty of resources that tell you exactly how to unpack and install mods - it's pretty easy.

The essential mods you'll really want (or have?) to get are:

- NAM (Network Addon Mod): adds a ton of new realistic roads, interchanges, ramps, etc.
- SC4 DAT Packer: makes the game more stable by centralizing your mods into one big file
- Cheats By Buggi: allows you to input a bunch of different cheats that will make your life easier if you're looking to play this game in sandbox mode

+++++++++++++++ Standalone Mods for Sim City 4 +++++++++++++++

There are two notable standalone mods for Sim City 4. They install as separate programs:

- SC4 Terraformer: this program is really old and a little clunky, but it will all you to hand sculpt a Sim City 4 map by drawing mountains, valleys, hills, etc with your mouse across any or all regions - even over borders, which is impossible to do in-game. The regions can then be imported into your game.

- SC4 Mapper: This program lets you modify the size of the regions in a current Sim City 4 map. If you wanted regions to be bigger or smaller, or if you wished that the borders of a certain region were located somewhere else (like, one region on your map that is not 90% water and 10% land), you can edit them with this program.
