Region play allows you to make some truly massive megalopolises. Mods like the NAM fundamentally change the game in positive ways and the amount of custom buildings, terrain and flora on community sites is mind-numbingly large.

The only gripe I have about this game is the performance. Being an older DX app, it's limited to single core and 4GB of RAM. Crashes and performance issues are abound on modern hardware, and it doesn't seem like EA would ever willingly release the source code of the game. Still a solid 10.

The game shows it's age (more so when coming to compatibility/performance) on new machines but this game is so freaking fun to mess around in. It can be difficult to master but when you get it right it's like you've successfully dunked a biscuit in tea and it didn't flop and sink into the tea.

That's how good you'll feel when you get a great town going 

Also in regards to compatibility and getting the best performance this launcher helps [b]so[/b] much and it's easy.
http://community.simtropolis.com/files/file/28544-sc4-launcher/ 

Here is a great guide for it as well
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=279736936

A classic. Truly a polished game, once the expansion was added. Came out in 2003, but is still the one to beat. I've played Cities Skyline and while a decent game itself I would not compare to Sim City 4. I have played Sim City 4 since 2003, owned it since then on disc and recently purchased on steam; thousands of hours in game honestly. The soundtrack is one of the best of any game.

Love this game, I originally brought this on release back in the day on disc back in 2003 and have been playing it ever since.
You will need NAM and other user created content to expand the game as the base game is lacking in transport options such as highway types.
I would recommend that if you own this already on cd and are running win 10 that you upgrade to a digital copy.

Pretty much the best citybuilder and one of my most played games of all time. I own a physical copy of it, and I recently picked up this Steam copy... definitely one of my favorite games ever.

You need to mod the game in order to make it playable, and the game tends to crash, lock up, and run slowly. There's no autosave and you'll probably lose a lot of hours of gameplay. Loading a custom region is cumbersome, installing mods is archaic, and the whole thing is just clunky. Using some mods will require literal hours of patience... ask me about custom highways or building a mass transit network. Piece by piece, slowly, surely, but satisfyingly.

Beneath all the clunk is a diamond, the absolute best city builder of all time. Every game that comes out can't seem to match a well-modded Simcity 4. You can install a massive amount of options for mass transit and building variety. It's intoxicating, if you're into it.

If you just want to build a pretty city, you're going to need to work slowly and learn how to do it. This game honestly isn't friendly or accessible for new people... But if you work at it, and you enjoy the genre, you're going to love it.

I put a ton of time into this game on the Steam Deck. It works perfectly there and with a control scheme that suits me, some mods (NAM, fixes, custom regions, some custom buildings), and the launch options to ensure it is full screen, it is the best city builder I have ever played. Just wonderful!

I highly recommend for anyone looking for a city builder on the Deck. 

The original review still stands, for me at least. With a ryzen 7 1700 and a 1080ti the game does not run well .

--------- Original Review ----------

I wish there was a way to get this game to run well on my modern machine, but i just cannot figure it out. I have pretty much maxed out my patience trying, from launch options, to changing the graphicsrules and card files, to launchers. I just cannot recommend the game even though it looks pretty awesome, it runs very poorly (sub 30fps) on my modern machine.
The best Simcity game that exists and I've put at least 200 hours into every single one. Beware though: Steep learning curve and you will lose track of time once you get into it.

if you're looking for a classic city builder, then look no further. this game is still better than simcity 2013, and would play it a lot more if cities skylines wasn't a thing. i have clocked over a thousand hours in this game over the years, not knowing it was on steam.

I love the way I can make all sorts of different cities and join them up. Lots of fun figuring out the commerce, pollution, water and trash issues. A great way to while away a LOT of hours.  I played Simcity before there was Steam.
The game is worth it, it has a lot of replay value, but make sure you save your game often. The app closes randomly, but apart from that, it's a very addictive game.

This game was a huge nostalgia rush for me! it brought back some of the good old days of sim city and now that I am older and understand how to not go bankrupt, I have managed to build some pretty sweet mega cities! the only downside i have ever had with this game (with the CD as well so don't expect a patch) is the game WILL 100% GUARANTEED crash on you at random and sometimes at the worst moments! the worst part about the crashes is they always seem to happen when your having fun and are not thinking about saving...asside from that I would highly recommend this nostalgic city builder!

A timeless classic of city building. With unmatched tools, situations and problems. It will grab you by your neck and not let you leave your Pc for hours. Rejoice as your town grows into a city, as you place those majestic monuments and as your citizens rally to support you all round. The art style has not dated, even though special commands needed to play in glorious 1080p.

After all these years I'm amazed how this game still incorporates almost every aspect that other games offer through much more convoluted interfaces and systems.
This plays just the same but feels much much smoother after all these years. 
And I'm playing only vanilla nowadays, with mods it can get even bigger.
Over time I also found more and more interesting the Sims part to get a more df-like kind of feedback for my cities.

A must get, tho it needs a little bit of fiddling (or a conveninent external launcher).

The Best game Of all time, With Mods............. maybe about 2 GB worth....... annnnnnd you can put up with the crashes.........   but still the best.  How i can still be Playing this game 20 years on shows how grate this game is, If you just want to build large citys made up of smaller city, this is t he game for you, it seems to strike a balance of simple game-play that is additive enough and you don't have to constantly look at menus and graphs for pointless busy work and pointless micromanaging, you simple just play and have fun and let your  creativeness fly, 
If only there was a new City building game that is SC4 with updated graphics, i used to think the every new city builder had to be 3d, but i was wrong, 2.5D is the only way, with pre-baked  assets to get the most detail in

11 years old and still an amazing game, especially with the modability. Still waiting on that next great city builer sim, though...Cities: Skylines came close, but it's just not what I'm looking for. How many more years will it be before someone steps up and makes a better city sim than this? It's not looking very likely at this point. 

One thing I like about this game is the realism. You zone land, it starts constructing, then you have plausible buildings start to pop up. Something I can't stand about modern city simulators is this cheesy, colourful, unrealistic look it has. I want my cities to actually look like they do in the real world...Not a fucking 3D cartoon city where Jimmy goddamned Neutron lives.

Before deciding to buy this game first decide wheter or not you like budgeting and micro managing. This isn't a city builder like Tropico but is a slightly more realistic and economically focused experience. I like it, although if you looking for something with a bit more imagination and fun then perhaps try Tropico 5.  SimCity 4 has aged well and I can most definatly recommend it to anyone looking for a hit of nostalgia or fans of city builder simulators.

After all these years, and all the city builder sims that have came after it, SC4 is STILL the gold standard for city building sims everywhere. Even with as good of a game as City: Skyline is, and it does some things way right, and has things I wish SC4 had, (like districting, and road building) is still doesn't feel as deep or as compelling as SimCity4 does. I fell that's it's way too easy to hit a ceiling in City: Skyline. After a while, I get a sense that I've done all I can do and have nowhere do go but start a new city, and start all over again. Meanwhile, in SC4 there are always new things to tackle and new problems to fix. I spend most of my time playing SC4 staring blankly at my screen, pondering my next move like a chess master. That's what I love the most about this game.

It makes you think.

The only drawbacks about this game is the frequent crashing. This was an issue that was present with original disk I had of this game way back in the day, but it now seems exacerbated on the Steam version. It will crash about ten or so minutes into the game about 40% of the time. This is beyond annoying and breaks any concentration you might have if you're constantly worried about saving. Also, I found that certain mods run a lot less seamlessly with the Steam version of the game as well. Perhaps I need to look a little more into this, but a lot of the highway mods I loved using on the disk version of the game, really tug the game down. I excepted the Steam version of the game to run much better which was why I bought it instead of buying a used diskset like I've done before in the past. I dunno whether to blame Steam or EA for the game's performance, but I assume it turn a lot of younger player away from this game when the game has real troubles running for more than a half an hour. Which is a shame as it's still the best city sim of all time.

A classic city building game, which has a fun learning curve. Can be hard to get into the game and learn all the diffrent features at first, but once you play it for about 10+ hours you should be able to enjoy the game and even get addicted to it! The last great city builder game EA has come out with, but a great one at that.

Simcity 4 requires a LOT of tweaking to run on a modern system. It will NOT run properly on systems with multi-core processors and it will not run correctly at 1920x1080 out of the box. Once you edit some configuration files, the game runs but you're still going to run into issues. 

If you're willing to pop the hood and get your hands dirty, this is the last true SimCity title. EA owned Maxis by this point, but the company had SimCity 4 already in development beforehand and was able to release the title with little interference from their new abusive parent company. 

Electronic Arts then proceeded to completely absorb and destroy Maxis, leaving SimCity 4 as its epitath. 

RIP Maxis.

Another amazing game here on planet Earth. This piece of jewel entertains me since 2004, so it has been 10 years. Ten WHOLE years ! I still remember my begginings with this one. It was tough, I was just 13 back then. But I still tried to build my cities, to rise my skyscrapers, to be the best. I failed many, many times...

Until... until I rised up as well. I mean - psychically. I am now 23 years old and my brain works a lot better than 10 years ago. I had improvement my strategic thinking, so my cities can grow even more. 

This game is a living legend. This game will never be old. This game will be here forever, like Super Mario, Tetris, Diablo 2 or Command & Conquer. This game has it's own life already, supported by moders and dozens of mods. Sim City 4 - more than just a game. It is a life style !

The Sim City 4 is one of the best in the series, not is it just really fun to play, it is still one of the best City Simulator Strategi after 10 years, it beats the new Sim City (2013) by far! I used to have a cd version of this, but i lost it after 10 years so i picked it up on 2,5 Euro on the sale, dam that price. You want se a good game for this price and to be this high age to. The only thing i dont like about the steam version is that i have no way knowing how to change the languages from English to Norwegian, i prefer this type of games in my own native language and i think the steam verion dont follow with Norwegian, but comes with dannish and swedish and some another europe language if you buy from europe.
I paid $20 for this game, but I have windows10.  This game REQUIRES DirectDraw...Directx9-12 dont support DirectDraw, so, as you can guess....It doesnt work.  I need to get a refund.

At $20, it's hard to recommend a game from 2003, which is basically ancientware at this stage. However, if you're patient and don't mind consulting Simtropolis a ton, this game still offers plenty of fun and value. 

Positives:
+The soundtrack is spot-on 
+Planning and building and watching cities grow is addictive
+Endless customizability
+Huge regions (even if you can't play everything at once due to hardware restrictions) makes it feel more real
+Lots of ways to play - from rural / farming, small-medium-huge cities, landscaping and decorating, modding and modeling, etc.
+Supportive and active community on Simtropolis

Minuses: 
-Built-in mechanics can be annoying, but modded away
-Doesn't run all that quick even on modern hardware (I can only speak for laptops)
-Getting and installing and organizing all the files and dependencies for mods is a hassle
-Learning NAM (the traffic mod) is a big pain, with tons of menus and clogged choices and such
-To fill up even a small region could take ages

All in all, I'd buy it on sale IF you already know and love it. For people who've never played this kind of game before, $20 is steep for this old of a game, period. City builders seem to be in a bit of a renaissance over the last few years (in no small part due to Sim City's groundbreaking work decades earlier!), and I'm excited to see what's still to come for these kinds of games.
An absolute classic. A major improvement on SimCity 3000, too. I played both 3000 and 4 a lot as a kid. Those games walked so that City Skylines could run.

I like the idea of playing this game more than I like actually playing it.

It's from a bygone era when we were kids, willing to stare at barely anything happening for hours on end. I love SimCity 4 nostalgically but by modern standards it's a boring idle game. Like watching a garden grow, or paint dry. Once you've seen one blocky block of apartment blocks you've seen them all.

Even if you keep yourself busy, most of your time is spent adjusting the city budget, gradually increasing funding for schools and clinics. It's such boring and menial spreadsheet work. Just like being a real mayor. The underlying problem being that the game's all numbers. It doesn't actually simulate anything, just applies some equations on economic values and then screams at you for being negative.

But its biggest flaw is that terrain doesn't matter. Not having to work around obstacles or build industry at resource locations just means that everything will be covered by a homogenous carpet of infinitely tiling mixed zone blocky city blocks.

The game is outdated and cannot run on modern machines without a person taking it upon themselves to do some coding. Here is a guide for anyone needing that kind of help: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=279736936

*** I'm not recommending due to performance issues only***  I loved this game when it was new, but it doesn't run well on my modern system.  Looking in the forums and online there are all sorts of tricky things you can do to improve the performance with newer hardware, but that is a hassle.  If you are lucky enough to get it running well on your machine, this is the definitive version of Sim City, way better than the newest iteration.  I grew up playing SC 2000, and this feels like a nice upgrade from that experience.

likes to crash, and favors cars a little bit too heavily. Best game for those of us who don't have infinite storage space (lookin at you cities: skylines), but still want a strong region/city builder.

Something about this game is nostalgic and makes me come back for more. I did not play this game as a kid but have always been a fan of city building games. This game lacks nothing and I would say better than SimCity (2013) or Cities: Skylines. The only issue is compatibility and crashes since it's an old game but you can find fixes online. If you love city simulation games, this is a classic with all it's early 2000s graphics glory. It is lovable and a fond memory for those that have played this for years, I'm sure. Therapeutic even with head shaking panicked city advisors.

As someone who has played SimCity 4, even longer than it has been on Steam, playing it again is a great visit down memory lane. And, with mods from sites like Simtropolis continue to make this already great game even better. Well worth the price in my humble opinion.

This game is unfortunately, without a doubt, still the best Sim City you can buy.

Not only do you manage your city, but your city is just one of many within a wider region. You build up these cities separately, connecting them together to share jobs, housing, and utilities, to form a wider metro area.

No multiplayer sessions unfortunately, which would have been fun, what with the deals cities can make. And to make a region with another, you have to share either the files, or the computer... if you share the files, only one person can make use of them at a time.

But still, lots to do, great singleplayer fun. If you want Sim City, you've found it.

20 year old game still one of the best games every made. If you want real life buidlings and mods to do whatever you want go to https://simtropolis.com/ click on Exchange Simcity 4 and they have mods, lots and regions. You can make Simcity 4 whatever you want it to be.

I recommend this game, especially for Finnish politicians who are currently dragging our budget sliders and clicking tax percents.. this game shows what happens when you do things without thinking.. so maybe learn by playing the game so you don't have to think in real life situations?

Simcity 4 has aged like wine, though perhaps that's only because city builder devs have taken multiple steps back since its release (minus a few exceptions). 
In my opinion the difficulty is more balanced and engaging than its modern counterpart, Cities Skylines, so make of that what you will. $20 for such an old game might be pushing it a bit, but the fact it's arguably the best in the genre makes up for that.

9/10.

While it does have some balancing issues, and is very difficult to break even with cashflow, it's a decent city builder. The Graphics are nice, I love the music, and the region system where cities adjacent to each other can influence each other is my favorite aspect that I've only seen in this game.

Sooo,  steam says I already own this game.  I was sure I did as well,  It doesnt show up in my library, so I am willing to spend Another 4.99 on it no problem.  Let me buy it dammit steam!!!   Its the best Sim City there is    Sim CIty 4 rush hour is TOP NOTCH!!!

I just cannot believe this game is still better than any other City sim game out there. And makes SIm City 5 blink twice. 

No DRM hassles. 1600x900 resolution, full details on with modern machine. Sure it looks aged but it has definitely aged well. 

My search for a good sim game is over. time to return to the classic.

Welcome to Sim City 4. In my humble opinion, this product right here is the pinnacle of city building simulator games humanity has ever been able to create. Don't be blindsided by later releases of this franchise or any other city building franchise for that mater. Sim City 4 builds upon previous entries in the franchise and doesn't fail to deliver. Neglect the fact that its old, it still looks fantastic and runs well on modern and old systems alike.

You might ask yourself: city building must sure be boring. You little fool, you have no idea what you're missing. Planning out industrial, residential, commercial office zones, watching them grow, setting up hospitals, fire, police and schools so the city can evolve, planning out streets, roads, highways, mass transit systems, water, trash, energy so the city can live... this game has it all. I won't go into detail as there would be too much to tell, but its worthy to mention that in the end, you can crash all your hard work by calling a giant robot to destroy the city... or maybe spawning a volcano in the middle of downtown. Tornados and meteorites are classics too.

There's always plenty to do in sim city, if any game should grab your attention, this should certainly be one of them.

I decided to commit an attrocity and write this review comparing this classic with Cities Skyline instead of the other way around. I just want to trigger everybody. Let's see if this will work.

The first downside of Simcity 4 is that, unlike its noble competitor C:S, it is purely isometric: you can turn your camera 90° but that's it. Point to C:S.

In this one you can zone your commercial/industrial/residential areas at will and the game will optimize roads within the zone. Wait... point for SC4 O.o

Well, if we compare the variety of roads, CS wins for sure. But SC4 has way more types of zoning. Draw.

Also, SC4 allows you to go control specific cars and go out on MISSIONS! Point for SC4 again!
SC4 also has Mayors, trying to advise you how to improve your city... plus the graphics and statistics of your city are way more meaningful than what C:S shows you.

Apart from graphics, SC4 aged super well. If you liked C:S you will probably like this one as well. No achievements, but also, no DLCs. Gah, take my thumbs up already!

PS: worked flawlessly on Linux via Proton!

Oldie but goldie. If u wanna try a classics in city bulding, this is it. And it still runs fairly good, possibly need some work(cant remember), but for me, runs 1920x1200 on Win10 normally. Tons of stuff to build, natural disasters, its all here. All here and complete, not after buying 20 DLCs for 300 euros. Yeah, just the game from the days, where games and gaming industry was still allright.

Yeah-and cause the Rush Hour datadisk is included, u can drive cars around your city. Even do some Police or Fire Department missions. Funny stuff, not for a long time, just few minutes of not building. Ive played this for ages before I bought it on Steam too as I couldnt be bothered with CDs.

[h1] Too bad EA Thanos snapped Maxis out of existence [/h1]
* slaps top of PC * back in my day i bought this games disc version, and when i say disc version i mean the 4 discs the game and all of its expansions came with.

THOSE WERE THE DAYS SHEEPLE. 

Too bad EA Thanos snapped Maxis out of existence 

Memeing aside this game got me into the city building genre without this game i wouldn't be the best mayor i could be in like 100000 other different games throughout the years.

[h1] Key Features: [/h1]
✅Huge region map for linking cities together
✅Disasters! lots of disasters! 
✅Old school graphic aesthetic 
✅freedom to build the city YOU want

[h1] Final Verdict: [/h1]
10 walking robot natural disasters out of  10

EA doubled the price, happy to have bought this for 3 EUR on sale, because it also suc*s! Aged terribly bad, I am used to play old games but this is a real punch in your eye, also the controls are terrible. If you like city sim, try Tropico 4 or Tropico 6!

If you wanted to play a good Maxis game, you've come to the right place mods make this game 100x better than it was. Trust me if you like modding, simulation, and good Maxis you've come to the right place.

The base game is already enjoyable for an almost 20 yo game but I strongly recommend to use some mod packs for a better simulation experience. A couple of region dlcs by Maxis are available on internet. 
The game's unstable on Win10 as expected, bugs & crashes happen so often, no sandbox option, probably the online server is dead (game crashes whenever I try it) and you can't extract natural sources like you can do in SimCity13.

So I was browsing a forums post on SC4 steam page and saw someone describe how to fix the constant crashing and play in 1080p on Windows 10. I did both of those things, and man I have been having an absolute blast with this game again. As a nostalgia junky, I love the feeling of sitting back in my living room for hours on end in 2005 playing this game on the family computer, except I understand way more about civics, government and urban development! So as far as the game goes, there's a bunch of things this game does so much better than Cities: Skylines. As an American, I have more attachment to the SC4 art style vs CS; as the game feels more aesthetically American. To the houses, sky scrapers, industry buildings, and service buildings; they look more realistic than what you get in CS. I also appreciate what the regions aspect does to city building, as the economy of adjacent towns you control will effect the region as a whole. So while you want to make a city of a million sims right away, you have to really nurture your region into a megalopolis. Something that the isolated CS builder is missing. I also feel like the budgeting is more challenging than other city builders, but misses the depth of CS ordinances/districts. It may sound like I hate CS, but it's one of my favorite games of all time. SC4 is just that good. If you're into simulators or city builders, SC4 is quintessential! Pick up a copy on sale, I couldn't have paid more than 10$ for mine

SImcity 4 is very fun, and it didn't age badly. 

It's cheap, can run on a toaster or a hardware equivelent. However it does have some crashing problems, and not all resolutions (like 1080p) are supported.

Enter this in SImcity's launch settings (right click on Simcity--> properties --> set launch options):

-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -CPUCount:1

First played this game in high-school, and over 15 years later, its still an amazing and addictively fun game. Adding mods to this game using sites like Simtropolis will make your customization of the game so much better. The game does crash often, so you'll want to install a separate Sim City 4 launcher that has an auto-save feature. The one I use is in the link below......

https://community.simtropolis.com/files/file/28667-sc4launcher-simcity-4-launcher-with-auto-save-feature/

I've seen it go on sale often, so slap it on your wishlist and grab it when it does!
old skool game, but has given me much enjoyment., Started to play this again, after much dissapointment from newer versions or games to feel as though they are equal./.. A++++

This is my favorite game but it is not playable on steam.  I was forced to choose another provider after steams recent update destroyed the video qualities of this game.  They refuse to admit it.  April 15 2019 was the update - date is approximate.

Gameplay 7/10
Story 1/10

Difficulty 8/10

As of 2021, [I]Simcity 4[/I] is still the best city-building game.

[list]
[*]Make sure you get the deluxe version or at least [I]Rush Hour[/I] as they improve gameplay, add some stuff, and fix quite a few bugs.
[*]Game is a bit unbalanced. It helps to use cheat codes and some ini-tweaking but it's not necessary.
[*]Mods. There are hundreds of thousands of mods available. Mods that revamp all roads, add new transportation types, overhauls all zone types, agricultural overhauls, building mods, etc. There are a lot of mods available.
[/list]

SimCity™ 4 Deluxe Edition promises an immersive city-building experience, but unfortunately, it's marred by frequent crashes. Like many others, I've encountered frustrating interruptions during gameplay, leaving me feeling disappointed and discouraged.

Despite its potential for captivating city management gameplay, the persistent crashes detract from the overall enjoyment. It's disheartening to invest time and effort into building your city, only to have your progress interrupted by technical issues.

While SimCity™ 4 Deluxe Edition has its merits, the prevalence of game crashes significantly impacts the player experience. Until these issues are addressed, it's difficult to fully recommend diving into the world of urban planning with this title.

Mac version not recommended.  It was clearly an afterthought and even simple features such as importing heightmaps or custom regions are not supported.  Most mods will not work.

Gameplay in general is enjoyable but not as engrossing as I remember classic Sim City being.  

U Drive It missions are terrible.  The interface is clunky and slow to respond, and while you're trying to learn how to drive thrings around your city your failed missions cause you to lose money, reputation and sometimes even city features.

For the price I can't recommend it.

Good fun, even comparable to Cities: Skylines. Takes a lot of effort to build a big city, so despite 19 years of age. this is not only certainly better than Simcity 2013, but if you're okay with an isometric view, just as fun as Cities: Skylines. Good buy.

All the poeple saying that this game wont work, they may be wrong. If they have not tryed to paste this in properties, then launch properties.

-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -f -d:DirectX -Cursors:fullcolor -Intro:off -CPUPriority:high -CPUCount:1
-r1920x1080x.  Chance the numbers to whatever your sreen resolution is.

I love this game. even though steam says i have under 1 hour i have proberly 50+ hours in this game. I played it on my old  computer, from a disc, until a windows update which made the disc unable to be read off.

This game is hard but fun. I have had alot of fun trying to make a working city, which is what made this so fun.
it is a little unstable, on some computers it is more stable then others, keep that in mind.

Let me start off by saying this is much better than the 2013 buggy mess that was Simcity.

Though this game can be quite difficult for beginners, understanding of what to do and how to get out of debt can be quite challengeing but when you finally understand the core basics the game becomes fun and easy to play.

I GIVE IT A 8/10 FOR EFFORT

Its a shame that Maxis want bad and died. Id hoped the series would continue to inspire young minds with games about building and nurturing something, and then optionally destroying it.

This iteration of Simcity is in soul the last and in my opinion most engaging and merciful of them all. It has plenty of quality community mods that have been around for ages for those who would want to pile more detail and micromanagement on a game thats already everything to do with micromanagement. I tried Cities, its not bad, but the game play is simply not intensive and micromanagey enough for me. Neither one is a replacement for the other.

I've clocked so many hours on this game. I love it. I'm a big fan of the city-building types of games. Endless fun. Also can be very meditative. I recommend naming your city something weird, so that when you see the headlines pop up, it's super funny. i.e. [b]My Left Sock[/b] is on fire! or A Grave Needed in [b]A Couple of Old Fish[/b]. ETC, ETC.

SimCity 4 (with the addition of Rush Hour) is still my favorite city building game, and I have Cities Skylines. Sure, at times it can be maddeningly frustrating when the game makes certain vehicle missions neigh impossible to complete, and there are the random crashes, but the attention to detail in the art and sprite animations are a delight, and there's nothing quite like growing a Podunk farming town into a regional high-tech mega city. The U-Drive-It missions add an element of playfulness that I feel is missing from Skylines. Despite being almost 15 years old this game is still fun and has an active modding community, so try it! (and save often)

I love the game. But I'll NOT recommend anyone to buy SC4 on Steam after the price surge by EA. Even the sale price at 75% is still expensive. Price is super expensive for 20 year old game.

Best Sim City game after 2000

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I've been playing this game since it was released all the way back in 2003, and I still say it is the best city building game ever released (sorry Skylines, you know I love you). Given how old this game is, there are some technical hiccups regarding modern systems, you need to do a bit of work to stabilize the game, and the highest resolution you can reasonably run it on is 1920*1200, believe me, I've tried. Once you have those tweaks done, it's very stable, and an absolute blast to play, and the modding community for this 16 year old game is still very actively creating new content. I fully recommend this game.

Simcity 4 crashed every 2 hours for me so ir ecoommend saving every 20 mins, otherwise the game runs perfectly.

If Simcity 4 doesn't work for you get simcity 2000

Do not complain that much and just add this launch option -intro:off -CustomResolution:enabled -r1366x768x32 (or whatever your resolution is so you can play it widescreen. It's the best city simulator for me for years and i played the new versions of these games.

Recommended to new Sim fans.  I remember years ago, playing the original Sim City and many of it's decendants. (Sim City 2, Sim City 3, Sim Chopper, etc) This used to be one of those games you would play for just a few more minutes - then next thing you know it's 3AM and you have to work the next day. I bought Sim CIty 4 Deluxe with a bit of fond nostalgia,  and soon enough I was looking at familiar yet different screens. In the older versions you had to build water and electric infrastructure, connect power across roads, and make sure you had sufficient plants to take care of all that. This version has a bit of that but it all seemed somewhat... tamer? Anyhow, with the advent of the internet and multi-player gaming I can see how this could be a good way to kill time with some friends, but for a single-player I think the older versions had something that was a bit more engaging. I read about a bunch of bugs this version is supposed to have, but I didn't run into any yet, so I think Steam did a decent enough job of patching it - or perhaps the bugs just aren't that noticable. The controls were all reponsive and with a bit of practice I learned where all the hidden menus were tucked away. I just don't think I will be spending that much time on this game, but for the price (under $5) it was worth it to me.

I really just have to give it a negative review.

But EA will never take care of their old stuff.

Will not work on Windows 8, and EA the shadiest game developers on the planet will not fix it.  Although a great game before EA started offering steamy piles of unfinished sh*t that you have to pay more for to get more ridiculously overpriced DLC, it connections with EA make it a buyer beware type game.

Greatest and most complicated city builder to date. It's very interesting exploring the ruins of this game's modding community online.
UPDATE: If you really like this kind of game but the age is showing it's wear, check out Cities: Skylines.

I've played around 12hr and had 2 or 3 crashes.. save frequently.  otherwise, awesome!

Edit - looked online and found some suggestions for fixing the crashes.  Set SimCity 4 to use 1 CPU core in the launch options and this solved the crashing issues.

SimCity 4 is not like SimCity 3000 in a few areas, but in most parts the gameplay is still the same. In SimCity 4 your budget is now fugured monthly, so it becomes even more important to get a good foothold quickly, and you need to be very careful in how you fund civic services, and keeping the city compact enough to allow for the radi of police, fire, schools, and any clinics or hospitals to fully grow to get the best bang for your simloins, as the tresurary can be depleted before you know it if you just build the serveces and not manage it correctly. Adjust funding as needed, and keep an eye to the news ticker, or to your various HUD's to know when something needs looking into so you can get on the job quickly. If funding remains too low for too long your sims might go on strike, which is not a good thing, as it hurts you mayor rating. You will want to keep the mayor rating well above -30 to prevent riots. If you do not have fire protection early, the first thing that could catch fire is the power plant, and if that burns down, then your city is in the dark. Do not wait until a fire breaks out to place a fire dept down. The tutorals will guide you through the basics of the game, and afteer you finish the tutoral, you can play the city like normal. Some aspects can be difficult, like getting one way streets to flow correctly can be a challenge at times and requires some trial and error. If you ever feel that the city is sinking too fast, you can always wipe it out and start new with a clean slate. If you made changes to the city before creation, those changes will stay, as will any trees that spawn in the city or that you have planted before or after city creation. There is more than just one city you can build in one region, and depending on how the region map generates there can be as many as 80 cities in the area for you to build. A true megaoplis can be built in SimCity 4 with all of its surrounding suburbs like a real major city.

I play sim city since the amiga with a great version on super famicom, simcity 2k was just as innovative and finally for climax simcity 4.
All other things released after that with ton of DLC are just regression in city builder gameplay !

Oh i forgot : simcity 4 has tons of mods and works perfectly on win 10 64b (with -cpucount:1 parameter)

in simple words : a must have city builder :)

One of the greatest PC games of all time. Cannot say it any clearer than that.

i have loved this game since it came out. Was so happy to find it again at Christmas. I remember playing it all christmas 20 years ago. WIsh they'd make a modern version. It crashes a bit.

Simcity 4 runs pretty well under Proton (I am using Proton-GE 7.55 currently) and seems to be pretty reliable and glitch-free at 1080p. Google for simcity 4 1080p to find some ways to set your screen resolution, I used the method where you hex edit the config file with the hexedit program on Devuan 5/Debian 12.

This game is pretty good, despite being paper-thin. It does a tolerable imitation of having a functional economy, if you don't expect too much from it. I used to play on vmware player, but the performance is quite a bit better in Proton.

Much like the original The Sims game (which this was released after and before The Sims 2), this game holds up. It's hard, cos running a city is hard, and it takes a good amount of time to understand how it all works, especially with the in-built expansion packs (the whole thing with controlling vehicles? Not part of the base game), but it stands the test of time. I used to play the original on a Windows XP eMachines computer when AOL was still a thing! Nothing's changed and it's still great!

If you hate what became of SimCity, with the always online stuff and general EA buggery, this is the best choice you can make. It's a great port of the game and just as fresh as it was when it first got released.

This really is the ultimate version of SimCity. Stripped down of everything that requires your brain to do much of anything, SimCity 4 Deluxe has everything you love about classic SimCity without the things you don't need.

Despite being over a decade old, this game remains the champion of its genre, thousands of modifications and additional buildings extend the gameplay into the eternity. That being said, game could use a bump in graphics/performance department. It's clearly not made for the powerful gpus available today, even though the graphics aged pretty well. Performance suffers a lot.

All in all, amazing game that you can now get for close to nothing!

With a fantastic soundtrack and an immense level of detail (considering it was made well over a decade ago) I found this game extremely immersive. It was fun setting the nuclear power plants ablaze and driving around trampling sims and cars alike with my tanks.

However, one drawback for me were the 'advisors' (Nagging children in disguise) constantly popping in unannounced at random intervals and whisking me away to the other side of town to have me do some remedial task such as 'replace a power plant' or cure a case of low funding  causing me to grossly misplace a monument I've been saving up for.

Nonetheless, great game, always stay faithful to Doctor Vu.

Had this game a long time ago, when I was in middle school. I could never really get the hang of it; lots of numbers and graphs and the like. I  recently re-downloaded it. I highly recommend playing with a cheatcode for adding money; I tend to flounder without it, and it's plenty challenging even with it. 
My only complaint: you cannot be good at this game if you play like a libertarian.

Amazing game, this is what the city builder should be. I am so sad that the new Sim City was such a let down after waiting so many years for the new release. I consistently play this one because of it's simplicity and feature set.

City Builder of its time.

Simcity 4 is the fourth followup in the detailed and engaging city builder series Simcity. Simcity 3000 and 4 are the only the ones I've played and generally see them on par as each other, whilst Simcity 4 is more detailed, there are some certain quirks that I dislike about 4 (i.e. vanishing traffic).

However, like Simcity 3000, Simcity 4 bathes in interaction, immersive sound and introspection. The game is highly polished compared to other recent city builder games (City Life series I'm looking at you), and although lacks a proper 3D engine has a definite charm to it. In short if you've never played city builders, this is your best place to start.

I know it's old, but this is perhaps EA's BEST rendition of the SimCity legacy to date. I played the new one on Origin quite a few times, played through many cities, and while I admit, the graphics might be a little more up-to-date in that version (I'm honestly not sure how to refer to it beyond the Origin version), and its gameplay might be a bit simpler, they killed a major element of SimCity with it. If nothing else, the areas you can play with in the Origin SimCity are TINY compared to what you get in SimCity 4. Yes, you play several of them in one region, but in SimCity 4, you get many HUGE areas to play with. It reminds me of EA's other major accomplishment, The Sims, in this way: by providing players with seemingly endless opportunities to keep playing, be it with a new city (new family in Sims) or by continuing to develop a city or group of cities to your heart's content. 

EA did this with Sims, too: instead of taking what's good about a game being consistent with it, they reinvent it over and over and it's basically a gamble of whether or not you're going to enjoy it again. They did the same with Sims. But anyway, if you haven't played SimCity 4, I'm happy to personally recommend it because except maybe approachability, it's great fun. I honestly get a little overwhelmed in the SimCity games from time to time when things aren't going right.

Has it really been 14 years since I first played this game? I remember going to Target and getting it the week of release and Wikipedia tells me that was 2003!! There's been a lot of games that I've played and forgotten about in that time but I still come back to play SimCity 4 once in a while.

I haven't played the Steam release as much but I used to spend hours upon hours on the disc-based version of the game. However, I still love making experiments with cities and see how they turn out. What would happen if there was no mass transportation in this city? What if there was no education? What if there was only one road? Etc..

Slowly and surely after playing city after city I see a huge megalopolis develop with large airports, extensive monorail routes and lots of freeways. 

This game definitely deserves a nomination for the Test of Time award. I don't think I currently play any games on Steam older than SimCity 4.

At this point, SimCity 4 is a creaky classic, but still a classic. If you're considering a citysim game you should weigh this alongside its predecessor SimCity 3000 and its figurative successor [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/255710]Cities: Skylines[/url]. If you already love the game, it's probably worth a Steam purchase if you haven't already. If you're still undecided, read on.


SimCity 4 was and still is commonly regarded as the pinnacle of its series by citysim enthusiasts. With the release of Cities: Skylines though, many of those same enthusiasts have seen that game as the new king of the genre. After a decade and change, SC4's life as the sole premier citybuilder came to an end.

However, SC4 still delivers a great citybuilding experience with enjoyable depth, graphics that still hold up well, and excellent music to listen to. Whether you should actually [i]play[/i] it depends on your affinity for the SimCity series, your attitude towards its complexity and your appetite for tinkering with the game to get it working.


SC4 is unquestionably the deepest, richest SimCity game, but for more casual players it can probably get too complicated. The game was released in 2003, and it doesn't play nice with newer computers. It's easy enough to get it running smoothly if you're technically inclined.

Custom mods truly bring the game to life, but each one has to be manually downloaded and configured. This can become annoying if not downright anal when you take into account the multiple separate dependency files that contain textures, items and other things that most mods use; a holdover from the waning days of dial-up internet...that morphed into creator pride which refused to allow the distribution of files with the mods that [i]actually used them[/i]. Also, if you don't organize your plugins folder, hunting down trouble with your plugins can be a nightmare.

If none of that sounds appealing? SimCity 3000 is older, but it delivers the series' best balance of accessibility and challenge. Meanwhile, Cities: Skylines is easier to run, has Workshop support for mods and takes inspiration from SC4 while improving on it in certain aspects. With the release of additional expansion packs, patches and Workshop mods, its depth may come to rival and even surpass SC4's, all while still maintaining a little more accessibility. Skylines however has a large number of DLCs, whereas SC4 had only one expansion which is included in the Deluxe Edition - definitely lighter on your wallet.


It's not a totally outmoded game, either. SimCity 4 does citybuilding a bit different than Cities: Skylines; it ultimately has a bigger scope and feel than Skylines offers, which might be more appealing to some. Other than that, its primary draws at this point are it's complexity if you're into that, the pedigree of its series, and its region play. If you already know you don't like SC4's region play I guess that won't matter to you.

Skylines gives you the option of purchasing more land to make into new districts, and the amount of land can be increased with mods. SC4 though gives you entire geographical regions of varying sizes to build multiple interconnected cities on, not to mention the capacity to download others' or make your own.

Region play is fascinating and very in-depth, which enhances the depth of the actual citybuilding. Unfortunately, there's no option to build a singular city by itself like in Skylines or previous SimCity titles, and you pretty much need to start other cities to have them grow past a certain point.

There are a couple things SC4 lacks, though. It lacks truly curved roads like in Skylines, and it doesn't have a lot of focus on walkability (an important aspect of modern urban design) without the addition of user-made mods. It also doesn't have mixed-use zoning, a sign of SimCity's roots in outmoded mid-20th century urban planning...though to be fair Skylines lacks this too, and you can always combine residential and commercial zones in any given block for something approximating it.


SC4 has over a decade's worth of custom content from its dedicated community, some of which is truly excellent & high-quality and extends the game considerably. Having a lot of mods however makes the game slower and sometimes more prone to errors, and you still need to manually download and place them in your plugins folder, so choosing and organizing them strategically is advised. If you're into it enough, it's worth it to go to [url=https://www.sc4evermore.com/index.php/downloads/category/22-dependencies]the dependency section on SC4Evermore[/url] and download everything there so you don't have to hunt for them when you download a mod.


Ultimately, even with minimal user-made mods SimCity 4 stands tall as one of the best of its genre, having only been really surpassed in any way by Cities: Skylines some 12 years after its release. If you've never played SC4 but decided it's for you, there are a couple things you should keep in mind.

As mentioned above, the game's decades old and can be somewhat unstable on newer machines. The game still chugs when running large cities. To optimize the game, I recommend the tips on [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/SimCity_4]this page[/url]. I also recommend saving your cities often in any case.

You [b]absolutely need[/b] a couple of mods to fix up the game and make it playable. The Network Addon Mod in particular unscrews the traffic algorithms so your transit network doesn't degenerate into a kafkaesque nightmare. There's a couple other quality-of-life fixes floating around, like the [url=https://community.simtropolis.com/files/file/30883-sc4fix-third-party-patches-for-sc4/]DLL fix[/url] or the [url=https://community.simtropolis.com/files/file/21342-opera-house-fix/]Opera House fix[/url] that aren't [i]as[/i] important, but still go a long way towards making the game more playable.

Always loved SimCity games, but this version kept crashing on me. Very discouraging when you put a hour or so of work into a city, only to lose all of your progress due to a lack of proper auto saves. Your experience may differ, but mine was a disappointment. Found City Skylines, and I've been playing that.

Still my favourite city sim, even though it's a bit dated, and it's a crashy mess on modern computers! Maybe that's nostalgia talking. At any rate, having the game crash while you're saving in case it crashes, is not fun. I really wish EA had put some effort into making it work, before adding it to Steam. Maybe they don't even have the original code any more? IDK.

At any rate, that makes it hard to entirely recommend, especially as they're still charging £10 for it. I picked it up in a sale a while ago because I thought it would be more convenient than using the discs I still have somewhere. That's not entirely true, but at least it's patched here.

If you're happy to go hunting online, you can find ways to make it run at 1920x1080, and switch the locale so cars drive on the other side of the road. (This is the USA localised version, but it seems to come with the data for the other versions, there's just no config screen to change it.)

Also, there's still an active mod scene at http://sc4devotion.com, but it would have been nice if they'd added workshop support, because who knows how long sites like that are going to stay around?

I first played SimCity 4 in 2005 and instantly fell in love with it. Back then, I clocked in hundreds of hours of playtime and to this day it remains one of my favorite city builder of all time.

The graphics, although they may appear a little dated to modern eyes, still hold up quite well.

The most important aspect, the gameplay, is just as great as it was back in the day. You can create everything from a polluted industrial wasteland to a shining metropolitan utopia and everything in between. Although easy to learn, the game can be quite complex: you can manage everything from the topography to transportation routes in your city.

Although a minor point, it's worth mentioning that SimCity 4's soundtrack is superb. It definitely contributes to the game.

Additionally, there is still a somewhat active modding community for this game. There are mods that add new buildings, transportation options, custom textures, and various other things that improve the game overall.

One minor criticism I have is that a little work is required to get everything running properly on modern hardware, but there are a couple of guides available on the community hub for this. After tinkering with Steam's launch options for a few minutes, I had no further issues.

Overall, I recommend SimCity 4, especially if you like city builders. It is a classic and still one of the best examples of its genre.

Sim City is a game series I have played for most of my life. 
It's creative, calming, and can be replayed over and over.  
If you like simulators and building games, Sim City is the OG.
Some people paint, I play Sim City and plant happy little trees! (Thanks Bob Ross)

The best SimCity game in the whole series, IMO.

It runs flawless on Windows 8.1, and you can even add a custom resolution command to play it in 1080p. However, the game has crashing issues on multi core CPUs. This can be fixed by changing the CPU affinity to 1 core, but this has to be done every time the game is opened.

Old school sim game with limited graphics, but fun none the less.  Great game for the $2 I spent for it on sale, well worth the money!  It of the generation of Civ III, back with lots of limits on it capabilities, but simple fun like a old-timey board game.

SC4 allows you to build the city of your dreams and is amazing at it. Now, you might be thinking, why dont I just go buy Cities Skylines, it has better graphics and performance and still gets worked on! SC4 has its own unique touch that I cannot explain, I think of SC4 and Cities Skylines on the same level. Sure this was made in 2003 and has 2003 graphics, but it is such a good game, and its cheaper than Cities Skylines.
If you like city building and riots from your people getting angry when you build a missile silo next to their elementary school this game is for you.

Sim City 4 is a very good game, loved it when I was Younger and I still enjoy it now. For a game made in 2003 the graphics could somewhat be relevant to 2012, as 2017 is a different age of gaming. Hope they could make a SimCity 5, as Sim City 2014 was a bummer.

The crowning achievement of the SimCity IP; SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition delivers all of the best features and systems of each of the previous versions into this better and improved offering.  Some would argue that SimCity 5 was a more improved version, and to them I say this, Origin was not inolved in the making of SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition and therefore is the much improved title!  The need to be always connected to the Internet in SImCity 5 killed the game for me, I love the option of Online Interaction but hate that I cannot play the game as a single player Offline; thanks again Origin!  The addition of Sim interaction in this game was wonderful, the ability to add your own Sims to your cities and get their oppionions about specific things was sorley missied in this title's predicesors.  Having played all previous versions I had always longed for an in-game method for dertermining which things about my city were small annoyances to my populace but not major enough for my advisors to complain about.  These things would affect your mayoral rating as well as have an effect on which Sims would move into and out of certian areas.  Furthermore, the addition of the Piloting mechanics added a new layer of depth to the game while offering new construction options to the player for accomplishing different missions.  If you loved any of the previous SimCity games, this one will not dissapoint!

Simply the best city building environment ever. The custom content and dedicated online community has kept this game going for over 20 years around the world. It can be played as a game or as an ongoing creative sandbox to build huge regions of beautiful cities. There's a sense of humor as well. 
Beginners may encounter a learning curve but online help is available and persistence will ultimately reward.

Still one of the best city builders out there, though the sheer amount of mods that you need to download to play this game to its best potential is really staggering... I'm talking dozens and dozens of mods that for some silly reason are not all packed together in a convinient single file.

But then again, can't really throw hate at the guys who modded this thing for doing things one way or the other. The simple truth is that without mods this game loses its value.

If you liked the previous SimCity titles, then you'll dig this one (after modding it). Definetely better than the newer titles out there.

It's just hands down one of the best games ever. If you get hold of hte freely available mods to improve it, then you are in for a treat. Playing it vanilla can be a testing experience, but one that is refreshing to go back to after playing with the mods.

Wow,

Ive had simcity 4 since i was 4 (it was first on disk) it was a great game BUT, i have been getting better at the game and the game has been getting increasingly esier but it has been getting more and more boring but it is still fun

Game rating 8.5/10

Sim City 4 is still the Gold Standard city building simulation game, 12 years and counting.  This game still is at the top of the throne because of all the customization and modification you're able to make in this game.  With several websites solely dedicated to hosting SC4 mods, you are left with endless possibilities in how you want to design your region and cities.  The only misfortune this game suffers from is that is doesn't have the modern luxuries of new games(enhanced graphics, better hardware support, better core features to name a few), but the modification to this game helps alleviate most of this issues.  

While my time on Sim City 4 is limited through Steam, I have certainly put in over 1500+ hours of game play throughout the years, and it remains one of my favorite games of all time(a game that I certainly keep coming back to over time).  If you're into city building games, this is a must for anyones gaming library.  Even after 12 years, every city building game that comes out has the same questions, which is, Can this topple SC4 for best city build sim?.  Each game has failed to dethrone this champion(Cities:Skylines might be the best bet).  With all that said, if you haven't played this game, I highly urge you to make this an addition to your library, you will not be disappointed!

Ive played this game for years, its a fixture in my games library. The sheer joy of growing a city or a region of interconnected cities is unrivalled within the genre.

Game is a classic. Its life has been extended so far by what is still a vibrant modding community, including a few mods that are absolute must haves like the NAM.  

Load times can be a bit long if you go mod crazy and given the age of the game it doesnt look amazingly shiny, but overall if you have that itch to be a mayor, then this will scratch it and more!  Even on todays machines, with a few tweaks - that anyone can do imo - this runs like a charm.  

No matter what, this is the pinnacle of Maxis work with the SimCity line up.

Bought it and then refunded, the reason: Constant crashing after about 5-10 minutes of gameplay. I seen solutions for this fix. People on the community forums suggested that a person should download thirdparty modding and autosave features, so that when it crashes, you can pick up where you left off. 

While I thank modders and community for these suggestions, the games current state is no excuse, for lazy devs not putting any effort into this release, it's shame because I was somewhat interested in it's system; it seemed complex and fun, but the constant crashing had me start ALL over, and that's not a challenge, it's annoying and unfun.

If you can get this game to work like a dream, with no crashes and maintain framerate like I did, coupled with several hundred or more great mods from Simtropolis.com, this game becomes one of the greatest, if not the greatest city- builder money can buy. also, Can't forget that nostalgic ass music by the one and only Jerry Martin.

Pick it up, download some mods, and put a little time into creating some great regions.

The new age of SimCity has arrived in SimCity 4: Deluxe Edition. EA has created yet another fantastic game for the PC and they have succeeded in making it work. SimCity 4: Deluxe Edition is a marvel, because it's like you are building a real city on real terrain. You control the city in every way possible. I got this game because I am a SimCity fanatic and I couldn't wait to try it out. Once I finally installed the game I did the Tutorials (which are optional) and finally got to create an entire region! That's rite I said region, an entire state seems to be at your fingertips! You can make Oceans, lakes, rivers, mountains, cliffs, and even plateaus with GOD mode. Forests and animals alike can be created as well! In this game you are finally in control.

Graphics 9/10
Now I'm not one to judge a games graphics, because to me, that doesn't make a game what it is but this game is different. It looks as though you are in an airplane looking down on real forests and buildings that you yourself created, now that is what I call the work of EA.

Game Play 9/10
Now this is what makes SimCity what it is, you have control of everything on your map, the terrain, the animals, and obviously your city. You make your city from the ground up, you start with nothing but level land and then you make residential, commercial, and Industrial areas along with a power plant. You work your way up and begin adding schools, police and fire stations, library's, water plants, and so much more. Before you know it your small village where everybody knows everybody becomes a bustling metropolis, complete with towering sky scrapers and traffic problems, which brings me to my next topic. The expansion Rush Hour comes complete with the Deluxe Edition making it possible to drive cars, boats, and airplanes in your city. You can be a police officer chasing down a thief or you can be an evil scientist attempting to transport dangerous chemicals across your city. You can really be anyone and do anything in this game. There is also a mode in which you can move your sims into your city, where they can gather opinions from civilians that live in your city about how good of a job you are doing. In MAYOR mode you build your city and make complex road systems, airports, seaports and massive bridges to cross seas. You can design a sewer system or even create a vast country side of ranches and farms. The best part is in GOD mode, where you can unleash a hoard of disasters on your city, from fires too alien invasions you can re-create judgment day on your defenseless sims.

Replay Value 8/10
You can never finish the game but after a solid good 6 months of playing it you will feel like you have done everything there is to do, but in this game, the sky is the limit. If you had the energy and lived in a decent sized city you could recreate it rite on your computer, that is just how detailed this game really gets. This game gets more complicated the bigger your city gets and sometimes you get so confused that you just give up playing for awhile.

Do not rent this game, just don't buy it if you don't like simulation games. It goes for about forty dollars and it is a good buy so if you are really into the SimCity games you can mow a couple of lawns, but if you just like any good simulation game go ahead and buy it if you have forty bucks laying around.

Overall rating 9/10

Best city sim ever created. Not without it's problems, dense cities become impossible to manage. If you're going for a city with a population of a million citizens you can do it but no matter how well you plan there will always be too much smog traffic and garbage. There will also be idiots who leave their houses deserted and start a life of crime in the thousands because their commute to work was three hundred miles away for absolutely no reason at all. Seriously if I put a commercial zone next to a house why do it's occupents commute to Holland?

Still, this is the best of the series and the series is the best in the world at city building. Simcity 2013 has exactly nothing that this doesn't have except a higher price tag and a deep feeling of regret.

To my knowledge this was the last of the actual SimCity Simulator games, which in my mind makes it the best.  Yes it is an old game and the graphics will show that, but the game play is MUCH better than SimCity BuildIt which is a shadow of its former self.  One annoying thing is the driving quest feature just doesn't seem to work right with the newer operating systems, at least I have never got it to work right.  Anyway take this review with a grain of salt.  You will either like this old, yet original format of SimCity or you won't.  Happy City management, Mayor.

For an older game SimCity4 is worth playing in my opinion.  I know a lot of people get frustrated with this game because it tends to lag a little once your cities get bigger but, I dont't think its the end of the world its still very playable. Within this series, I've played SimCity 2000('93) when my brother introduced me to it then I moved on to SimCity 4 and I've been hooked ever since. Another thing I've noticed about this game is that, you need a lot of patience and most people don't bother and they give up. The reality is SimCity 4 is very strategic because, you must think way ahead of time when laying out your city and think of future problems like traffic. I'd suggest taking your time and not try to rush growth of your city because, you'll run out of funds very early. It takes time to build a solid foundation so that you can have a decent mount of monthly income. Everyone who plays this game figure out what strategy works for them but, don't let the occasional frustration steer you away. Overall, I think this game is very fun to play and you can let you imagination go wild with the extra downloads you can add to your city.
I'm more of a fan of SimCity 2000 (I got fired so many times in that one!), but SimCity 4 is a great game in its own right, and it's still more in-depth, vast, and varied than the 2013 series reboot.

Still the best city building simulator around. It's complex with many options on how to run your city and it doesn't oversimplify your problems. If you were looking for Simcity 5, look no further because that game was garbage and this game is golden.

THIS GAME! MAKES ME SO ANGRY!

Not really the game itself, the game is legendary, this is by far the best city building simulater I have played, certain featured of Cities XL have made it a competitor, but does't get over the line against this game! There are a range of mods for this game to increase the functionality of roads, to expand on the limitations of the road snapping and limited interchange types etc. The only reason I get mad is since the game is old, it  has some performance issues on modern pc's when you have a larger city with more things for the CPU to load, it's simply not optimised for modern day machines.

I can't say I have played the new Sim City, alot of people have said it's not worth the time compared to this game, but I wish they made a re-mastered version of Simcity 4 like what they do for games like Age of Empires.

All in All, great game, lags sometimes on larger cities but great game!
With so many mods like CAM and NAM to say the least the game has become what it should have been from the beginning. @0 years on and I'm still coming back to it.

8.5/10

Even though I now played Cities:Skylines,this game is indeed a legend. I haven't played the latest Sim City, but I've played all the rest. This is by far, my most favorite version. This gives you all the features that you expect out of a Sim city builder game. You zone land for the three basic types in your city: residential, commercial, and industrial. Each of the three zones has three subcategories. For example, you can pick an agricultural zone for industrial or medium density, which will allow small shops and factories. Same goes for the other core zones. Placement of services is critical in the city. Police stations, fire stations, and hospital proximity to things is all important. But your sims want more than just the essentials. They want soccer fields, plazas, playgrounds, and tennis courts as well. Again, where these units are placed is critical. Each thing you make costs a build amount and a monthly upkeep, so thought must go into it. As does how much road you have and of what type. You can eventually add rail, boats, planes, and a myriad of other additions to the pulse of the city. 

I have a few gripes with the game though (all minor). One, the camera controls could be smoother. Two, WASD should be the primary camera control instead of the arrow keys (the game shows its age here). And three, I wish the game had more organic choices for laying roads and placement of zones. All things snap to the grid and diaganol roads have a funny bend to them. These have nothing to do with the enjoyment of the game though.

Sim City is a relaxed, leisurely game to play.

I can't stop playing this game lately.  The region building tools and the interconnectedness of each community gives me umpteen thousand ideas as both a writer and a gamer.  This game holds up amazingly well for its age.

And whilst yes, much of SimCity 4 has become outdated compared to recent City Builders; and it's somewhat behind in terms of the interface and streamlining of modern games; there are few games out today that offer the same feeling. The only game I can think of that comes close to this in terms of offering a balanced and enjoyable city building experience is Cities: Skylines, and that hasn't even been released yet.

So my verdict: A classic with gameplay that is still relevent. And whilst it's only mere days until the promising game Skylines comes out, meaning that anyone looking to play a game whilst waiting would already have taken their pick, SimCity 4 is one of those games with features that just don't get made the same anymore.

Easily one of the best traditional city-builders to date, along with Cities: Skylines. There's an enjoyable experience to be had all-round, from the regional gameplay allowing for metropolises of very large sizes, to the small details that appear upon closer inspection. SimCity 4 easily has the most in-depth simulation of your city's economy, which really allows you to see how your choices affect your city's growth. The art direction in SimCity 4 also adds to this, with each level of wealth and density receiving its own unique appearance, adding an extra layer of detail on top of the already impressive simulation. Every part of building your city is accompanied by a fantastic soundtrack, too, which will really make you want to continue building. The extensive modding community can add additional content on top of this already great game, too (although it isn't anywhere near as big as the Cities: Skylines modding scene).

SimCity 4 is not without its flaws, however. It's somewhat poorly optimised for modern systems, and this can become especially apparent with larger cities. It's harder to make your 'ideal' city in this game compared to Cities: Skylines, given that it gives you a larger picture rather than something where everything can be personalised. The traffic simulation compared to Cities: Skylines is also weaker, since the two games simulate the individual people living in your cities differently. Overall, the pros and cons of SimCity 4 boil down to what you want out of a city-builder.

This game is so epicly good. Lots of fun in here. Game can run a bit poorly with a big city though as it doesn't really know how to utilise modern hardware (this game was released in 2003).

The game will also run on Linux through Proton, so there is no additional configuration needed for this game to work for Linux gaming.

Also, before you launch the game paste the following commands into the launch options, which you can find by right clicking the game in your library and, in the drop down menu, selecting Properties>General.

-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -intro:off -CPUPriority:high -CPUCount:2

This will make the game run in 1080p (or whatever resolution your monitor is, so long as you type that resolution in place of 1080p. It will also skip over the intro logos for EA, making the game boot a bit faster and changing the CPU priority to high and assigning 2 CPU cores to the game will make the game run a bit faster too.

Easily the best SimCity game. I can sink hours into this game and not even realize it. It runs well on Windows 10 except for the fact that it does crash once in awhile unexpectedly. So do save your game as often as you can.

Personally i enjoy this game. It came out in 2003 but it is still one of the best city building simulators out there. i used to own the disc. unlike sim city 2013 you have full control over the region, you can do what you want to the terrain and everything. theres lots of things you can do in this game such as Build Giant beutiful cities , if you want to build a massive transit system that goes from one end of the region to the other end you can do that. if you want to just build a small town you can do that. if you want make your city get destroyed by a giant dinosaur make out of cars you can  do that.

It's moddable beyond anything a modern games maker would even consider, letting you change traffic simulation, train, plane and ferry skins, add buildings, add HD textures, alter the way a city needs to grow, you name it. And installation of said mods is child's play, simply downloading files into a plugin folder. And because of it's age the sheer amount of mods out there is insane. The community is still alive and kicking after 11 years, which tells you something about the longevity of this game. If you like city builders then look no further, Maxis set the bar with this one and it has yet to be beaten.

I have had 500+ hours playing this gem-of-a-game which is, in my opinion,the best city-building game till date ! 
The fun that one gets by starting from scratch by building farms to enjoying those moments when the first skyscraper starts growing up is amazing . The depth this game has in terms of buildings and strategy  is what has made this game what it is . 
            From different varieties of powerplants,parks,playgrounds to the variety in roads,highways,transportation system,this game lacks none ! And the most amazing part is that,you also get to drive vehicles in your city  and see for yourself how pathetic or awesome your city traffic and roads are :)

This is IT!
This game is the Holy grail of city simulation. You can search for other city sims, but there is none worthy of this one.
Sure you have the new ''city sims''. But those are games. Maybe they are playable, maybe they have good graphics, maybe they have a satisfactory sim engine. But nothing beats SC4. Nothing can even compare to the vastness of this beauty! The only reason I got a Steam account is to buy this game again. 
After you get a hang of it, you will be able to build vast cities. And I don't mean vast simcity 2013 stuffthatisntreallyevenbig, I mean real life vast. You can make a city over an infinite amount of tiles. and the tiles are 4x4km, so that is vast. You can make complex networks of roads, rails, waterways, highways, canals.. bassically anything you can think of. Due to the again VAST online community of modders, who after 10 years still make new and new stuff every day!
And when I say that, that means free and for the more organised teams thoroughly coded, tested and fully functional mods, that have changed the game to an extent, that it became unrecognasible. And all that from people that live for this game, not some employees of some big company doing stuff they are dictated to do as quick and buggy as possible.

If you like the genre of city simulation. You can not buy a better game. And the amount of money spent on this game, is money well spent!

To a 10 more years of Sim City 4!
