Simcity 4 was, and still is, the best city-planning simulator.

It have very deep game mechanics, which ensure the city simulation is dynamic. It is nearly impossible to just pan outmore zones without many different issues. Most of these issues will have  affect on the population, and this would cause other issues, etc. All the city planning simulators came after it failed to reach its level in terms of complexity. And it is friendly toward beginners. ( Hint: After go wild building for a while, you may want to go back to check the tutorials.) 
Its graphic is outdated.The game engine is not very effective. (One of the devs explained that is because the game was built before DirectX 9) The camera is fixed. Look at the screenshots and determine yourself. 
The game is moddable. The UI and the engine can not be edited. But all the data and the models are. This results in a great collection of building (and other thing on ground) mods. Most of them requires manual install, and sometimes need additional dependency. They can be found on Simtropolis or SC4devotion.com.
The most important mod for Simcity 4 is Network Addon Mod, or NAM. It is a great improvement, if not overhaul, of traffic system. I recommend anyone who plan spending more than 10 hours on this game to install it. Due to engine restrictions, build a tram-in-avenue/tram-on-road interchange or underground tunnel is more complex than it should. But at least you can do it, with patience and time.

The classic and original Sim game - as good as it gets minus performance issues. SimCity 4 offers great replayability and complexity, with an insane amount of player-created content available on the internet. The learning curve is less than linear, with basic city building as easy as it has ever been, but end-game being at least as complicated as it has ever been (GameFAQs has some good write-ups to help newbies). The only notable drawback (other than tame gameplay, but hey, it's a SIM!) is how poorly SimCity performs on budget and entry-level PCs. Just lower the default settings to the lowest and slowly crank them up and you won't have a problem.

Anyone that wants to argue economic political views, or complain about their local roads needs to play this game first so they'll have a clue of what they're talking about. Hands down a better educational / fun experience than college courses about the same topics.

Pretty fun game, although be aware the game looks like it was made for Windows XP.  (Probably was actually). Played SC5, and honestly this (with or without mods, which you should at least look into) is better.

This was the second Sim City game I ever played, the first being Sim City 3000, but I generally preferred this one since it featured a tie-in to the Sims 1 where you could put your Sims in your city, had a driving feature, the regions feature, and more customization options. I wish more features carried on in later Sim City games, although I miss some of the old features from Sim City 3000 - which was revamped for the DS - such as different disasters and the option to choose your city adviser. I also liked Sim City Societies (available on Origin) but I would've liked it better with regions - it did offer a better climate system though. Overall, this is the Sim City game I come back to most.

Edit: If you buy this game and it crashes, don't try to fix it. If you attempt to fix it it could alter your chances of getting a refund. This is one of the times I really lament the state of the Steam review system. It is difficult to give this game the rating it deserves based on a thumbs up and thumbs down alone. Skip the next two paragraphs for the TL;DR version.

The SimCity series used to be synonymous to the city simulator genre, kind of like Xerox and Kleenex are synonymous to photocopying and tissue paper respectively. This is an old game, so there will bound to be some minor issues running on relatively modern hardware, and back then, it was, at worst, tolerable, because nothing else came close. I had been playing this game even before Steam existed.

Then came the lackluster SimCity (2013) after years of waiting for its successor, and then a few years later, came the promising Cities: Skylines by a different company. This game was really good back then and aged gracefully way beyond any reasonable expectation largely thanks to its modding community, but ever since, I started playing Cities: Skylines two(?) years ago, I just never went back to SimCity 4.

In conclusion, any person new to the city simulator genre should probably skip SimCity 4 and go with Cities: Skylines instead. This game is really showing its age, modding it is a bit more involved, and the minor issues are still there. For anyone who is already into the genre but wants to have a more vintage experience or simply wants to go down memory lane, you cannot go wrong with this game. Given all that I have said, it is with an incredibly heavy heart that I no longer recommend this game for most.

This is the only real City Builder I played as a kid. I remember spending hours of my time building buildings, destroying them, driving cars like I'm in GTA, and just watching time go by. It definitely is a fun game if you take it for what it is and how old it is. Don't expect the graphics or upgrades in Cities Skyline, but this is a great item to have if you're hunting old games.

I played SimCity 4 Deluxe before I knew about steam and when windows XP was the “modern” platform, so finding this game here brought back a whole lot of great memories. I love the way the game works and how you can build your city and even drive vehicles and all. I saw some people commenting that it crashes randomly or frequently but I don’t have this problem. I currently play it on my MacBook and it works great! Anyway I have always loved this game and I’m glad it can still be played on modern devices. Definitely recommend.

The greatest city builder game of all time. What more can be said? It may take some fiddling to get to run on modern systems but you will not be disappointed. the modding scene is also active. If you love city builders you need this game.

This game is still great to me and I can never seem to let it go. No matter how long ive owned it or what other games I have, I still always end up reinstalling and pouring tons of hours into SimCity 4 over and over agian. This is really what Im looking for in a Sim game. The Sims is cool and all but no other Sim game brings me back like this one. The huge grid format with all the different spaces for different municipalities where the landscape, utilities, traffic, jobs, and everything all interweaves like a real nation would. I love Cities: Skylines for its new take on the old SimCity games but it doesnt have this one feature that changed everything for me. It wasnt just building a blank slate over and over anymore. The different cities would build and evolve differently and affect each other. Striking deals with each other for garbage, water, power, and all the other little ways each new city would play into the dynamic of the whole map. It was a great direction that seems to have been left aside. You do see that same spirit in how the different sims in towns would interact and intermingle with each other in the later The Sims titles but nothing along the sim city gameplay. What keeps bringing me back after all these years is how differently each play seems to evolve, so it doesnt go stale for me. 

TL;DR Great Game. Would Buy

I have always loved this game since it's release. I have made many memories with it since it was one of my first games on the computer when i was a kid. It's debatable the last good Sim City. Back then, EA wasn't what it is today. 

Sadly the Steam version of this game always crashes on me after i hit a population of around 5-10k (must be Windows 10, i think this was made for XP). I still recommend this game, maybe it's just my computer.

Ignore the 0.1 hours spent playing, I've been playing the original retail build since I already had it installed and bought the Steam copy when it was on sale. This applies to the retail build but unless EA quietly made changes before it appeared on Steam, should still apply to the Steam version.

Now then, a game thats over 10 years old is still miles better than its 2 year old sucessor. How is this possible you say? No restrictions on city size, more transportation options, never required Internet connection in the first place.  Throw in game altering mods like Colossal Addon Mod and what could be considered an unofficial expansion pack, Network Addon Mod and you have near perfection.

Sure its a bit buggy and crash prone and no widescreen support but there's guides on the Internet on using what launch options to fix the widescreen issue and lessen the blow. Only downside is that I don't get a landmark commerating the server failure. SimCity 2013 has that though.

I would most recommend this to anybody who is into cities and simulators. Used to play this back around 7 years and ready I can feel the nostalgia when I heard the music. I used to have some trouble making cities but now I'm starting to understand the necessities needed to make a metropolis even though I've had yet to create skyscrapers...

Get your money's worth during the 75% sale.

[h1]SimCity 4[/h1]
Looking for a cheap way into city building/management games?
This is exactly what that is!
No endless DLC *cough*[i]Paradox[/i]*cough*
Many of the mechanics used in modern games came from this gem of a game.

[h1]Build Cities & Maintain Them[/h1]
Construct roads, setup trade deals with neighboring cities; provide jobs, a police force and watch it all burn by the feet of godzilla!
It's a city building & management game of the highest shelve, which aged like fine wine.

[h1]What do I do in it?[/h1]
I build cities, making sure you have a balan.. who am I kidding I build a basic city then call in heaps of natural
disasters to [b]burn it to the ground![/b]

[h1]Does it run on modern hardware?[/h1]
Yes, suprisingly so.
To get a modern resolution out of it you do need to do some tweaking.
It also doesn't crash .. ever.
[i]Unless you have messed with too much mods and settings..[/i][b]*Achievement Unlocked* Welcome to 'Sim' games![/b]

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*]A artstyle that held up well.
    [*]Many fun things to do, like putting Sims in game & driving with their cars; same goes for emergency services.
    [*]You can drive in emergency vehicles, fly helicopters, a feature not seen in SimCity 5 or other games.
    [*]Ability to add your own Sims while watching their every move.
    [*]More city building mechanics than you'd come to expect given its age.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Camera can sometimes be a b*tch to control!
    [*]Resolution is stuck at 1600x1280 unless you use external tools
[/list]


[h1]Tip for all Sims 2 Players :[/h1]
[b]You can build cities in SimCity 4: Deluxe Edition afterwards importing them into The Sims 2![/b]
If you own The Sims 2: Ultimate Collection on Origin this is quite simple as there are good tutorials out there.
Giving this the power of The Sims 3 Create-A-World tool but for The Sims 2.

Basically the standard to which any city builder is measured. The mechanics are initially obtuse but once you get the rhythm of city development going (Follow your RCI display steadily. Need housing? Build some and wait then the job demand will come. Constantly adjust your expenditures etc) the satisfaction of watching skyscrapers rise from your small village is incomparable. Each city zone becomes inter-connected and dependant as well, further feeding growth until you're rich enough to place landmarks like the Empire State Building or Pyramid of Giza.
For a game from 2003 it still looks fantastic as well, and the soundtrack has no right to be as well produced as it is. 
The only gripes come from someone that's reached the endgame of city development. The mod NAM is essential in fixing the quirks of population pathfinding, though it's a testament to the game's quality that it's still updated today. Agriculture will never provide sufficient jobs and isn't required to feed your civs so can be taxed into redundancy, the same with Dirty Industry which is essentially pointless. Constructions don't react well to inclines resulting in ugly jagged foundations, and without mods the boundaries between land and water are dodgy.
This is all nit-picking though. Sim City 4 has yet to be dethroned as the essential city builder.
The game was getting lots of artifacts and really poor performance. I tried a custom made launcher for newer hardware but nothing changed. From my personal experience I can't recommend it. Refunded.

Tried and true but with a few nuances that can be annoying, it's stable and works well. I've never had a crash or lockup caused by this game and I've had it for years. Just got the steam edition and it seems to be just as good as the original.

9/10

SimCity…The definitive city building game…The time show on steam doesn’t show the amount of time I have spent since I bought the game in 2004. As a matter of fact, I have gone through about 5 copies of this game…SimCity4 has infinite replay value. No 2 cities will be the same…..don’t even attempt to make a duplicate city…it will not work.Simcity4 works a little differently from the previous version of SimCity in that, where the previous versions just gave you a plot of land to build on, SC4 lets you select a region, akin to a city or county in your state. You can import and export among the regions, sell electricity, water and import garbage. Build a police station with a helipad and be a helicopter pilot stopping crimes. Build a hospital with a helipad, and deliver a liver for a transplant. Build a small airfield and  spray crops for insects, or write messages in the sky. Built an airport, and watch the tourism tax dollars start rolling in…

From Cities XL to Sim City: Societies, pretenders to the throne have come and gone, but none can truly challenge SimCity 4.

As the final franchise installment before the sale to EA, SC4 represents everything Maxis learned about the city-building genre they single-handedly created, quite appropriately, from nothing. It is meticulous without pedantry. It is involved without perplexity. It is engaging without gimmicks. Timeless graphics paired to a funky, soulful soundtrack bring it all to a mirror shine.

Sim City 4 is not just a shining example of wisdom distilled through generations; Sim City 4 is inspired requiem for a masterful developer.

9/10.

By that logic, it makes sense build and raze them after each emergency.

Since you are god you can also ruin the lives of your citizens by setting fires, tornados, meteors, volcanos, aliens, giant robots, and more! If this game goes $10 or less it is worth the investment.

A Classic that hasn't aged one bit. Like Civilization, the inner-victory of the game comes from one play-through of the game where one successfully implements his or her mental order onto the world of the Sims. I picked San Francisco because she is my favorite city. I began with a segment labeled 'Heart' where I built a Wind Power Plant, an Elementary School, a Clinic, a Farm and a Police Kiosk.  I grew the city from here as a core agrarian society, to the tune of the outer-hamlet. I picked low-density housing for my citizens because that felt good for everyone. There were experiments, for my citizens and myself: I destroyed the small fragments of higher density housing and industrial segments because they did not harmonize with the heart of the city. Jobs were available, and despite the recurring requests of my 'Law Enforcement Advisor', I deliberately made my enforcement coverage thin. Consequently, my fire defenses only required a thin coverage. After making my government profitable, I decided to built The Sphinx facing a beach, and hence looking west-wards towards the eternal enigma, for a community of Ocean-loving residents. The beat of the Hamlet started to change, and I built a seaport first. Then, a segment of heavy industries and a lighthouse. They became the immaculate clockwork giving the gold lustre to The Great Pyramid. The game crashed after I built an airport surrounded by culture and commerce. Boom, Bim, Draugvarsis... Life thrives. The bits yield infinite magic, but some games can be shy.

Ignore all of those bad reviews that pop up now and then, they're probably just people who have bad computers/brains. Anyhow, really fun game. Graphics aren't bad, even though they're mainly 2D, they're made to look like 3D. The gameplay is awesome, too. I remember playing this as a kid, I would literally rush for a large city with skyscrapers using landmark towers and stuff. Because at the time, I didnt really know too much about the game, but I kept failing, and kept playing. That's how good the game was. Games like Master of Olympus and Simcity 4 are the reasons why I am playing games today. Without these games in my childhood, I probably wouldn't be sitting here writing a review about it. I recommend to all who want a Simcity with decent graphics and gameplay, on a balance. It's got better graphics than 3000, and better gameplay than Simcity 2013.

I feel like Simcity 4 deserves a lot of respect for how re-playable it really is. This game is ridiculously addicting and had a strong impact on city building games of its genre. 

Simcity 4 is a city building simulator that is targeted towards all audiences, unless managing business or cities isn't your thing, I haven't really met anyone out there that doesn't like city building. In this game, you must create a city by zoning Residential, Commercial and Industrial zones to increase your income through Tax paying. While you do this, you must also provide them with healthcare, education, safety (police & fire departments), utilities (such as power, water and Sanitation) and transport. Its a system that works really well with no particular end goal other than staying out of the bankruptcy zone and trying to get to commercial skyscrapers as best as possible. This game really opens your eyes to managing financial income as it is important you are spending on the right resources and making a profit while doing so. I think this is the main strength of simcity 4 in how it manages the way business is done and it works very dam well. This is why it is addicting as there is always something new to improve, something new to help give you more income and it will keep you coming back no matter what.

The first simcity game I played was 3000 and when I played it I was really young and didn't know what I was doing. For those who played 3000 and 3000 Unlimited/UK edition first, it is agreeable that 3000 was good before playing simcity 4. 3000 had some unique features but the issue with it is if you go back to it now, its difficult to manage things and mechanics aren't as good as they are in simcity 4. Its like the major difference between Hitman 2 silent Assassin and Hitman Contracts, these two games are good but Contracts substantially improved upon the gameplay.

I first played Simcity 4 Deluxe edition when I walked into a GAME shop one day when I was out with family at a shopping centre, I got it for £10 I think and when I got home, I played this game way too much. The box this game came in was very well detailed and the manual was perfect. I loved the game so much. After all those years, in 2018 I think it was I bought Simcity 4 deluxe edition on steam and its still dam timeless. I play this game to relax sometimes but other times I'll bang it out and try my best at it. Its just addicting like it was before.

The expansion rush hour introduced more mechanics to the game like the U-drive it mode which is incredibly unique as it turns simcity 4 into a GTA like game where you drive in your own cities. You can drive cars, helicopters and UFOS. If you get your hands on a tank, UFO or fighter jet in this game, you can go around destroying your cities. Its that good.

Simcity 4 also happens to have, in my opinion, the greatest soundtrack I've ever heard in a video game. Okami, Max Payne 3, Hitman Contracts, Fallout 1&2 are some games which have outstanding soundtracks but simcity 4 just has a remarkable soundtrack that I sometimes listen to casually. Jerry Martin and Co are just musical wizards who knew what they were doing when they composed this games soundtrack and it deserves wider recognition.

The sims 2, the best sims game in the series imo, had a bad soundtrack. To fix this, I use all of the music from SC4 in that game, it made the game's build buy and neighborhood music way better. Removing Jerry Martin as the main composer for The sims series was a really stupid decision. Also, if you have The sims 2, you can make your own Neighborhood terrains in simcity 4. Another great feature of Simcity 4.

Are there any issues with Simcity 4? yes. First off, you need the NAM mod to make the gameplay fair, if you don't have it, for some reason, citizens go jobless due to a messed up traffic system. NAM gets rid of this issues and improves the gameplay. 1920x1080 resolutions are not available unless you set launch options on steam and people have issues on windows 10 from what I have seen. I have windows 10 and haven't had any problems with simcity 4 whereas I had issues with The sims 2, another Maxis game.

Other than that, simcity 4 is still a legendary game everyone should play

Probably the best city building, management and simulator ever made. Extremely detailed, with lots and lots of well done prerendered graphics (the world, cars and some objects are 3D though, so it doesn't ruin the presentation at all). It's the deepest SimCity, and it's also the hardest: you'll really need to grow your city slowly and watch the taxes, or else you'll be bankrupt in no time. But if you're patient, you'll be rewarded with hours and hours of fun. It's good to be the Mayor!

There are some problems though. For example, no widescreen support and flawed transit (both can be fixed by mods). Also the game has some compatibility issues with newer systems and 64 bit Windows, so you'll have to use software mode and put some graphics options on medium and low.

Other small flaws are: the driving minigames (you can drive cars, helicopters, planes and even a tank on missions around the city), which are a bit annoying, and can become frustrating due to city traffic and sudden failures. Nowhere near as good as what Streets of SImCity did with SC2000's maps. And the other small problem is that  it tries to mimic the graphic style of The Sims, so most cities will look the same. Still, it's good that they didn't casualize the game to the max back then in 2003, trying to appeal to The Sims audience. Instead, we got the most complex SimCity to date, and I recommend it.

Well, if being the mayor of a city is your dream, well that dream has come true. Pick this game up when it goes on sale and you'll have a lot of fun.

But please note: This game is from 2003. Expect graphics bugs, optimization issues or anything along the lines of that. If you do experience problems with gameplay, remember to look online for solutions. Many people have posted solutions to this problem. Try them all before posting your negative review. If you give up on this game so easily by just giving a negative review and leaving it to rot without even trying a solution, you'll miss out on one of the best city builders ever made.

There is a category of game that is underated by most of the gamers,   The city builder simulation...
How is it posiible to make fun by building and managing a city.   Playing a political character and try to get the most vote from the citizen.

Well, this game has a way to pull you into investing a lot of hours into building a city.

At the beginning, you will have only a restricted number of options.   You will build residential area, commercial and industrial.   After a while, you'll have to manage the education and the health departement.  You'll have to create a power grid and a water supply.

A new feature in SimCity 4 is the region map.  You will be able to create cities next to each others.  They are gonna be linked to each other in many ways.

First, they are gonna share the demand in residential, commercial and industrial zones.  
Seconly, you will be able to make deal between the cities (buying electricity, selling garbage, ...)
Finaly, when you'll become a master in creating a small town,  you'll be able to create large cities of residentials area connected to other cities that will be providing power, water, garbage disposal ...

There are a lot of MOD available on Internet and a lot of fan created content.

This game may be a little old but it's still the king of it's kind in my opinion.

so, i hope there would be some games which would have better gameplay depths than this game, and better game running stabilty, and better for 64bit era, but unfortunately, no one can be better than this game, i mean gameplay.

     When I was still 11 and browsing the Steam Summer Sale of 2013 (roughly a year ago) and a game caught my attention. You see, at the time I was obsessed with what I called them Retro Games and all the history they might hold. One of my favorite games from the NES/SNES era was Simcity. Rather simple but very rewarding and interesting, the original Simcity melted away countless hours of 5th Grade (when I was still 10). So when I saw Simcity 4 on Steam for $5.99 I hade to check it out. 

     Starting out, I had a hard time figuring out what to do, this is no simple game to learn. The in-game tutorials aren't very helpful except for teaching you the bare-basics of the game. I had to watch a large amount of YouTube videos to be remotely successful. Math is also required to make effective grids whether you use unit distace or cost to measure length of roads or avenues. To even get skyscapers in your city and make it look like a city, you need extensive knowledge and mastery of the game's concepts. One example of this was when my technology teacher let us play Simcity 4 on her computers every once in a while (she's an awesome teacher by the way), most of the students ended up skipping the tutorial and spamming disasters on barren terrain. One of my friends who played through the tutorials couldn't sustain a good income and generally didn't know what he was doing.  Accessibility gets a below average 4.2 out of 10.

     On to the good bits! When I finally got things up and running the game became challenging yet addicting and rewarding, I also felt proud when my city was filled with plenty of houses, shops and factories. The GUI can be hard to learn but once you get used to it it's efficient contains everyhting it needs to and more! It's cool when your perfectly laid-out grid is functioning perfectly while also being pretty.The journey to getting your city to this state is highly enjoyable and satisfying. One of the biggest things that makes this game so much fun to play is region gameplay. This lets you connect your cities and let them share resources such as power and water. This allows certain cities to provide certain things while being kept alive by other cities while keeping them alive. Maybe a city based around power getting water from a city based around water. Being as great as it is, gameplay gets a very good 8.6 out of 10.

     In terms of visuals there's not much to cover, for a 2D game in 2003 it's pretty standard fare. Although some 3D models like cars planes, and helicopters are a nice addition. zooming in reveals a lot of little details maxis has included like a giant spinning pizza at the pizza restaurant and clotheslines in houses' backyards. skyscrapers have and other large builings have little details like a pool near the top floor. Visuals gets a strong 7.8 out of 10.

     As for the music, I'm gonna come right out and say it, this my favorite video game soundtrack of all time. The music not only fits the game fantastically any track is amazing music to listen to while doing something like schoolwork or.... other schoolwork! Yeah.... Check out the whole soundtrack on YouTube, you owe it to yourself to do so. This soundtrack a masterpiece, so it gets a well deserved 10 out of 10.

     After finding the mean of all my scores, SImcity 4 recieves a respectable 7.65 out of 10.

SC Deluxe is the pinnacle of City-Builders to date, offering a complex city simulation and a steep learning curve unlike any other. The game tutorials introduce you to the core mechanics and an overview of how to balance your finances with your cities growth, and then allows you to develop the neighbouring cities into fledgling cities. Once you have accomplished this feat, the game offers various other famous locations to build your metropolises from scratch.

Although the game suffers dated graphics, the gameplay is definately not. My only suggestion is that if you do buy Simcity 4 Deluxe, ensure you visit the modding community, who have poured years into the various mods which not only increase city variation, but offer complete rewrites of various features (Such as NAM, a transport network mod which offers unprecedented levels of control of how your city traffic flows, and how it appears)

This game is very fun and enjoyable. Improving on the great Simcity 2000, everything is classic Simcity with improved graphcs. (looks 3D enough to be considered modern, though the resolution is not the best) I consider it the last game of the classic series. The newer Simcity games deviated from the classics a bit. 

In this game you play as the mayor of a city, building roads, power plants, police stations, schools to satisfy your citizens while maintaining a balanced budget. The schools and hospitals are similar to games of its genre. The transportation options are really detailed. You will have different types of roads, railways, ferry, bus and subway. You can also connect to neighboring cities, buying garbage capacity, water, and electricity. There is a little addition that allow you to control vehicles and complete missions on your streets. I consider it a small enhancement, not really important but sometimes giving you nice bonus cash to ease the game out a bit.

The only thing I am not able to recommend is the price. $20 for a game from 2003 is not justifiable. The game goes on sale for $5 during holidays. Would recommend buying it during sales.

[b][i]SimCity 4 – Deluxe Edition[/i][/b] is a city building and management simulator. Elected Mayor over a city-to-be or existing city, manage city development by laying roads, plotting land and zoning, constructing public service buildings and maintaining financial balance as you thrive to build a megalopolis.

[b]Pros[/b]: You are giving a lot of flexibility, from zoning density to street type. As your city grow, additional selection of power plants become available, and additional needs are requested such as water treatment facilities, trains and subways, ports and airports, as well as a variety of educational establishments, health and emergency services. You have a good list of additional tax options, each with their own downside and benefits. Keep a balance between how much financing you can afford, and how much you need, to give to each of your public services (as a whole or per individual buildings). More special buildings and landmarks become available as your population rises. You can even connect your different cities togetter with your streets, highways and railroads, if they are located on neighboring tiles on the map.

[b]Cons[/b]: You are limited to determining individual land plots and zoning type, with little control on what will actually be built. You may have small shops and fast food being build on high-density commercial areas you were planning to have towering office buildings on, or maybe cheap low-cost apartment blocks will appear on residential zones you wanted luxury condos in. City interconnection requires you to actually build the neighboring city, its streets not necessarily being aligned with each other's connections. Tax revenue is hard to come by, and you'll often catch yourself speeding up time and wait years to get enough money to continue building without resorting to high-interest loans. Public service coverage is radius-based, which forces you to finance overlapping territory, or leave out coverage in-between your schools, police stations and hospitals.

[b]Verdict[/b]: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you

The amount of micro-management you have, plotting individual land plots, and the amount of effort it needs to reach actual high-density buildings, makes [i]SimCity 4 – Deluxe Edition[/i] more of a town simulator than a large urban sky-scrapper city simulator. Still, it remains a good example of the genre and the best game in its franchise.

—————————————————————————
[i][b]This was just my opinion.[/b]

[h1] Introduction [/h1] SimCity 4 is still a solid choice for a game that came out 20 years ago, although it definitely runs like a 20 year old game. I can't recommend buying this if you're not interested in minor modding, to put it bluntly: It really needs mods to be stable. 

[h3] Gameplay [/h3] Once you load the game, immerse yourself in the classic intro cutscene [spoiler] (which you should sadly disable in launch settings due to stability problems) [/spoiler] you are greeted with the Region screen, likely looking over Timbuktu, the tutorial region, one of the six ready-made regions made up of square tiles of 3 sizes, 1 sq. km, 2 sq. km, and 4 sq. km. (while you're here you should totally [u]back up[/u] the regions before you use them) 

After perusing your regions, and finding a nice tile to work on you face the God mode, where you can use powerful terraforming tools to reshape the city tile. [i]Remember the [u]backups[/u] you made?[/i] SimCity 4 does not have multiple saves of a region/tile, so you must be fairly careful to backup everything once in a while. 

After terraforming the perfect city (or inhuman crags if you so desire) you can found the city by choosing a difficulty, picking a name for your Mayor and your City and then you're off to the simulator aspect.

[h3] The real Sim was the City we along the way [/h3] Once you found your city, the game really bears it's best aspects, and it's worst. One thing you'll likely have picked up if not when terraforming but once you begin building a city is that the game is based on a orthogonal grid of tiles, which restricts the shapes and road networks you can come up with heavily, even with mods.

 After this, if you decided not to pick the tutorial city with the giant waving arrow, you'll be bombarded with a really quite spectacular, yet complex web of systems, budget this, power that, water this, pollution there, traffic here, et. c. This is not a game you can pick up for 5 minutes and do well in, unless you play very cautiously you will likely bankrupt your city several times. Now, this is not a guide but I have nothing but praise for the depth of the city simulator in this game. 

[h3] Mods [/h3] Before you buy, as I mentioned eariler, you should REALLY, and I mean REALLY get some light bug-fixing mods, and one of the best mods for SC4, the Network Addon Mod. The NAM greatly improves the traffic simulator, allocates more ram to allow for this simulation upgrade, and increases the capacity of all transit networks to allow for a more realistic city building experience. The mod also includes a ton of (optional) puzzle pieces for building much more complex transit systems. In addendum to these great community patches, there's a bustling modding community that consistently churns out all kinds of bug fixes, reworks, ploppable buildings, building types and more.

[h3] Summary [/h3] Still my favorite citybuilder in 2023, and many could say the same. If you're here because you're a city nerd, or owned it in the past I'd certainly buy it on sale even if you like playing other options like Cities: Skylines. It's truly remarkable how this gem holds up and has a dedicated modding scene so long after it's release, and abandonment by EA.

Time has passed but this game hasn't aged that much. It's a solid fun game, friendly to kids and adults as well, where you cause your own troubles in your city, and for this cutting-edge graphics aren't a priority. Even more than ten years later, the basics for city building games hasn't changed. What excites me most in SimCity 4 is doubtless the Rush Hour, where you can see the traffic in your city and makes you plan your design more carefully, combining different modes of transport and thinking about city population density. Give it a try.

having played this game to distruction, both on cd and here, I have to rate this down, its lack of cpu multi thread use makes this game slow and jumpy on big citys, its a shame because I love this play style, but having a high end cpu and not using it was a killer for me.

PLEASE NOTE, this game crashes on most systems with multi core cpu, to work around this, right click on the game then properties. under load options please paste -CPUcount:1 then apply, this worked for me, but as I said, runing this on one core is bad.

The first few cities you build can be fun, but it gets old real fast with the lack of scenarios, objectives, or other features to make each time you play more unique.
The game makes abandoned buildings occur so frequently all the time, not matter how much you address the issues that caused them to be abandoned. 
As well, once you start a city in a tile, it is almost impossible to do any landscaping because of how small and slow the landscaping tools are. 
If it is on some sort of blowout sale, it's worth a play, but definitely do not pay full price for this game.

SimCity 4 suffers from the same terrain/elevation problems that SimCIty 2000 did, but worse since you can't focus on a single square and end up destroying buildings trying to change the terrain to build things that are more annoying to build such as bridges. Game also crashes regularly. I probably won't put any more time into it.

I still have the disks for the original and expansions back in the day for this game, although I don't keep a CD player around for my PC anymore lol - not sure they'd even install now anyway. When I saw this pop up on Steam, I thought it'd be great to relive some memories considering how much time I'd spent before on it.

Some memories are best left behind. Unlike some other games that resurface with updated graphics and other features to bring them to the modern world, this version is still living back in 2000 or whenever it was. Graphic options are very limited, so if you're playing on a nice little wide screen monitor these days, well, this kind of sucks. Actually, most everything about this game graphically sucks now. Back ~20 years ago, this was great stuff. In 2020, well...

Other than the graphics, the game is like you'd expect from the old days. It plays the same and reminds me of why I liked it so much. 

I'm voting to avoid this game though, because while it is a fun stroll down memory lane, it's nothing to be excited about these days. Pick up Skylines or one of the others and enjoy the graphics more.

This game was made in 2003 and is still better than any sim city after it. This game isn't the best looking and refined up close, but for a game that is from 2003, It sure as hell does it's job well! :)

First when i saw it, i thought it was a crappy game, but then i gave it a shot, and now i think it is a fantastic game. There are many details that i havent seen in other city games, such as you can control the taxes, and your city cant become an utopia, for example if you lower the taxes then you get a lot of jobs and rich people move to your city, and if you have high taxes then you can afford renewable energy and welfare, so there is no right or wrong but only different strategies. In the beginning its a bit hard, but when you first find out how to play it then it becomes fun.

What a city simulator needs to be. No major issues with Steam version, tweaks work what I've tested, even uses Windows Documents folder to seek for plug-ins and stuff. Plenty of support, ideas, mods and what not from various internet sources. Prefers Intel processors though, used to crash regularily on my old AMD dual core way back then.

Much recommended, regardless of its age, possibly the only city simulator ever truly worth it.

EDIT: Further study revealed that the issue with crashing or sudden abortions of the game was and remains to be mainly use of multi core CPUs, not so much of the make itself. Therefore it's advisable to set the SC4's CPU affinity to single core only which significantly reduces the infamous occurences of game aborting to desktop in a zap. Still, keep saving the game progress frequently, especially before and after all major building or city tweaking sessions. Google for further details on how to set CPU affinity or to modify Steam's game start settings.

I bought this game while it was on sale, and I was curious to see how different it was compared to the MSDOS version I had back in the early 1990's. This game still has the basic easy to understand fundamentals including lots of newer things such as different types of roads, tails, and even letting you drive a selected vehicle. I played endless hours of this game as a kid and nothing has really come close to it, especially with the NAM mod. However, these days it is impossible to get it to work on most computers. As we get farther from 2003, the number of tricks you have to employ has grown. I've tried everything and finally gave up getting it to work on my machine. I got to the point where it would display the region, but clicking to start a new city would crash it. This is after getting the 4gb patch and configuring all the launch parameters. Even those that get the game to work report a ton of crashes during game play. Just shows how much this game was loved that people try so hard to keep playing it, but at this point it's too much work for a game!

It's now 2014 and this is still the best city building game out there. Sure the graphics are outdated but every other aspect of the game is superior to more modern titles. Despite being old, the graphics are still pretty decent (actually supports HD widescreen, just google it) and you'll find yourself sometimes zooming in to buildings just to admire the details. Although the game is simple to pick up, its deceptively difficult. It takes practice and planning to grow your towns into cities into bustling metropolitans. The mechanics are complex and challenging but also very rewarding to master. I have logged hundreds of hours on this game over the years creating vast multi-city regions.

Once you think you've covered all of the game, finally grew some elusive skyscrapers (or whatever your goal is), there is still a plethora of mods available to you. Whether you want real life buildings, fantasy buildings, custom regions (some created using real life data), or advanced networking/traffic capabilities, there is something for everyone. This game is now 10+ years old and there is still custom content being created on nearly a daily basis. What other game has this much longevity?

It's by far one of the best simulation games ever made in any genre.

11 years on I'm still playing. Ny hours don't reflect thousands of hours played before joining Steam. LOTS of great content at Simtropolis. The king of city builders, Works fine on Vista/WIN 7 32/64 bit. You don't need a killer video card but a quad core and lots of memory keeps it from getting bogged down as the cities grow. Anyone who claims this game sucks has no clue to how it's played. To be STILL offered on Steam after a decade says a lot about the quality of the original Maxis team. 100/100

What's with this game? You start off with a hefty sum, you lay out your city, and you're on your way. Later on, people start complaining about lack of fire coverage, or there's a crime spree in the city, or the health and education aren't up to code. And you try to convince them that it's NOT IN THE BUDGET! SURPRISE! A fire breaks out in the city and you're forced into buying a fire station. I really wish how tax per-capita works in this game, because every time I put a school down, it's like 250 a month. Put a large medical clinic in, it's around 500. And it has to scale with the population with your city or the masses will strike. Same issue with public utilities and public safety, it cost so much you have to take out a lump-sum or raise taxes so much people leave your city completely.

Playing SimCity is a lot of fun, but how did they miss the mark so badly on the technicals? 
-There's no Undo button, so if your building doesn't place right you need to spend the money to essentially rebuild it. That can be rough if youre on a budget. 
-There's no manual rotate or placement key which can be frustrating when you're trying to orientate a zone or building correctly
-Next there's no auto-save, which wouldn't be huge if it wasn't for the next problem 
-THE GAME FREQUENTLY CRASHES. So you need to go back and redo the 20 minutes or hour worth of whatever you were doing. VERY frustrating. 
-The soundtrack allows you to edit the playlist, but it doesn't tell you the name of the track you're listening to. 
-Popups will pause the game, but when you're through reading them it will revert to the speed you were running, which can be problematic if there's something time-sensitive and it goes back to high-speed. 

Also there's a shoe-horned in minigame where you drive around your city in a little car which is cute for a minute, but then it becomes tedious and annoying. Like a feature that was poorly thought out and tacked on at the last minute. Sheesh as I'm writing this review, I'm more and more shocked that this is hardly the first SimCity in the series, but it's like they didn't playtest it at all. I got this because I had the itch to play SimCity and this was the cheapest and easiest path. Now I feel like the $20 pricetag should be more like $5 or $10. It's a pretty flawed game.

Update: The crash rate is making this game unplayable. Such a shame

I played all the SimCity games from the very beginning, and SimCity 4 was a crowning achievement in the series. Sadly, however, it's just too old now. If it weren't for the folks at Simtropolis, it wouldn't have lasted as long as it did. It had a great modding community that pushed it well past its expiration. If you got SimCity 4 back in the day, then you lucked out. However, if you're new to this genre, or this game specifically, then look elsewhere.

Unless it's on sale, or you have a computer with specs and hardware from the time frame this game came out, then don't bother. Also, for me personally, SimCity died long ago, when Maxis was purchased by EA, and we all know how there's not enough time for that story.

If you want a better city simulator, check out Cities: Skylines. While I'm not a fan of having to buy 20 DLC packages, and don't get me started on Season Passes, Cities: Skylines does the City Simulation genre justice and scratches an age-old itch.

Not even 5 minutes into the game it already suffers crashing, graphical issues, and other gamebreaking things. This is a shame as I have been looking forward to playing this game for a few months now. It wasn't what I expected of it. The IOS version of simcity (Simcity Deluxe) is far better than this game, with some exceptions, and it is also cheaper than this.

- On my machine after installing (windows 11) text input fields were not functioning at all. (Can't name city)
- There's no option to invert mouse scroll or change interface controls. They're a little bit clunky.
- The number of gameplay settings that can be adjusted appears to be 5. There's some graphics settings.
- Overall the interface feels clumsy 
- A top down view might give a bit better oversight.

The actual content of the game might be alright, but I didn't quite get that far. The interface was a bit uncomfortable. Overall, I think it feels like a clumsily done city management game. You kind of have a certain set of things you're probably expecting to do, and there's a take on most of those things in the game. But the way things are done is just kind of not there. My first impression was that after starting the game, the text input fields didn't work. It was not possible to write the name of the city. Then I tried to create the city, and the mouse look system was hold right mouse button and drag, but I'm used to the inverted version of that, and it's not possible to toggle inverted scroll for that. That's just a basic thing that has done been done in a thousand games, and there's usually an option in the settings to toggle that on or off. So when I looked into the settings, there was 5 items you could change. That seemed unusual. I think it's probably that the core game is fine, but the interface is not. Based on the first 26 minutes after which I felt this probably isn't working out for me.

SimCity 4 was lots of fun back in the day, but reality is that the game didn't age well.

When compared to Cities Skylines, this game has better mechanics, despite its bugs.
Sound track is better in my opinion and budget management style is more direct to the point and intuitive.

Building the city's road network system is another story.
I don't consider neither this or CS good in this side.
Both games have mods to help you, but it's quite a nightmare to get something done right.
Simtropolis is the main mod page for SimCity 4, and you can get Network Addon Mod to give a try.

In terms of graphics, this game already shows its age, but the biggest issue is the game UI, which can't be upscaled.
You can run this game with Widescreen Resolution and SweetFX, however the UI will get smaller, as the resolution gets higher.

My best recommendation, if you are running it in a 1080p monitor is to use the following launch parameters for the game:
-CustomResolution:enabled -r1600x900x32 -f -d:opengl -intro:off -CPUCount:1 -CPUPriority:high

Then add SweetFX to improve image quality by dropping the contents of the zip file below in your ...\SimCity 4 Deluxe\Apps folder:
https://mega.nz/file/s4cizA5T#xjHtxjvEfP9OpRskXiDsR6jN6ekQ-GFBwnFv6RbZdjY

If you want to edit SweetFX parameters, open the SweetFX_Settings.txt file inside the ...\SimCity 4 Deluxe\Apps\SweetFX folder and change parameters to your liking.

Note: I've written a more detailed guide for this:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3258173631

The game realistically simulates city building with systems such as traffic, air pollution, education levels, water pollution, and many more factors that add up to a realistic city building experience. I have played this game for 4 years and I'm still exploring many of the built-in options. For example, you can increase the demand for city services (which are represented as industrial demand, residential demand, and commercial demand) if you connect two separate cities on a map via a road connection. This game has many features which make playing a very comprehensive and fulfilling experience, with many buildings and features that can be unlocked via game play, such as an Area 51 base that can be unlocked once the player's city reaches a certain level of education and high-tech industrial buildings.

SimCity 4 Deluxe is a classic city-building simulation game that, unfortunately, falls short in many ways. Despite its pedigree, the game suffers from a range of issues that make it frustrating and unenjoyable to play.

One of the most significant problems with the game is its steep learning curve. The game's mechanics are complex and unintuitive, making it difficult to understand how to build and manage a successful city. Even after hours of gameplay, it can be challenging to get a handle on the game's many systems and mechanics.

The game's graphics and performance are also lackluster, even for a game that was released over 15 years ago. The graphics are dated, with low-resolution textures and blocky models that fail to create an immersive city-building experience. The game's performance is also subpar, with long loading times and frequent crashes and freezes.

Another issue with the game is its lack of depth and variety. Despite the game's many systems and mechanics, there is a noticeable lack of content that makes the game feel repetitive and dull after a few hours of playtime. There are only a limited number of building types and options, making it difficult to create a unique and varied city.

Finally, the game's AI is poorly implemented, with the simulation failing to provide a realistic and engaging experience. The AI is unpredictable, often making bizarre decisions that make no sense and can lead to frustrating gameplay.

Overall, SimCity 4 Deluxe is a disappointing entry in the city-building simulation genre, with a steep learning curve, lackluster graphics and performance, a lack of depth and variety, and poorly implemented AI. While the game may have been groundbreaking when it was released over 15 years ago, it has not aged well and is not worth the investment for modern players.

Twice I have built cities of 20,000 residents, only for the game to crash, and the area on the map to be untouched when I return.

SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is a timeless city-building game that continues to impress players. It offers a deep and complex experience, allowing players to create and manage every aspect of a thriving metropolis. Despite its older graphics, the attention to detail is remarkable, and the game features a dynamic day-night cycle. The simulation engine provides a challenging and rewarding gameplay experience, where players must balance the needs of their citizens while managing resources and handling unexpected events. The Rush Hour expansion pack adds transportation management options. The game also benefits from a dedicated modding community, offering a wealth of user-generated content. Overall, SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is a must-play for fans of the genre, providing countless hours of strategic and creative enjoyment.

[b]Mayor Rocks According to City Blocks[/b]

SimCity 4 Deluxe is a classic city-builder game that offers players the chance to build and manage their own metropolis. SimCity 4 has the best interactive UI of any city builder I've seen, though I might be blinded by nostalgia. The game features memorable city advisors, each with their own unique personality and expertise, which offer valuable advice to players and help guide them through the complex task of running a city. Additionally, the game's fitting soundtrack adds to the overall immersive experience.

However, one major flaw in the game is the development desire system, which can be frustrating and economically damaging to a city. The unintuitive zoning demands can lead to a city's development being stunted or even reversed, which can be a frustrating experience for players who aren't familiar with SimCity-type city builders which rely on the player somewhat gaming the system to incite rapid growth.

Despite its issues, SimCity 4 Deluxe is still a great game to me that has offered a lot of nostalgia-driven enjoyment. Its classic graphics and the manual drive missions provide a unique gameplay experience that I haven't seen replicated in any other city builder to date, and the memorable advisors add a lot of personality to the game. SC4D is a solid choice for anyone looking for a classic city-building game, especially for older hardware that won't play nice with the newer titles. The game still goes on sale semi-frequently for massive amounts, and I'd recommend picking it up then.

Definitly worth the price. This is one of the best town management/building games I have seen so far. It is way better than the newer one. Although it does have it's problems. This game is simply the best city building game you can buy right now. It is over 10 years old, and it is still better than the new SimCity. It might be difficult to some, but that's the fun in it. After all your hardwork, you can watch your beautiful city growand thrive. There is not better feeling than that.

Seriously, this is the BEST city builder.

Still my favourite city builder as of 2020, if not by much.

The modding is by far the biggest advantage. There's both tons of existing content and plenty of ways to modify the game to one's own liking.

And while Skylines has that too, what keeps me coming back to this game more often is how easy and rewarding it is to jump in and start building. It loads almost immediately and growth is fast and visually impressive. So I keep coming back to try out new strategies and layouts.

There's also the fact that this game has the second best soundtrack ever, after SimCity 3000.

The game's main downside is the notorious infinite commuter bug, which severely hampers regional play - one of the core features of the game and what would have been its main draw otherwise.

The other major disadvantage is the lack of resources beyond power/water/garbage. All industry is essentially generic and always exports. Nobody consumes anything and there are no imports or internal freight traffic. This aspect is what makes Cities XL one of my other contenders for favourite city builder.

I got this during Steam Summer Sale 2017. Like many of the people who play, I had SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition on CD. I spent about probably 8000+ hours since I started as an 8 year old. Ah, back when I couldn't find the damn registration code but a friend of mine always lent me his. Good times. I got this game after a certain update in either Windows 7 or 8 disallowed something that SimCity 4 on CD requires to play. Since this is entirely different from the CD version, it works tremendously well.

If you're into graphics and all that for simulation games, you might as well throw that view out the window. For a game that was released nearly 14 years ago, this was at the top of its game and honestly, it still is. The gameplay is fun as hell, with the tank being the most strongest vehicle (until you crash into 100 tanks and log trucks). I prefer this more than the new SimCity that came out 4 years ago(?) any time.

How you play SimCity 4 is really up to you, though. You could either play with the standard and already implemented buildings, or you could go to Simtropolis and download mods for SimCity to make yours look more realistic. There is nothing wrong with playing with either, however, one disadvantage about playing with custom mods: The more you have, the longer it takes to load a region, and in a related topic...

Depending on your computer, you may crash numerous times. The game does take a lot of demand on the computer, but again, this varies. Sometimes you'll still be running the game, even if you have already quit. I do suggest reading the compatibility stats for your computer and the game.

Overall, still a great game and a lot of nostalgia value for me. Give this game a try!

this game series I was told was the cream of the crop for city builder sims, I found the game very infuriating to play. had to spend more time shifting through menu and menu. no way to track common issues and expenses without have to switch between up to 6 different menus to see individual stats for buildings would have like to track thing in a more streamlined fashion for general ease of control. custom regions option is  not even well thought out as you have to edit each tile individually to create a map. speed up function was pointless as as soon as there was a crisis it would pause the game, as soon as you closed the pop up would speed through 2 more months before you could fix the issue causing drastic drop in mayor rating. felt like game was build to be played in 1x speed to promote longer play times. game felt over bad compared to its 2000 counterpart which feels like a much better game which is sad. I had a positive review of this game but I changed my mind.

-There's hardly any QoL mechanics we're used to now.

-I HATE how 1 small ditzy fire pauses the entire game.

-If your city goes without power for a few days on accident your entire population will disappear like they were never there and it takes forever to rebuild it (I mean when your power cuts out in your city it sucks but you don't see 75% of the population leaving within 30 minutes of the power being out, calling it quits).

-City growth can be confusing as hell sometimes and makes no sense.

-Zoning can be a PITA as you have to fight and juggle which direction it faces.

-You need to have those annoying popups on and when you have a big city they pop up every 30 seconds to minute, if you have them off you can lose half of your city to something stupid.

-Crashes sometimes.

The only thing I like about this game is the region mode but other than that this game is a nightmare to play.

Maybe next time you should think before getting windows 8 and expecting it to run a 10+ year old game. Seriously though this is a great game, a classic if you will. Pretty sure they have it on iPad's now as well so yeah... Go play it. 10/10

 These frustratations led me to give up on the game soon after playing it.

Unintuitive, clunky, poor interface, boring, lack of personality, just plain not fun. Any one of these things would spell the death knoll for a game, but SimCity nails them all. To make matters even worse, it doesn't like windows 7 or 8, and will fight you to the death on anything past XP. And it will win.

See, the sad part here is I actually *LIKE* city-builder games. Tycoon series? Pretty good! Tropico 4? Awesome! SimCity 1? Win. Afterlife? Epix Win. Sim City 4? Eh... mediocre at best?

So what went wrong? How did SC4 fail it up so badly?

I think the biggest problem was they lost sight of what made sim city games fun... the city building and the balancing of economy against people's desires. These things all exist in Sim City, and they've been inflated to a status of excessive grandeur, but that may be where the problem is: too much of a good thing.

Yes, there's lots of buildings, tons of them in fact... but it mostly just turns into a bogged down mess of junk to sort through if you want to have even a minimally running city at all. Instead of having a reasonable juggling act of a few major things your people need to be happy, tempered by a limited economy, Sim City 4 just throws all caution to the wind and piles on heaps of useless busywork. It's not even interesting construction; a good chunk of it's underground where you'll never even see it anyway. It's just there to waste money and make building the city more realistic but less interesting.

If I wanted real I wouldn't be playing a game.

Tropico 4... is a nice balance. It tosses the balls at you one at a time, slowly ramping up the difficulty and keeping the game entertaining and interesting the whole way. Sim City 4 piles too much needless crap on all at once that provides a remarkably harsh learning curve, for a minimal reward at the end.

Sim games have typically struck a wonderful balance in the past between the work and reward aspects, and gave you the tools needed to quickly and efficiently manage your little slice of heaven (or both heaven and hell if playing afterlife =P ). SC4 just kinda drops the ball (to maintain the juggling metaphor from the previous paragraph) by giving slow, irritating, clunky tools which technically get the job done, but are a pain to use and not very fun.

Toss in the severe glitches, and absolute, seething hatred SC4 has for pretty much anything above WinXP, and you may as well not even bother considering it. There's simply better games out there... Cities XL for the obsessive compulsive realistic city builder, Tropico 4 for those who want a great storyline and awesome gameplay with proper balance of being just right a la goldilocks... and afterlife or sim city classic if you're nostalgic.



Final Verdict:

SC4 really just doesn't have a place in the city builder market. Anything it does, other games do better. Much, much better. Game-breaking glitches don't help it's argument, either.


Overall Score: About 40%. If you can get it to run, it's not really BAD... it's just not particularly good, and you can do better for lower cost, anyway. The music's pretty epic, though.

Holy crap this is ancient. It seems to be a good game for it's time. I remember Simcity 2000 and 3000 with nostalgia goggles on. This one has an elaborate multi-city system, which seems like it would have been a good idea. There was love and care poured into it for sure. I liked that I quickly discovered you can custom make a few sims and move them into the city. 

However, I simply cannot get past it's age. No scroll speed adjustment, no 16:9 resolutions, no diagonal scrolling, no viewing the stats of buildings or adjusting them when you click on them, etc. I cant even tell what the symbols over abandoned buildings mean half the time. I only played for about 10 minutes, but it was long enough to know that I've moved out of the stone age and discovered fire and the wheel since it was made. I won't be getting a refund, as I bought it on sale, but I'll likely never open it again.

TLDR: If you can handle bad controls and a not-so-intuitive design, this game might be awesome. Otherwise I would say purchase something newer. Cities Skylines is okay if you can deal with the brain-dead traffic AI, and Simcity 2013 is good if you can tolerate the bugs and don't mind never using megatowers. Spend your money there instead

After a 20 year break, I figured this summer it would be a good time to get back into the SimCIty franchise with 2003's SimCity 4.

This is one of those games where its greatest strength happens to also be its greatest weakness. The game is incredibly deep, which to a SimCity enthusiast must be the ultimate dream. For entry level players it is however a substantial barrier to entry. There is a tutorial, although I felt it could have been a little more in depth beyond the basics it does go over.

But once you are rolling, you are in command of all the tools you'll ever need to run your city. If you're like me, you'll become attached to your city as its very own life-form, and will want to nurture it along in its development. 

And since this is an 8 year old title, it was a nice surprise to have a game today that isn't innundated with achievements and ceaseless updates.

I grabbed this game hoping to relive my days from playing SimCity 2000. It's total garbage. No matter what strategies I tried, my cities all failed. Even if I, by some miracle, could manage to provide sims with all their desires, and balance the budget, within just 12 months (game time) my city would suddenly decline, go into debt, and fail.

After some research, I found out there are a lot of quirky algorithms dictating how you can play, if you want to succeed. Many people stated you could NOT separate zoning in your cities, but had to build zones intermingled with each other. Utility stations, even clean energy/water stations, age, even if there is no indication, and require bulldozing and replacement. Trees actually affect how well you do.....Trees.....Really. To top it all off, forget building grids to help manage traffic. Grids promote fast growth, but somehow lead to sims then taking only 1 or 2 streets, clogging the transit lines, and ultimately choosing to abandon your city.

Nothing about this game is straight forward. Nothing you do to meet your sims wants works, short of hours and hours of area micro-managing. And, again, even if you somehow succeed, you then almost instantly face changes that make no sense, lead to your city being abandoned, and your budget ultimately failing.

I believe that Sim City 4 is the greatest city building game that has ever been created. The graphics are way ahead of its time for a game made in 2003 and they are actually realisitc. The buildings look like real buildings, the cars look like real cars, and etc. You would think that todays city biulding games are improving on grpahics but they and other genre games really aren't. People now adays think that going to a graphics system that looks like a cartoon (City Skylines) is improvement, but its not, period. Though a positve is that it does have smoothed edges for those apple lovers. (1) Graphics are realistic and pretty dang good. SC4 also has more to offer, more unique buildings such as real world landmarks and gift buildings. (2) More Stuff. The management system and zoning of SC4 is also more indepth as there are I beleive 12 different distinict types of zones that you manage. There are 3 main zones that you lay out based on density, Commercial, Industrial, and Residential, but within those, you control the taxes of 12 types of zones or groups of people within those main three. For instance, Industrial has 4 types of businesses that you virtually control by rasing and lowering the tax rates for each one seperately. You have Agriculture, Dirty, Manufacturing, and High Tech Industry and the Tax rates that you set for each of those businesses will effect how each of them is demanded in the city. A high demand in manufacturing for instance, means that manufacturing businesses will set up shop in your city until the demand resets itself. (3) More Management and Even More Stuff. The only thing that I can see might turn people away for a legitimate reason is the fact that SC4 does have a square grid pattern, but even though it has a grid pattern, you can still make roads and etc go diagnally. Balance this small negative with the Good Graphics and there is no reason you should not get this game. No debate, there is  more to do in Sim City 4 than City Skylines, more management, more building, more everything. Every city-building game lover should get this Classic and Legendary game!

This game would of deserve to be a great sandbox game if it weren’t for the CONSTANT CRASHES that this game tends to do! This game has not aged well, I had a boxed copy 20 years ago and picked it up because it was 90% off.  All you do is plop down a bunch of zones and then give them services once they complain about it.  There is next to no challenge except maybe restarting an empty city about 2 times to figure out to leave space for future highways and railroads or perhaps which type of power plant or water pump to buy that are cost effective at the start of the game.  After that you will win every time.

Also, 20 years later, the game still runs like sh-t with 50x the CPU power, occasional crashes and there's no autosave.  I don't care about mods, when you have to install community assumed required mods to make the game PLAYABLE you know you are in the wrong territory.  It doesn't matter if mods can solve the horrible lag because the base game is just plop down zones and occasionally some services.  Houses will travel clear across the city to go to work but other houses literally right next to them will forever say they are without a job and will not evolve.  The mechanic where the game saves you from bankruptcy by magically offering basically free money via shady deals like having a military base for extra money a month is just bad game design.  It tries to make it sound like they thought it out by making the surrounding areas undesirable but any 6 year old can figure out, just put them all in a corner of the city and leave a big gap so nothing is affected, so it's basically a mini little cheat code.  You can also just spam loans (they let you take out WAY too much) and instantly spend 100% of the loan on new zones, you make way way too much money even on top of the loan interest.  Also, the fire fighting mechanic is absolutely stupid and just wastes time, I quite literally think they were trying to make up an excuse to prevent players from just walking away and letting the game run so they can skip to what little fun can be had when you get money again.  Thanks to all of this most of the time you zoom in on unused space in your city (so that the game runs fast) and press the highest simulation speed button until you hit a fire.  If you do that work you now have bought yourself the fantastic ability to plop down more zones!  Such fun.

For a real and challenging city builder, check out Impressions Studios City Building Series, like Caesar 3, Pharaoh, or Zeus.  You don't need mods to play those except they have source ports now to play them at hi-res, at least none of those mods change anything about the base game, meanwhile everyone defends this and insists mods are part of the game because it is so bad.  Playing SimCity after playing any of those makes SimCity feel like a console or mobile game for little kids.  Most of the other reviews are nostalgia goggles which is pretty telling.  SimCity was always dumb there was just nothing better at the time that would have been sold at Walmart  (Just kidding, Impressions City Builders were there at the time and better)

I can't believe how many people gave this game positive reviews.  It looks NOTHING LIKE the game depicted in the images.  The graphics are halfway to terrible, and the usability is in the toilet.  I messed with it for two hours, and finally decided it just couldn't be worth it.  I spent twenty minutes trying to make a highway, and none of the pieces would connect, no matter what I did about on-ramps and ground-this and clover-leafs-that.  I even went through half of the tutorials before I played.  Worse than this is how often you build an area that builds itself streets that aren't connected to existing streets or builds plots that can't access a road.  And can you just bulldoze them?  No.  I also wasted fifteen minutes trying to make the land appropriate for a beach—seriously?  Why not have the beach auto-teraform if you're going to make it so picky?  Add in the screaming idiot always calling to you to try his stupid roadway adventure (i.e., boring arrow-tapping exercise), and you have an intolerable game.  I'm so disappointed.

Who wrote these other reviews?  Everyone made it sound like we finally had a proper Sim City game again.  I hate to say it, but we just don't.

Ok, had the game long enough now, so time for a review. PS, this is a base game review, as I do not believe that mods should be the saving grace for any game as if that is the case; it reflects a major failure in the core game.

Whilst I wouldn't say it is a terrible game, I would feel dishonest in giving it a whole hearted recommendation.

The graphics were a nice improvement over it's predacessors and the terrain customization feature was a brilliant idea. Those were the things that I liked about it. What I did not like about it was... well, almost everything else. 

1) I hated the way you could just click and drag to build a city area, though that is probably just me, I get a great amount of satisfaction in tweking every minor detail myself. I feel that alone took out a lot of immersion from game play.

2) The absolute worst feature, I think, personally was the city zones. You could have different sized zones that you could micro manage until they're full, if you wanted to. If memory serves, zone sizes could range from 1 Kilometre upto 10 kilometres. And whilst the concept was interesting, it just felt like I was managing multiple cities, rather than one big cities individual zones. Cities: Skylines pulls this off wayyyy better. It also took the AI neighbour cities away from the player. Which I thought was a great feature, the way it was implimented previously.

3) Ok, so there are a few more things I liked about it. I liked the interface. Was easy to understand and navigate. and I liked that you could get up close and personal with your own city by driving inside it and performing missions, getting money and rating boosts as a perk.

4) The things I like about it though does not make up for the things I dislike about it. It is monotonous and in the long term, boring. It feels like a massive downgrade from simcity3000 and I WISH they'd have put that game into steam, rather than THIS one as SimCity3000 was by far the better. Inmy most honest but humble opinion, that is.

To start with the game seemed fun and the issues minor however the following issues cause me to not recommend the game 
1) Crashing frequently, loosing the last half hour - 3 hours of effort (as inevitably I have not saved since the beginning of the session)
2) I find the tax system both too simple and too controlled - Not able to tax anything more than 20% and not able to do tiered taxing, e.g. first $100  earned per month is tax free, then the next $100 is at a low tax rate, then a medium tax rate and anything over $500/month is at a high tax rate. Also having people leave due to high tax rates. Not sure if this is how it works in America but in England everyone has a personal allowance (currently approx £12,000) then you are taxed at a basic rate of 20% for anything up to approx £46,000 then a higher rate of 40% up to £150000 and anything above that is taxed at 45%, I understand that this is a game so can't be overly complex but not being able to charge more than 20% tax is prohibitive and having the tiered tax would be more realistic.
3) There are other areas where it would be helpful to set the rates but I can't see where to do so - such as changing how much toll booths charge and saying that certain roads or streets can only be used by certain vehicle types. The traffic also does not move in a logical manner, I will have a street with a dead end at the end of it and big lorries go down it only to turn around at the end and return the way they came.
There were a few other things which were causing minor issues but those are the main ones, over all I am pleased I brought this in the sale and so didn't waste too much money on it.

SimCity 4, in case this is your first time ever seeing a computer, is a tycoon/city building game where you allocate land into Residential, Commercial and Industrial zones, build roads and power infrastructure, and encourage people to come live in your city, watching their buildings grow and the streets fill with bustling traffic. 

Fantastic idea and SimCity 4 is arguably the best of all of these games for the simple fact that every city building game to follow this has been greedily, evilly butchered, with the majority of content stripped out and then sold back to the customers as massively overpriced DLC.  SimCity 5's $10 Marina addon (just so you can have boats) and the community backlash was one of the factors that may have lead to EA's CEO at the time resigning.    Cities Skylines is even worse than Sim City 5 for anti-consumer greedy DLC gouging.

So, why am I not throwing this one the thumbs up it once truly deserved?  It's simply too dated now.  There's no widescreen support.  There's no HD support.  It's a little buggy and badly optimised, it doesn't run so great under Windows 10.  The game will never be updated to properly support modern PCs.  It's really a shame. 

Now cracks a noble heart.  Good night, sweet prince, and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.
