Get into the game and you are plagued by constant pop ups, to the point where you cannot concentrate on being a mayor for ordering fire engines to put out fires. The minute you start placeing government buildings like schools all your staff start striking.

The easiest way to progress and have a working city is to use lots of low density zones, power them with wind and water them with towers, have no agriculture, no public buildings, no transport or utilities. Your scumbag city will sit there and generate a nice wee income and you can tinker at the edges.

But try and build a thriving metropolis and be prepared to be bothered out of your wits by endless advisors.

For a slice of old school Sim City try the iPad version. Much better.

**SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition Review**

**Overview:**
SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is a comprehensive city-building simulation game developed by Maxis and published by Electronic Arts. Released in 2003, this edition includes the base game SimCity 4 and the Rush Hour expansion pack, which adds several new features and improvements.

**Gameplay:**
SimCity 4 Deluxe allows players to build and manage a city, from zoning land for residential, commercial, and industrial use to managing the city's budget, services, and infrastructure. Players can oversee transportation systems, utilities, and public services, ensuring that their city runs smoothly and efficiently. The Rush Hour expansion introduces new transportation options, including one-way streets, avenues, and the ability to control individual vehicles with the U-Drive-It feature.

**Pros:**

1. **Depth and Complexity:**
   - SimCity 4 offers a deep and complex simulation experience. Players must balance the needs of their citizens with the city's budget, manage resources, and plan for growth and development.

2. **Detailed Graphics and Sound:**
   - The game features detailed graphics that bring the city to life, with realistic animations and vibrant cityscapes. The sound design complements the visuals, providing an immersive experience.

3. **Customization and Modding:**
   - The game's strong modding community has produced a vast array of custom content, from new buildings and landmarks to gameplay tweaks and enhancements. This extends the game's longevity and replayability.

4. **Rush Hour Expansion:**
   - The expansion pack adds significant value, with new transportation options, scenarios, and the U-Drive-It feature, which allows players to take control of vehicles within their city.

**Cons:**

1. **Steep Learning Curve:**
   - The game's complexity can be daunting for new players. Understanding the intricacies of city management, zoning, and infrastructure planning requires time and patience.

2. **Performance Issues:**
   - SimCity 4 can be resource-intensive, especially on larger cities, leading to performance issues on older or less powerful systems.

3. **Lack of Tutorial:**
   - The game lacks a comprehensive tutorial, which can make it challenging for newcomers to grasp the mechanics and features without external help or guides.

4. **Dated Interface:**
   - The user interface can feel dated and cumbersome compared to more modern city-building games. Navigating menus and managing city elements can be less intuitive.

**Conclusion:**
SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is a classic in the city-building genre, offering a rich and detailed simulation experience. Despite its age, it remains a favorite among fans for its depth, customization options, and the added features of the Rush Hour expansion. While it may have a steep learning curve and some performance issues, dedicated players will find it a rewarding and immersive city-building experience. If you enjoy complex simulations and city planning, SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is well worth playing.

SimCity4 is a legacy game that still has a lot of love from its loyal community. If you're looking for support, you can find it here on Steam or on www.simtropolis.com, where there are a lot of mods available and a lot of still-loyal fans of a great game. 

Yes, the graphics are dated and official support has ended a long time ago. But the game is a classic. It is easy to get lost in its simplicity. If you're looking for a good city simulator that was only upstaged by City:Skylines, than this is for you!

[h1]Summary[/h1]
The OG old school city builder simulator that still holds up.

[b]Pros[/b]
+ Fun sandbox
+ Simple complexity

[b]Cons[/b]
- Outdated graphics
- Tinkering required to run properly

[h1]Overview[/h1]
Sim City 4 is an old school city builder simulator that will likely appeal more to the older generation as it has dated graphics and is more of a nostalgia play for many, though it cannot simply be regarded as an outdated city simulator as it is probably still one of the best in the genre outdated as it is.
Most will probably also notice that the game uses a lot of the (older) The Sims UI and even the character models for your advisors as this was one of the games made by the original Sims developers, Maxis the kings of simulators of their time.

[b]NOTE[/b]
Do check out [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/SimCity_4#Essential_improvements]PCGamingWiki[/url] to ensure you get some patches and mods to run the game and / or improve the game for an even better experience.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
As a city builder simulator you will be building a fully functioning city dealing with all its needs such as water and power, maintaining the happiness of your populace, and also balancing the city economics with taxes and commercial and business sectors.
It sounds rather complex but overall not actually too difficult to play as the goal is to simply make a city, you can make a nice little one or attempt to make gigantic metropolises but in essence the game is a simulator so there isn't really any winning conditions. You are also not really limited to playing the game properly as there are some funny options you are able to do such as trigger disasters just to see the chaos. There is also drive mode that puts you in a car letting you drive within your city streets or off them if you so choose, this feature likely came from one of their other game Streets of SimCity if anyone remembers that.

[hr][/hr]
If you find my reviews useful do follow my [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/11028547-Dods-Echo-Chamber/]Curator[/url][/b] page for more!

I got the game to work in windows 7 but it sometimes will crash. reading that it has issues with windows 10 and 11 after the start screen intro. i found a solution to try. place this in the properties. I read and tried similar codes but this worked, may have to do with the -d:soft. give this a try if you got windows 11 and it crashes on startup.

-d:soft -intro:off -CPUCount:1 -w -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32

also you cant close the window to exit the game, you need to stop is on steam. trying to close it on the taskbar fails too. this is why I run it in (-w) window mode so you can access the Steam app on the taskbar.

SimCity 4 in 2024 still holds up as a competent and impressive city builder and one of EAXis' most tremendous accomplishments to date. With a few tweaks to run smoothly on modern systems there is a wealth of opportunity to build and develop thriving regions with millions of residents. Mods are still being updated to this day, which stands to show not only the dedication of a still lively fanbase, but the game's merits to still be experienced today. The graphics are charming and well done and manage to not look outdated for a game released over two decades ago. The mechanics are suitably detailed and complicated but not convoluted to grasp, which is a balancing act not many titles manage to handle. I'd definitely recommend giving it a go if you haven't played, or coming back to it if like me, you've had a long history with the franchise but haven't found the time or motivation to play in a while. I've sunk hundreds of hours into SimCity 4 since the mid-2000s and I'm confident I'll continue well into the future for as long as it continues to work on modern systems. Being available on Steam for a decent price, you have nothing to lose! Come back and enjoy a product of EA's golden era today.

SimCity 4: Balanced the budget with nuclear readiness!

City builders are to me what heroin is to a normal person, and in some aspects they're at least marginally more affordable for me. And much healthier. But the issue with city builders has always been logistically trying to improve on the basic form factor. SimCity to SimCity 2000, then to 3000 and the various divergent evolution paths that go everywhere from there. Roots going to PopTop's Tropico to the Caesar/Pharaoah Games. And after so many years of zoning out to Skylines, I was feeling the itch. The urge, the monkey on the back demanding I waste another afternoon erecting a massive tower of terrible skyscrapers.

And then I remembered I had SimCity 4, had failed to make a city operate like an absolute weenus and then decided to do it properly. And then it took me one slightly ambient soundtrack and it hit me. That and then immediately getting BODIED by this game requiring you to actually budget versus huffing paint thinner and taking out loans with no consequence. This is that dreaded missing link, that Colossal ran with. 

The subsequent games in the franchise, both by Maxis and by Colossal really undersell the city builder. It's really easy to set something up to be a money printer in Skylines, meanwhile SimCity 4 will throw you and your administration under the bus if you don't do your job right. Everything in this game is the correct delicate balance of things, which is my excuse for not building schools until we're at least 2k in tax profits. Everything must be laid out perfectly to make sure you can actually build some level of office space, otherwise you're going to make your city look like Extended Baltimore. 

Plus you do have the silly but neat feature of forcing your Sims 1 characters to live in your dystopia, which is useful to help gauge the individual issues of the city. You think it's a gimmick, but I routinely have used them like some sort of informant network. Works better than the advisors who are helpful, and routinely yell at me for streets I'm refusing to fix. Realistically I need the suffering of my people.

The only gripe I can ever lay at the foot of this game is the stability issues, which after two decades have been pretty reasonably patched out over and over again. Go dig around the forums, stab the fan patches into ancient code and you should be relatively good to go. And you get to have all of the city building fun without the legally mandatory 30 Paradox DLC's that take your regularly priced indie game and make it cost more than anything else.
Downloaded this for a dose of nostalgia and was surprised by how intricate the game mechanics actually were. Some bits here and there are a bit janky, but overall it makes a really fun time-sink.

The game is a very realistic city builder with a nice look and style to it. the music is impeccable, never gets old and really gives a good vibes to the overall game. Although the game is very difficult. Been playing it for years and still haven't learned how to make giant sky scrappers let alone a functional city lol. But that's also where the fun can be, in the challenge.

The soundtrack alone is a 10/10. It saddens me to have seen the SimCity franchise alongside Maxis studios disappear as they made some pretty good games.

SimCity 4 Deluxe, released in 2003 by Maxis, is a city-building simulation game that takes the helm of urban planning to new heights. As the mayor, players have the responsibility of designing, building, and managing a bustling metropolis. The Deluxe edition incorporates the Rush Hour expansion, introducing new features and challenges, making it a comprehensive experience for city-building enthusiasts.

What I like about the game:

SimCity 4 Deluxe stands out for its intricate simulation mechanics. It delves deep into the complexities of city management, offering a realistic portrayal of urban dynamics. From zoning decisions to managing budgets, every aspect contributes to the city's growth or decline. I love building train tracks that go round and watch Sims going on a circle train ride.

Despite its age, SimCity 4 Deluxe boasts charming graphics that capture the essence of a growing city. It has a vintage 2000's PC game look that makes it quite enjoyable. The isometric view allows for a detailed look at your creation. The soundtrack, composed by Jerry Martin, adds a delightful touch, enhancing the gaming experience. Basically more aesthetically vintage looking than Lethal Company or Baldur's Gate 3 so = better.

The game provides an extensive array of building options, allowing players to create unique cityscapes. The ability to customize terrain, implement various transportation systems, and design intricate neighborhoods fosters creativity and replayability. I personally like the burger restaurants they look like they cook absolutely awful stuff.

To spice things up a bit, SimCity 4 Deluxe presents players with a variety of challenges and scenarios. From natural disasters to economic crises, these events keep the gameplay engaging and provide opportunities for problem-solving. Actually this is annoying but I guess some people like challenges like speedrunning a loli simulator or else.

Not to mention, the game has a dedicated modding community that has extended its longevity. A plethora of user-created content, ranging from new buildings to complete overhauls, adds an extra layer of depth and variety. Little silly goofy mods can be added to have a good laugh on a tuesday evening.

Stuff I did not enjoy tho:

SimCity 4 Deluxe is not the most accessible game for newcomers. The intricate mechanics might overwhelm players initially, and the lack of comprehensive in-game tutorials can hinder the learning process. I still don't understand sh*t at this game. I hate my dumb self.

The multiplayer aspect is limited, especially when compared to more modern city-building games. Collaborative or competitive multiplayer features are minimal, limiting the social aspect of the game. I would personnally love a split screen mode and a friend to play with.

The user interface feels somewhat dated, lacking the sleekness of more contemporary city-building games. Navigating through menus and managing city details can be less intuitive for players accustomed to more modern interfaces. I don't know how to quit the game.

On modern systems, SimCity 4 Deluxe can face compatibility issues. Players might need to apply unofficial patches or tweaks to make the game run smoothly on newer hardware. What do you mean it's not ready OUT OF THE BOX?? o_o

General opinion:
SimCity 4 Deluxe, despite its age and the car icons that launch missions you can't do, remains a hallmark in the city-building genre. Its depth of simulation and creative possibilities set a high standard. While the learning curve and dated aspects may be deterrents for some, the game's charm and replayability make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Its enduring modding community and the timeless joy of constructing and managing your own city make SimCity 4 Deluxe a classic that continues to captivate urban planners and virtual mayors alike.

~~~ From a 90s perspective ~~~
As a 90s child who used to construct LEGO towns, I absolutely loved playing this city building simulation! This game was somewhat simple, so it was easy to grasp and understand as a young child. I never really looked into the budget, only to 'Legalise Gambling' for more income. It was exciting to have your very own town or city digitally on the computer, but you were somewhat limited with what you could do. The natural disasters never really interested me to be honest.

This was a single player game and I much preferred to play this in my own spare time. Sometimes though, I was sadly pressured into situations where I was forced to watch someone else play SimCity games. It was not fun or enjoyable to watch someone else play SimCity games single player. I don't see how a multiplayer CO-OP mode could work for such games, but could have provided an 'interesting' experience.

~~~ Modern perspective ~~~
The game has aged horribly in comparison to other modern city builders. Impressive titles exist such as Cities: Skylines and we will see Cities: Skylines II. Hardware and technology has come a very long way. This game has probably inspired other city building simulations as well.

~~~ The Sims 2, creating custom neighbourhoods using SimCity 4 ~~~
SimCity 4 is a handy utility for making custom neighbourhood layouts for The Sims 2 Ultimate Collection. You can load up SimCity 4, lay out your road layout, and import that into the Sims game. That is my only reason to use SimCity 4 in modern times.
20 years of development in this genre makes this game look quite simplistic, but its still up there with Skylines in many ways. EA / Maxis were unable to improve on it in later titles.

The great thing about Sim City is you can work on it and watch TV, and make all the various choices of the type of Cities you want. I am working on over 10 cities, and have built a complete area of 8 Islands with sea travel from one to another.

I have always been a SimCity fan since the 1990s. When this came out my Senior Year of High School I immediately purchased it, 3 times in fact over the course of it's lifetime.

Simply put, its a fun, casual stand alone game with great game play out the box. What truly makes it shine is the wonderful modding community that has truly breathed new life into this 20 year old game. New custom content is still being created at a steady pace.

Highly recommend for those who like to build worlds and create stories through SIM gaming.

The real challenge comes from building multiple cities and connecting them, maintaining balance throughout each of them working together.

SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is a city-building simulation game that offers a deep and complex simulation of urban planning and management, allowing players to design and build their own cities from the ground up. The game play of SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is centered around managing the various aspects of a city, from zoning and construction to infrastructure and services. Players must balance the needs and demands of their citizens, while managing the city's finances and resources. The game also features a variety of disasters and emergencies that can occur, such as fires, earthquakes, and terrorist attacks, adding an additional layer of challenge to the game play. One of the standout features of SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is its deep and complex simulation mechanics. The game offers a wide variety of building and zoning options, allowing players to create a unique and customized city. The game also features a robust transportation system, including roads, highways, and public transportation, as well as a variety of civic services like police and fire departments, healthcare, and education.Additionally, SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition offers a variety of customization options, including mods and user-generated content, allowing players to further enhance and customize their game play experience. However, SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is not without its flaws. The game's graphics are somewhat dated, and the interface can be overwhelming and difficult to navigate for new players. Additionally, the game's AI can be frustrating at times, with citizens sometimes making questionable decisions or getting stuck in traffic. SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition is a classic and beloved city-building simulation game that offers a deep and complex game play experience. While it may have some flaws and be intimidating for new players, those looking for a challenging and rewarding simulation game will find a lot to enjoy in SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition.

This game is pretty brutal out of the box. I used to be absolute garbage at it, but for some reason I just keep coming back to it. I don't know if it's because the way the buildings grow out of the ground is really satisfying or what, but once you get the hang of it, it's seriously fun.

Overall I was very impressed with SimCity 4. Unlike SimCity 3000, SimCity 4 really is a major evolutionary step in the series. To be honest I wasn't convinced that it was that much different until I played it for a while, but like an onion, there are just more layers to unwrap. But at least with SimCity 4 you won't be crying the entire time.

Still probably the best game in the series.

Still the best city builder of all time, though there are some good attempts coming out that update the genre nothing quite compares to this gem. The graphics have aged really well and I actually prefer them to Skylines, which at times can feel bulky. The isometric view keeps things feeling organized and simple to manage. It's a steal even at full price.

This game is practically old enough to drink, and yet it stays alive and competitive with many modern titles that are very well funded and excellent games. Cheers to a vibrant modding community that, amazingly, still operates and allows this to be a fun and worthwhile experience. This is clearly the peak of EA games; I can't say they've done a superior title since.

Now, if you're a fan of simulation games, then you're gonna love this one. SimCity 4 is all about building and managing your very own city. And let me tell you, it's a blast.

First off, let's talk about the graphics. For a game that came out in 2003, SimCity 4 still looks pretty damn good. The cities are vibrant and detailed, and the animations are smooth and fluid. And if you're into modding, there are a ton of options available to enhance the graphics even further.

Now, let's talk about the gameplay. SimCity 4 is all about balance. You have to manage your city's finances, build infrastructure, and keep your citizens happy all at the same time. It's a delicate dance, but when you get it right, it's incredibly satisfying. And there's no shortage of things to do in this game. From zoning to transportation, there are countless options to customize your city to your liking.

But what really sets SimCity 4 apart from other simulation games is the modding community. There are hundreds of mods available, from new buildings to custom transportation options. And if you're feeling adventurous, you can even download mods that add entirely new features to the game. The possibilities are endless, and it's a great way to keep the game fresh and exciting.

In conclusion, if you're a fan of simulation games, then you need to check out SimCity 4. The graphics still hold up today, the gameplay is challenging and rewarding, and the modding community adds even more depth and customization options. So what are you waiting for? Start building your dream city today!
I've enjoyed SimCity games almost 30 years.  SC4 is from 2003 but with a few hugely popular mods available from the SimCity community, it is a vastly improved and fascinating game.

Can be glitchy/buggy at times, may even crash, but by goodness I love this game. If you are interested in infrastructure, city designs, or other Sims games, this may just be for you. Plus the modding community is still very much alive.

SimCity 4 is the best city builder ever released to this day - even better than Cities Skylines. Unlike Skylines, SimCity 4 can support colossal mega cities of over 2.5 million people without a performance hit. Sure, it can't take advantage of modern day hardware and won't run at super high framerates, but it's consistent from when you're laying down your first low density residential zones to when you've filled up the final grid spot in a city. The modding community keeps this game alive and it can be expanded infinitely without taking eons to load like Skylines does. 

There's plenty of useful community-made patches which vastly improve the game. Search these up and install them before you start playing:
-IH Missing Jobs Fix
-SC4Fix
-IH Quadrupler
-Opera House Fix
-HippoTank Demand Fix
-Private School Fix
-Web Button Improvement Mod
-SC4 Launcher

If you have the patience, look into using a DirectX wrapper such as DgVoodoo2, as it will make the game run slightly better on modern hardware.

Finally, there's also a colossal mod that's been in development for almost two decades called the Network Addon Mod (NAM). Many players consider this essential and it's been a long time since I played without it. 

I can't recommend this game enough, especially when it's on sale 90% off like it was this past Christmas.
Always a game i come back to feel the nostalgia...one of the best city builders ever made and the last good one after the series was left to rot unfortunately.
Great for its time, not now. Just had a crash after hours of gameplay, all to waste, not that todays games do not crash, they just autosave at some point.

Before Cities: Skylines...  There was only SimCity 4 as the greatest city builder since 3000, 2000 and the original game.  Societies was an interesting experiment, but then there was the disaster of  2013's...  SimCity, the game meant to succeed SimCity 4...  ERRRR WHAT?!?!?  Everyone knows SC4's true successor was Cities: Skylines!
Skylines allows you to expand your city...  SimCity 4 let's build an entire COUNTY!  The map is divided into tiles of varying sizes where you can establish town and cities, ultimately giving you the ability to setup those all-important utility deals (Power, Water, Garbage, etc.).  Like The Sims you can easily make some asynchronous gaming fun around taking turns building up your cities and making deals with each other.  Speaking of The Sims...  If you have a working copy of The Sims 2, you can make your own makes to create worlds from in Sims 2.
Between Cities: Skylines and SimCity (2013), the comparison is night and day!  SimCity 4 on the other hand...  Between Skylines easy moddability and SimCity 4's ability to build up an entire county of cities, it's kind of hard to play favourites here.

But...  No harm in playing both!

SimCity 4 is a classic city building simulator. Among the best in the genre. It follows a basic gameplay loop, design and build-up a city (or many cities on one map). It is dated, and can be a bit jarring for those used to the more refined city builders these days, however it would be a missed opportunity not to have this in your Steam Library. Even as a game you play for a little bit here and there. There are also many good in-game features including making or importing your own Sims to place in your city, starting both natural and absurd disasters to rampage in your city, and a driving minigame that allows you to drive around the city you built from a topdown view. 

A classic. A game I can recommend from my childhood. 

8/10

This is probably my all-time favourite game. Ever.

Seriously, this game was like, 50% of my childhood. Ignore my Steam playtime, I played thousands of hours of this back in the day.

So it may not be the only big-name city builder in town now that we have Cities: Skylines, but I think there's still some things that this game does better, ever nearly 20 years after its release. For example, you have whole regions rather than individual cities, although individual cities in this game are smaller than their C:S counterparts. (A medium SC4 tile is roughly equivalent to a C:S starting tile) I'd argue that this game, being [i]technically[/i] 2D with an isometric view, allows for much more detailed and realistic buildings that you get in C:S, especially vanilla stuff.

What really makes this game great though is the same thing that makes its de facto successor great - the community. Over the years there has been some amazing custom content released for this game, and while there's no workshop support, there's plenty of guides out there for installing mods and custom buildings available from all the major fansites such as SC4Devotion and Simtropolis, among others.

Be aware that this is an old game, and it doesn't always play nicely with modern hardware. Like before there's guides to get this game running as well as it can on modern systems, but even with all that you will run into slowdown as your cities grow. A major limitation of this game is that it's single-threaded, so even the latest multi-core processors may not help much. This game will crash sometimes as well, so you'll need to save often.

There are tutorials in-game, but with these types of games I always think the best way to learn is by just playing. There's no shortage of tutorials out there for everything from basic city planning to interchange designs (using the Network Addon Mod) and more. This really is an all-time classic, honestly one of the last truly great games to come out of EA. Speaking of which, there's none of that Origin nonsense here, so consider that a plus.

Honestly I could talk forever about this game, but I'll finish it here. Just buy it. If you have even the slightest interest in city building or management games in general, you'll like this. Even at full price, you'll get more than your money's worth.

Sim City 4 is still every much as enjoyable today as it was in 2003. There is a certain charm to these older sprite drawn sim/rts games that was lost in the age of fully rendered 3D. To me these graphics are an art style that aged like a fine wine. You will have no problem losing yourself for hours as you build up your burg, just be ready to dip more into the red than the Biden administration...
This game still holds up as a simulation of what it feels like to run a city (or what I imagine is the craziness of trying to please everyone).  I recommend this to anyone.

Pros:
- It runs very well for a 20 year old game
- It has all of the great things that a city builder should have
- Unlike Simcity 2013 and other games that came after, SC4 has bordering cities that you can play as that allows for regional RCI demands
- Nice reward system
- Decent tutorial that can be skipped
- Plenty of mods that can be downloaded

Cons:
- Random crashes that can occur (SAVE OFTEN)
- Unrealistic traffic (Can have a population of 14,000 and need to place highways)
- Unable to create curved roads without mods
- Unable to make profitable small towns unless you finesse a bit
- Some mods make the game significantly slower or can crash it

Overall, it's a great game that still holds up many years later.
been playing for years simple game to kill time. I'm sure people would choose Skylines over this game but for the nostalgia of playing one of the first city builders, I enjoy it..

Even this nearly two decade old game still has charm and appeal beyond mere nostalgia. Compared to modern fair like Cities Skylines, this game has a brutal difficulty curve, you WILL need to balance things properly compared to C:S more forgiving and relaxed gameplay,  but this makes eventually growing a true balanced metropolis all the more satisfying. The old graphics have a good style to them that looks very detailed despite being borderline pixel art, too, and the biggest thing...REGION MODE! You can see a huge continent's worth of cities, something C:S is SORELY missing!

I'd still say C:S is better and more playable in general, but it's still easy to see why this game made the genre so popular at the time.

Unless you have at least a 15-year-old PC or laptop laying around this doesn't run well on modern systems. Also, to be really honest, Cities: Skylines does all this better anyway (even ignoring all the DLC).

Haven't even tried the mods or cheats yet so I'm excited. :D

I've been playing this game ever since I got it for my birthday, back in 2005.
Sure, there's now heaps of newer games in the genre, with mods and whatnot, but I still keep coming to this one, once or twice a year and notice something I haven't noticed before.

Being almost twenty years old, this game has some issues, it mainly has to do with newer hardware. So, it may run sluggishly with larger cities and sometimes even crash. If there's a game I'd love to see remastered one day, it's this one. I sincerely believe that it could catch new breath, with better support for modding and new content - it worked for AoE. Sadly,  I know that with Maxis gone, there's a slim chance of that ever happening and probably one day, in next twenty years or so, this game will become just a precious memory.

SimCity 4 is one of my most played games of all time. Considering the times I spent on Origin, GOG, Steam, and on the disc, I would have spent over 10,000 hours. It is a game that is unspeakable in its profound experience and replayability. It has charm and character that modern city builders are missing and a level of incomparable depth and difficulty. It's older than some people on the planet (over 16 years old!), and it still holds up in graphics and systems. It's a game that is still better than Cities: Skylines and one of the last great EA games. How can I forget the soundtrack! It's amazing! Can't I forget that you can get it for dirt cheap?

It has a very active and passionate modding community (shout out to Simtropolis and SC4 Devotion). Mix in a couple of mods and fixes, such as Network Addon Mod (NAM) and CAM (Colossal Addon Mod), and you got something that is complex and very enjoyable to play. The only complaint is the game's age, it can be very choppy, and loading can take forever on modern systems. The game can be buggy, and you need to get fan-made fixes (such as crime does not pay and opera house fix). The game's camera angle, a fixed trimeric (not isometric!), can make things difficult to see when you have lots of high-density buildings.

The game has interconnected regions where you can mix urban and rural together, build small farming towns or build a large metropolis—the transportation systems in this game rock. Build complex highways via Real Highway (using NAM), and you can drive vehicles. God mode is an exciting idea before crafting your city. There are advisors to yell at you. There's goofy messaging, a Mayor Rating and even riots (although extremely rare).

Do you  like installing mods?

If you don't,  then don't buy  this game and go for cities skylines instead.

But if you do, and you can deal with some of the instability that comes from playing a game from 2003 in modern systems, then take a few hours to learn about Sim City 4 and you'll discover why people are still playing this almost 20 years later. Without mods, it's almost unplayable and full of bugs, but with the right mods, it becomes the most powerful and customizable citybuilder game of all time.

I like this game because you can feel satisfied after building a megalopolis.  I like the planning that goes into deciding which districts will be commercial, which will be industrial, and which will be residential.  The side missions are also entertaining while you are waiting for your city to grow.

I love this game.  I prefer it over City Skylines, and I think I say that because the traffic and population numbers seem more realistic.  The graphics style and game play have a nostalgia for me as well.

The one thing I would say is Save, Save SAVE.  Every 5 minutes.  This game is better than the disc version I have, but it still crashes (compared to crashing every 5 minutes on Windows 7 off disc).  It's frustrating when you've put 30 minutes into your city and then lose all that progress when the game decides it's time to take a dump and crash without warning.

Still very good after all these years. I've have owned this is many forms, well 2. The original CDs and then on Steam. If you buy this make sure you look up the mods for it, the Network Add-on Mod as it fixes lots of issues that were never patched or resolved.

I'd say its even better than Cities Skylines. I prefer the art style of this and its much more detailed regarding the city simulation. Cities Skylines is good but feels more forgiving, where as this really feels like a real live city.

As mentioned, mods should be looked into if you want to get the most of this game now due to its age. Small part of its history, which I learnt the other day is the road simulation was very good and advanced for its day. So much so that unfortunately the PCs of the day couldn't run it very well, so the mechanics of the road simulation were decreased so they wouldn't slow the PCs down. Meaning buses etc take less passengers so you may always have traffic issues. However with the Network Add-on Mod you can customise the road/traffic system back to how it was originally designed making the game a lot more realistic.

This holds nostalgic feeling for me and I hope this game continues to be playable for years to come.

Sim City 4 Deluxe edition is an old game that still keeps on giving today. I bought the game because I cant afford Cities:Skylines with all its DLCs and my computer is a bit old to run that game. It has been the best purchase in years and cant stop playing Sim City 4 now. It has tons of transportation options, has solid gameplay and its not difficult to get into (at least for me). I recommend to look for a couple tutorial videos on how to install it correctly and which mods are essential to run the game today, also is a good a idea to watch a couple tutorials to have an idea of the gameplay since it can be a bit hard for new players.
The best thing about SC4 is the awesome community around it that keeps adding tons of new content: gameplay changing mods, new buildings and new maps. Totally recommend this game to anyone willing to spend a couple hours installing mods after purchasing the game.

It's just like the original SimCity, with improvements - the classic of the management sim genre.  This game is good for hundreds of hours of play.  You;ll have to stop yourself after a while.  I particularly like the addition of regions, which make it possible to build cities that border and interact with each other.

I usually spent most of my time in SimCity 3000 rather than 4, but the fact that no other city builder has topped this game in over 20 years says a lot about the legacy of this game. It makes me sad that I never never spent as much time fiddling around with the metric-fuck-ton of mods the SC4 community has made over the years. If you see my playtime increase dramatically after making this review you'll know that I've rekindled my love for city builders and the definitive game in that genre known as SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition.

I like the isometric graphics, since I'm an adult and don't want to see the bright colors intended for children.
I really enjoy building up the region and I mostly ignore the prompts from the advisors. I like that it's a game that you can lose if you get over zealous and give your people ALL DA SOCIAL SERVICEZ. I really enjoyed the mini game in which you have to take money bags to the new location for the casino. I created this thing called the ghettoville challenge. Basically you try to make a city as ghetto as possible, but you have to provide power, water, and trash and conform to normal zoning standards. I'm wondering if you can actually get kicked out of office for being corrupt, while it's common for newbs like my friends to go bankrupt. Also it's hilarious when newbs place power plants right next to residential. 

I'd like to see this game have a come back. Most of the Simcity discordsphere is into SimCity BuildIt which I quit playing after it made me wait 50 seconds to produce nails to upgrade some of my first houses.

The best mod for this game is the network add-on mod, colossus add-on mod makes it hard to load, the functional seaports mod will not install even when I extracted all of the dependencies.

I wouldn't recommend the network add-on mod for beginners. The basic function of the network add-on mod is that it makes people more likely to use public transportation similar to cities in Europe rather than America.

The game works well on windows 10 and 11. If you're installing a blank map, create a new folder in the regions folder and copy in the blank configure file this will usually be a blue (0,0,255) bmp file.

The most common fix is the software to hardware switch.
I recommend getting google drive for desktop and then automatically backing up your regions.
Back before EA was a complete dumpster fire of a company, Maxis used to release some pretty good Sim titles. I really enjoyed most of their games during this era. This is a great version of SimCity.

It's still the best SimCity / city builder game out there. It's dated though, so make sure you pick up at least the basic mods out there to fix outstanding bugs. If you haven't yet played this classic, please do.

When i first played this and exited the game, the game was somehow still running even after i closed it with the task manager. i played for only about 30 mins and have 68 hours logged (pretty i put more hours than that when this came of in the early 2000s)
It wouldn't be an EA game if it didn't crash all the time, but I still love it.. It has it's bugs and building issues but I can spend hours building one city after the other..

This is a fun urban planning game (despite how old it is). But the game takes many hours of incremental planning, and careful thinking in order for you to build a successful Metropolis. 

I recommend this game to anyone who is fanatical about urban development. If you're a casual player, just throw down a dozen farms, some roads, a few houses, a couple of stores and a garbage dump on the map for your enjoyment. :)

I have to agree with others on this issue. It doesn't seem to operate very well. It crashes several times through the day. I also can't save my progress. Whenever I try to save I get an error message Error saving city.(Rioverview.sc 4)
I will recommend it for people who like to build but no too concerned with saving progress.

sure I would say others to play it, it's so relaxing and fun playing this game, I've played a billion hours back in the time on an old laptop.

it's simcity.. complex yet so fun.

I found this again after many years and it's as good as I remember it - more modern city builders provide more flexibility but none strike quite the right balance between detail and style as SimCity 4 Deluxe edition does.

Even after all these years, SimCity 4 is still one of the best city simulator to this day.

Just make sure you get Network Add-on Mod (NAM). You don't need it, but it's highly recommended.
I jolly well regret playing this game over its refund limit. I used to play Sim City and  enjoyed it. That was not this version. Horrible experience, lousy. I wouldn't ever buy it again
Super fun, but it has a huge learning curve! Managing cities is super relaxing, but it's very necessary to be able to manage money and citizen happiness. I could and do spend hours in this game.

I Had a CD version of this game as a child. It was such a great time playing it on my Dad's old computer with a Pentium 4 processor. I find this game still as thought-provoking today. I recently found myself thinking about the data categories that measure the success of a city in *SimCity 4*, and how that reflects on the way the game's developers saw the world around them. There was a lot of care and effort put into developing this game. The game developers designed a seamless administrative simulator that makes every new city you build a unique experience. You can create your own topography and test out new city plans. This level of user empowerment is something I crave. Kudos!

One of my favorite games of all time. In my opinion, despite its age, it's still the best game in the series and it's better than other city building simulators that I played. There is just something special about this game; its 2D graphic, music, and everything else.

Obviously this is the last time I play this game when I was a kid, but now a days, despite of how it's goes from good game to a bad game, due to the glitches, errors and it'll crash on Windows 10 without warning, you'll prefer actually play Cities of Tomorrow or Cities Skyline, but there's nothing special about that anymore, who'ever works on this game isn't gonna put in some updates after some players I can't stop looking and reading negative commits about this game how it'll either crash or something worse I don't want to find out what happens if I play this again, either way, if it crashes and forces to close my game, I'm not coming back, what a waste.
I love to build things so this is just up my alley. There is a fine line between keeping a thriving city going as your building and going too far and things falling apart. The key is the balance!
This has always been one of my favorite games. It is nice to be able to enjoy it again. The last time I tried to play it the OS did not cooperate. With Windows 10 I am having no problems.

I like the different building styles you can choose.  I usually choose two for each city within a region to make them a little unique.  I am building out a freeway system in my current region, even though I'm not sure how beneficial it actually is.  It just looks great.

Its just a classic all rounder. Love this game and have for many years. I still dont prefer it to Sim City 3000 but that is just my own personal bias. You cant go wrong with this game especially if you can get it on sale. I love the fun little built in modes of play where you can have a sim living in your city, and drive cool vehicles around your town. Lovely game, aged very well, highly recommend.

games works fine but for some strange reason after long hours it crashes a i am forced to restart the pc as just closing steam and restarting it does not seem to allow me to restart the game. overall i am very happy with the game

Great game if you use mods to correct the traffic issues.

The fact that every road becomes congested after 30 seconds whether you have 1 house or 100 is the only thing that ruins this game.

Im only recommending it because it can be solved and the game is old.
It was in the queue for a long time, I don't regret it. It works without problems on Windows 10, I'm running at 1600x1200 and it hasn't crashed once in 82 minutes.

One of the first games I've played. Without a doubt one of the classics. Its got great mechanics and design that hold up til today. Its very satisfying to watch as the little village you built turns into a bustling city.

I've played this game when I was a child. I still believe its the best Sim of all. I was hesitant to purchase it due to the claim from everyone, stating that it would crash on Windows 10.
Well, I took the risk and played it 2.2 Hrs with no problem at all, no tweak nor anything weird. I haven't tested the Import Music (which I would eventually do). I'm pretty sure my Windows 10 settings automatically allowed it to play regardless of being old.
If this continues working, I will have no problems to share my laptop's specs and any setting that I currently have.

Minor nuisances aside (rare, random crashes and a couple of reward buildings not working as intended), this game is fantastic. If you're interested in city builders, I'd definitely recommend picking this up when it's on sale.

Or wait until EA hopefully remasters this gem one day.

A niche classic. One of the best simulators I've ever played. Though I really am disappointed that it doesn't run very well on Windows 10 (even though it's to be expected.) The music is a little funky, but it grows on you after a while. It's such a soothing and innovative game.

Cities Skylines may be newer and prettier, but this game has heart! There is a charm and pleasentness to playing this game that doesn't exist in other city builders I've played, save earlier sim city games.

I've played a lot of city builders and SimCity4 is definitely my favorite. It's age may show but it doesn't have all the odd early game requirements or late game issues that City Skylines seems to have.
This is my favorite city builder ever! Its just the right balance of control over your city without being overwhelming or over complicated.  Definitely should try this is your a fan of city builders!

What can I say?
This is the same game that allowed millions of children to play GOD as they built and then destroy an entire city! I've been playing this on and off since the 3rd grade on their old Macs and I'm still playing it as an adult today on my Windows box via steam.

I played this game as a kid and still love it. It's a true sandbox game. While you are provided basic tutorials, what you create is based on your own skill and creativity. For some people, that's a negative. But if you're up for the challenge and have the patience, this can be a truly rewarding game. Although I still play vanilla, with all the mods available, I would say the game is more of a hobby than a video game.

Despite its limitations, especially when compared to Cities Skylines, SimCity 4 is still one of the best in the series and continues to hold up even today thanks to the amazing mod community. And as much as I love The Sims, it is a shame EA has thrown SimCity into the bin.

SimCity is nice because while you obviously still manage something, it is a bit more laidback because you don't have to worry about each individual Sim's needs, let alone what they look like. Which, let's be fair, can eventually burn someone out. With SimCity, you can let your imagination decide what your Sims are doing while you focus on building your city that they live in and preventing it from burning to the ground - until you want to, of course.

Although this is an old game, its more enjoyable than a fair amount if the games that have came out lately, Always there in my library to use when these newer games are questionably not up to snuff yet.

The only SimCity I played before SC4 was the original Nintendo version on SNES. 4 is a big jump from the first game in terms of complexity and interlocking systems, but it's really rewarding and fun to figure out how everything connects. The tutorials are super helpful in explaining how the simulation works. My only complaint would be how obnoxious navigating the terrain is. The original SimCity was 2D, so everything was gridded out on a flat plane. SC4 takes into account mountains and valleys, canyons and erosion. It's fun sculpting out the space but building on slopes and beaches is so finicky. Some of my Sims go to school on sheer cliffs because the game will automatically carve out a giant square brick in the earth if the lay of the land is too wacky. Oh well. Def recommend SC4 if you like Cities Skylines (SimCity is better, come on).
An epic time-waster. You'd think I'd be better at this game by now, but I build the same city over and over and they never advance. Tutorials be damned; I'll never get any better!

Its a classic, now rather dated but still great fun! Lots of mods and custom content plus its still the only city building game without any limits! You can make a 100km x 100km region and fill it up if you wish!
By far the best version of Sim CIty ever. I wish EA would release an updated version of Sim City 4 rather continuing to push the later version of Sim City that dumbs everything down.

Probably the best classic Sim City game. Much more challenging than Sim City 2000 or Sim City 3. 

Money is a constant problem; you have to be strategic about building new schools, hospitals, police stations, fire stations, highways, etc. because the upkeep for everything is very steep. Traffic and pollution are also significant problems you have to contend with. Relief from your money problems finally comes when you educate your sims, promoting them to the middle and upper classes, and when you create high-tech industrial factories and commercial skyscrapers for them to work at. 

One thing to know is that the AI path-finding in the original game is broken -- unless you install a mod to fix it, all sims drive to and from work using the (geometrically) shortest possible path. This leads to frustrating situations such as sims preferring to drive on roads instead of using your trains, subways, and highways, or sims all driving on one road when there are multiple roads available that could reduce traffic. Personally I fixed this issue by installing the Network Addon Mod (NAM), which you can find using Google. 

I had fun replaying this game from my childhood and building a much larger and more successful city compared to what I was able to build when I was in middle school. That being said, the game doesn't have much replay value; once you've built up a city as big as it can possibly get, with all reward-buildings unlocked and built, I don't see any reason why I would ever go back and do it all over again.

This game scratches the HELL out of an itch I've felt since moving on from SimCity 2000. I would say there was a comparable simplicity to SC2K that this one builds upon, with satisfying (but different) execution. There does seem to be the same bug that 2K had though - somehow, every time I play it, it creates some sort of hyper-localized warp in the space-time continuum centered suspiciously at my desk...
Better than Cities Skylines for sure. Picked up a copy from G2A for $2.50, would highly recommend buying there if you want to pay almost 90% less than the game's normal price.

The game is so confident in itself that it doesn't even have a main menu: past the splash screen, it opens right onto an overhead view of the region displaying all your cities. This is a game from a time when it wasn't clear which designs were going to make a billion dollars. At heart, it's the same simulation--but revealed to the player with a real grace that only Maxis could manage. It's telling that there's really only one big-budget rival to this game (we're not counting Sim City 2013)--Cities: Skylines. And that won't run on my computer so...SC4 it is.

Before Cities Skylines was hands down the best city builder in the market. Great graphics that still hold well today, straightforward gameplay, if you are willing to put up with the isometric 2D gameplay, and lots of mods in external websites such as Simtropolis.

Unfortunately it is not designed for newer computers and multicore processors, and takes not only little benefit from them but also crashes often as well.

10/10 10 years ago, but right now 7/10. If you are interested make sure to download NAM - it is pretty much a must - as well as mods of your choice.
It's a perfect port of a great game however, the aspect ratio on modern monitors is limiting and it is buggy - 1 out of 3 times when I touch the scroll wheel on the mouse it crashes.
I've played this game since I was little and still have no idea what I'm doing, but it's still fun! I would recommend this game to anyone that likes to build things.

Classic Game, detailed and requires a quite bit of strategy. This is as good as it gets. Better than Cities: Skylines, and the massively disappointing SimCity 2013. Game is 20 years old at the time of this review, and the creators went out of business long ago, so there will be no updates. Because of this, there are compatibility issues which often steers new players away and cause them to leave a nasty review. However, it doesn't have to be like this; there are easy workarounds to most of them with little research!

For running the game above 1080p, this guide is a must follow!
https://steamcommunity.com/app/24780/discussions/0/1471967615838569110/

For crashing issues, the most common culprit is the game utilizing multiple cores when it was made to only handle one. Use -CPUCount:1 in the launch options. Still save often, as there could be other reasons your game crashes and they may not have a resolution. Besides, its a good habit.

Finally I recommend every one download and install the latest version of NAM (Network Addon Mod). NAM is essentially a mod that combines a bunch of useful mods. It provides you with extensive and detailed road, highway, rail, subway, etc., combinations. Even if you do not wish to use these features, it contains its own traffic simulator that changes the path finding and parameters of the infrastructure to reduce traffic greatly and make it more realistic. It is worth gold for that alone. Plus it is completely free. 
https://www.sc4nam.com/download-the-nam/
A classic, that was really great for its era. It has been vastly surpassed by other city builders, but it is still fun to revisit it now and then, despite its quirks.
Complex but easy to understand. Been playing since 2003 and still haven't come close to mastering this game (bloody skyscrapers are so hard to create demand for) but still a very relaxing game.

I enjoy matriculating splines. If you don't know what that means, these are the words mentioned every time you created a new land mass to conquer in the original Sim City. Sim City 4 requires you to play a more active roll in creating your land masses. That has it  good points and bad. You don't have to put power lines over roads for power to get to the other side which means the whole quadrant is powered so long as the adjacent one is powered. That's nice.  I am still trying to work out the cost/revenue matrix which means I have not achieved the success I had in the earlier game. Also, I don't like being limited to adding only $1,000 at a time in their command line. They added a SIM person option to the game which I played a little and it will be more fun once I have conquered the skills to master the economics of city growth. This game is a fun diversion from Skyrm. All-in-all, I would buy it again and I plan to play it for several hundred hours so that equals a thumbs up from me.

Most complete city builder of all time, nothing can even come close. The best city sim builder ever made. It was so far ahead of its time, nothing has outdone it yet,....This was the peak performance of the Maxis team in the early 2000s, its a tour de force of simulations. Throw everything you can at it, its so complex and it just works. The public at large is too stupid for game like this to come out nowadays..

Holds up surprisingly well. Definitely has some things that show their age, but all things considered, a solid game considering it came out in 2003. Great strategy requirements and the cities build themselves well.

A strange game, so simple and broken at the start but with 3 hours of modding, it becomes a completely different game, so deep, so complex, it allows you to build a city that is closest to real life, i think even more relistic compared cities: skylines. If you want an in-depth experience that requires a little extra effort (modding, which is time consuming but fairly simple), go for this.

its extremely hard to make money for your city, but this is 100% the ultimate sim city game you remember from the old days, its quite fun however the game does encourage you to exploit farmers and treat them like slaves lol  you must add this to your start up options for the game: 

-CustomResolution:enabled -r1366x768x30 -CPUCount:1 -Intro:off

Really hard to play if you're impatient, but since I've been failing at this game since I was a kid, finally succeeding felt really good. Basically, you just have to let your city grow slowly....unless you like being bankrupt and having extremely poor air quality.
It's a great game. The only downside is the fact it randomly crashes often. Make sure you save frequently or you'll be rebuilding parts of your city a few times.

This game really holds up well! However, I would recommend using the Set Launch Options under properties to change the CPUCount parameters to 1 CPU so the game doesn't crash. (Type -CPUCount:1). You will have to re-enter this every time Steam restarts.
This is such an advanced simulation game! It's challenging, engaging, and fun. I played this game growing up and I was so happy to find it again here on Steam!

Conclusion:
This game is HARD. Also, it requires a beefy computer to run even though it's nearly 20 years old. I don't have a gaming PC, but my laptop is new and mid-range, and I tend to get around 20fps once my city is big. Really fun game, though.

The last good SimCity.  It lacks some of the personality and humor of 3000, but it makes up for it with a deeper and more complex simulation than anything that had come before.  A worthy entry in a great series.

This is the best Sim City game in my opinion not only are you building and managing your city you also get to play various vehicle missions to earn money or mayor rating it also allows you to get special buildings for your city if you complete enough of the missions which also allows you to drive more vehicles for missions or you can even free drive them.  some of the vehicles you can drive are police, ambulance, fire truck, helicopters, planes, trains, tank, bus, UFO. aside from vehicle missions you also need to keep the sims in your city happy and you can eventually get skyscrapers. you can also destroy your city with disasters too. the game will sometimes crash on windows 10 so save frequently. also if you have Sims 1 installed you can move your sims 1 sims into your cities. Still worth playing this game in 2021.

I found it difficult to make money. The advisers all want to spend on their project, each looking at the city's cash balance, but most of them could not be used while city is new & growing slowly.
Also water supply is threatened later by sabotaging pumps or cleaning.
To begin with use as few roads as possible: there is not enough traffic to justify wider roads or railway. Only use this to connect industrial zone to outside world & to commercial zone if too many commercial vehicles.

Well it was fun but it does not function very well after about 1100 years into the game. I think it has a lot to do with the Windows 10 os. The game starts to freeze up and the clock stops for a long time and then starts moving again. I had some fun though, definitely reminds me of being a kid again. I was even looking in the store to see if there was a newer version. The game does crash a lot so just remember to save every 15 minutes.
Not quite like the Sim City I've played before in the 1900's when I played on Genesis, or Nintendo, I forgot which, there are fewer options for your city, but it is still fun.
literally best game ever, I keep going back to it even though SC5 has been out for years. easier than cities skylines and more fun to annihilate your hard work
It's good, it's fun, and you realize from this game why most cities in the United States suck. You need to keep the rich and middle classes happy to have the tax base necessary to fund city services.
everything is the same about this game from when it came out but i freezes and closes a lot. so make sure to save often. if only someone knew how to fix that problem it would be amazing
This is my favorite city-building game. While Cities: Skylines is much more modern and better in almost every way, I always come crawling back for that classic warm feeling that SimCity 4 brings.
I like this version more than any of the new sim citys that they have released. There is allot of building options. I found that after this one they started dumbing the game down

One of the last good things to come out of EA/Maxis. A solid iteration on SimCity 3000 featuring huge graphical improvements, far more tangible visualization of your city data and more diverse transit options. Probably my favorite city builder of all time.

Pros: 
Sim City 4 is definitely a classic. It is a basic city builder that allows you to build multiple cities in one region. You can spend hours of your time building and creating different roadways and networks to your enjoyment. If you are brave enough, you can even mod the game (look up a tutorial). The game is simple to understand and is fun to play.

Cons:
For SC4 being an almost 20 year old game, it is surprising that it can still even run on modern day machines. With that in mind, SC4 does crash alot and can lead to you loosing progress, leaving you to have to manually save alot. The graphics are not the best, yet not the absolute worst. The game is not receiving updates at all, so any bugs that are in the game now, are in it forever. 

Price:
Is the game worth $20? The Simple answer is no. The good thing is that the game goes on sale quite often. So i would pick it up when it is on sale.

Recommendations:

   This game does not have that, yet, it is a very complete game.   There is also a wealth of mods for it, which you can find at Simtropolis assuming you can get an account.

I've owned and played the retail version for years off and on.  I've not played any newer city sims because I've heard bad things about them when compared to this one.  It's a shame the series peaked here.

I've seen some other guides on Steam for fixing graphic or performance issues, but I've not had any serious problems getting the game to run normally either the retail version nor so far the Steam version (should be identical).  There is no native widescreen support and the game doesn't have a native auto-save and WILL CRASH at random times sometimes so be sure to SAVE FREQUENTLY.  When this game came out, it was very intense on the single CPUs of the time and even today you may have graphical glitches and issues.  The day/night cycle in particular can create rendering problems but you can lock it to Day.

There's also some mods and patches you really should pick up.  I found one somewhere that fixes High Residential jobs fulfilled by High Tech Industry that's bugged in the original (they create demand but don't fulfill it, causing your high residential properties to go abandoned when they can't find jobs).  There's one for the Opera House too.  There's others, but those are the only two I've got added right now.

This SimCity is more complex and granular than previous ones and for the uninitiated it can be overwhelming to balance all the different demands of your citizens.  Losing money is easy, making it is not.  Just know that you don't have to build everything at once and if you don't have the money to support something, just wait until you do.  There's a lot of variables and some of it is not coded the best (there are mods out there that fix traffic issues too).

A classic. A must have if you are autistic or just really like maps and stuff as a special interest. It's stimmy AF. Jerry Martin is a god. Sometimes I just play it to calm myself down. Mods like NAM from SimTropolis are highly needed if you are going to get really into it, and trust me, there is still a community of people who are like, really into it. Without some mods and fixes from either simtropolis or sc4devotion. It's a bit buggy but still playable. Can run on one core if that's all you have. Not as goofy or funny as previous Sims/Maxis games but still pretty solid. Get it.

A classic that still holds its charm years later.

The graphics aren't cutting edge but they are quaint in a classic WoW sense. 

City building is fun and if you ever played Sim City (any version), come revisit this and remind yourself why it is so much fun.

I loved this game. It made for great memories and planted an early seed for strategic planning. 
BUT- That was on the operating system it was written for. This version doesn't even load 9/10 times. I get a black screen when the game tries to launch. My hardware specs are more than capable of running it. so I see this as a poorly assembled port. Would've been forgivable seeing as DirectX has issues with old ports from time to time, but at a ~$20 price tag it's sloppy.

***UPDATE***
Thanks to the user community for this game, I was shown the fix. Copy this line into your Launch Options for the game in your steam library:
-w -intro:off -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32

Make sure to save your game every 30 seconds or it will f***ing close on you for no reason.  Also, don't bother with the U drive it missions because most of the time you get to the target and nothing f***ing happens.

I downloaded this game because i remembered playing Sim City 3000 some 15 years ago. This game is much more complexed and alot harder to grasp in my opinion but well worth buying if youve got the patience and determination to succeed.

Classic city builder. The one everyone else is trying to be. Nothing else quite like it. Have been playing sim city since I had a SNES. I have played every iteration and this is the best by far. Deluxe version ( Rush Hour Expansion ) is a must have. Also recommend using the NAM mod and having a look at the Simtropolis site. It will help you get the absolute best from the game. A very big fan.

Most of the time the game will not stop running, even if it doesn't show it's not running in the task manager.  It won't let you close the Steam client.  It's irritating.

A simulation that puts you in the position of making decisions that might not be the right ones for the time, and how to correct them in real time. Very satisfying gameplay even if you can't get your town to grow the way you expected it to. Is there going to be a version where players can be Dr. Vu, shamelessly exploiting the town fathers and residents? I can see the appeal of such a game now.

This is absolutely a great game,.
Yes, old, but great.

(This review is mainly focused on the gpu, isnt about the how great or interesting the game is, if you ask, then I do recommend this game means everything.)

But it cant use Dedicated Nvidia card on Windows.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For Laptop Users:
If you're on a laptop, which use integrated card as display, then you need to be awared that this game doesn't support Nvidia Geforce Gtx (or rtx, but I dont have a rtx card), you can find that under system requirement/supported graphics chipsets (on the store page).
I mean, this game will not accept any card except the display card, as of my understanding after trying for couple of months.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

TL;DR: 
I have tried everything to let the game run on my nvidia gtx card, like adding my dedicated card string and pci id to the graphics rule and video cards respectively, that didn't work (btw, there are tonnes of different pci id of my gtx 1650, of different version, I did add all of them to the video cards.sgr file, but of course, that didn't work).
Of course I had tried to set the game using high performance gpu, at the time of writing this, windows overrode the gpu selection of nvidia control panel.
After, I deleted all ATI strings and vendor cards information on those files I mentioned before (because my integrated card is an AMD gpu), and that still didnt work.
EVEN, I tried to disable my integrated card on the device manager, then the game REFUSED to be launched!, I cant believe how stubborn it is that it doesnt want to be played with dedicated cards.
THE DEVIL!
(You might ask, why I must use dedicated, instead of integrated? That's because the integrated one cant run this game smoothly, that really affects my playing experience, AND I think it's UTTERLY a shame that it cant even run a 2003 game smoothly!)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 I first enjoyed the game with my old macbook air, which only has an intel 5000 series gpu, but I enjoyed the game with most settings set at medium or low and resolution only at 1366x768.
That was a really great experience, then, I wanted to play the game on my windows laptop, which had a lot better gpu, and absolutely can run this game with max setting and resolution at 1080p.

Then the nightmare started, actually nightmare isnt accurate, time wasting could be the better word to describe this:

Firstly, I didnt know that the game cant recognise modern dedicated gpus, after the first time of launching the game which I didnt find the fps counter, and then when building a big city that the game is lagging, I realised that the game wasnt using my dedicated gpu, which was gtx 1650.

Then, later I searched on google for a lot of times, wandered on different forums like metropolis, wondering for answers and solutions of this, and, I found a thread, which its content was about adding gpu strings to the graphics rules.sgr, and adding specific graphics card pci number to the Video cards.sgr.
I followed every step of that guide carefully and correctly, but it failed.
Reason? Well, I thought it was because some unknown problems occured or I didnt follow those steps correctly, but that was completely wrong.
After this failure, I retried those steps of the guide again and again, about 4 times later, that I had already tried some solutions like: uninstall the game completely, and reinstall it; restart, etc.
Except reinstall the system. (I cant reinstall windows 10, because it contained many important files to myself, and I have no space to store them, that was about 2 terabytes.)
As the tl;dr section mentioned, I also had thought that maybe I didnt add those information sufficiently, but all of them didnt work, I couldn't imagine how frustrated I was.
(I suppose the person like you whom would like to read such long texts would not dismiss the tl;dr section, wouldn't you? 😉)

So, lastly, after trying all whether normal or abnormal solutions, I was defeated, I surrendered. 
All of these wasted me months of time, I really don't have any mood and thought to play this game anymore, it's definitely waste of time, without any payback.
Maybe the next I would like to play this game again should be when I have a  current dedicated gpu level integrated gpu (having little confusion, aren't you?), the game with my current integrated card is just running like a rubbish, with full of lagging and crushes.
(I do know that the game uses 1 core will prevent some problems, I also tried that, with command line and set to only use 1 core, but the game was running even slower than ever before.)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So my advice is, if you're using laptop, and really care such thing like lags and low frame rate, then you can just give it up, make yourself cup of tea or coffee and play other games or do other things, this game is lacking of hope (nothing is absolute, isn't it.)

About desktop users, I'm not actually really sure if it can work, because I dont have a desktop, I will update this if I can have tested.
And possibly, on desktop, you may need to change display gpu to the dedicated one, I think laptop can only use integrated card is because it cant change display gpu (The gpu which display and illustrate everything on your monitor).
The result is high possibly may differ in distinct circumstances.

Hope you enjoy my review and some  jokes.

I don't think it's ever going to be too late to try it, so much so that it would almost need a remastered edition adapted to the most modern PCs. Super recommended.
