A classic! 
Used to play it back in the days and recently came up with the idea to check if it's on Steam, there ya go! 
Not much to say:

Pros:
+ extensive, addictive and detailed game

Cons:
- might get frustrated if you can't figure out how to create a functional infrastructure

Imagine not being able to build mid-rises and create a genuine transition between lively city centers and zombiefied Americana-spam. 
Imagine having zoned structures limited to a mere 1,024 square meter area because the zoning only extends outward 4 eight-meter tiles from every road. 
Imagine not being able to play with multiple cities and connect them into a living network. 
Imagine not being able to have elevations higher than ONE. FUCKING. KILOMETER. 
Imagine not being able to actually use your glorious one-city tile of 299 square kilometers because the network length capacity hard-coded into the game is too small, and they actually want you to use an area smaller than a big city tile in SC4. 
Imagine having to potentially dismember your city every time a new traffic jam occurs- and that said traffic jams can occur at any time of the day or night because the citizens never sleep and the factories and stores never close.
Imagine having your population capped at 1 million and your vehicle activity capped at SIXTEEN THOUSAND! 
Imagine needing to get computers as expensive as fucking down payments on new cars, because otherwise you won't be able to build JACK SHIT! 
Imagine that! Oh wait you don't have to imagine. Just play Cities: Skylines. 

Detriments to SC4: 

-you need mods to make the road network more flexible (NAM is a pain to get my head around though)
-water has a set height and does not flow from higher to lower elevations (at least it doesn't randomly flood like C:S)
-camera cannot be adjusted to any angle whatsoever, is stuck in birds-eye at every rotation and elevation
-buildings are stuck at angles of 45 to 90 degrees from each other as are most of the roads, which cannot curve easily
-autobuilding streets in zones sometimes spam without regard for the encircling road network, this also goes for the directionality of buildings in R/C zones
-corner road connections turn into endless traffic generators that fuck up regional demand and are never resolved
- crashes due to being too old for these multithreading CPUs (but it just went ~16 hours before it did on my PC, though I was mostly in region view) 
-many more, give me enough time and I will remember all the flaws.

Now, both of them have problems. And I did overinflate Skylines' ones. Maybe. Just a little. But they are also THE TWO BEST CITY-BUILDING GAMES OUT THERE! (and the only ones I've played, hehe, unless Surviving Mars somehow counts oh wait freeways and trains are banned from Mars, nvm)

Just fuse them together into one game that takes the best of both. Hopefully you won't need to decide between paying bills (or a new car/house/whatever) and a new PC for it. 

Been playing SC4 from 2007-16 and from 2019-present. Got Skylines almost five years ago. Been a helluva ride with both of them but I love them so.

This is an all-around fascinating and engaging game.  You can engage with it on a number of different levels, from playing on easy mode and letting your advisors point you toward building a conventionally successful metropolis as the requirements slowly grow with the population to attempting to use your vast intellect to micromanage your city with a deft hand and iron fist to make it the most minmaxed metropolis in existence.  My favorite part is the terrain editor — not because you can play god, but because it lets you construct interconnected series of cities that really look, from the map overview, like a real place.  The limited customization for architectural styles and very low-res artwork, along with sometimes buggy Rush Hour mechanics (which are otherwise the best part of the deluxe version of the game by far), are forgivable blights.
The best Sim City made currently. Blows away the newer Sim City (2013). Making your own map is easy to do, and gives hours of gameplay. Then the city building begins! Very easy to mod as well.

One of the best games I have ever played. Sometimes can be pretty hard to manage to stay in positive income, but when you do it is rewarding. It has really nicely made isometric graphics with some 3D effects. (cars, planes, boats, etc.)

It's Sim CIty. At this point you either like this sort of game or you don't. Fun, and pretty with many diverse building types to occupy your zones. Good way to spend part of an evening doing something mildly constructive.

You would think that sometime in the past seventeen years that someone could make a city builder that didn't cost a couple hundred bucks and only come close to this one.


Still king of the hill.

After you get the basics down, its quite nice to just zone out and play this game. Youll just be tinkering with taxes look down and 6 hours have passed. This game is 100% 420 friendly ;) And for $5, you cant go wrong...

SimCity 4 is one of the last great 2D city simulators. The art style is absolutely breathtaking and gorgeous. 

Initially playing more modern games like City: Skylines left me thinking I could never go back to older simulated systems. However, SC4 still does such a good job with its systems that it left me astonished when I finally came to play again. It does suffer from a lack of clear direction that can lead to hours of trial and error to figure things out. But the cities you get to discover along the way make that process fairly worthwhile. A trial by fire, the player certainly feels their efforts are earned, whereas sometimes more modern city simulators feel like they hand you some successes on a silver platter (which is not a bad thing--I appreciate that C:S makes some mechanics easier for a noob such as myself). 

SC4 is a beautiful game and one I love to come back to see that beauty, even if I have to stumble a bit to figure out how to make it work.

Despite the low play hour count on my Steam profile, I have played and sank in many hours of this game way back in the days of Windows XP on my Pentium 4 PC.

This is in my opinion the best game in EA/Maxis' SimCity series. I found SimCity Societies and SimCity 2013 to be both so disappointing. SimCity 2013 should have been called SimSuburbs with it's super small maps and the extreme level of micromanagement was simply too much. I guess I was just expecting the classic formula.

And this is where SimCity 4 shines. Having grown up on SimCity 2000 for Windows 95, SimCity 4 basically had the SimCity 2000 formula perfectly refined and with great detail, for a game made in 2003. It has the right amount of city management, without becoming overbearing which instead allows you to focus more on building and expanding your city. Some of the maps are simply massive and can take many hours to fill up. When you build roads they don't just appear out of thin air, you see construction crews laying down the pavement. This is the level of detail this game had, and it was in 2003! What's more, with a game that is now 17 years old, it's definitely not subject to any hardware limitations today so you never get any slowdowns on the simulation, even at max speed!

But that's not to say everything has aged well. Zooming in closely to see the buildings and vehicles will unfortunately show their low resolution assets clearly on LCD panels compared to the CRTs of those days. The user interface by today's standards is a little clunky, but its not all that bad. The game lacks proper widescreen support, but it's easily fixed by just adding a few command arguments to the shortcut for the game (just Google how to make SimCity 4 widescreen). It's just unfortunate they haven't taken the time to make a small patch to the game for this after all these years so that users don't have to modify the game shortcut themselves.

This being the deluxe edition, it includes the Rush Hour expansion pack, a great addition with new transport options, traffic management tools, and added songs to the soundtrack. Did you know you can even drive the cars in this game, though from the same top-down view (as it is the only viewpoint)? It can be fun to lose hours driving around your own city, exploring everything up close, or speeding your car and crashing to make chaos at intersections.

And let's talk about the sound a bit as well. SimCity 4 and Rush Hour have an absolutely fantastic soundtrack, very fitting for city building. They are actually memorable songs and you may find yourself thinking about the music even when you are not playing the game. That's a good thing, as I find there aren't many games that leave you with a soundtrack that you end up remembering years later. The soundtrack is even available on Spotify, which I keep in my library and listen sometimes when doing work. The sound effects are certainly passable for a 2003 game.

If you were ever a fan of any SimCity game growing up, you will likely enjoy SimCity 4. And if you are a fan of Cities: Skylines, you definitely should check this game out as well. Considering the messy, terrible disappointment that was SimCity 2013, which is nothing like the classic SimCity games, I have always considered Cities: Skylines to be the spiritual successor to SimCity 4.

These days I am spending tons of time in Cities: Skylines. It's similarity to SimCity 4, but on a modern game engine in full 3D, makes me want to call it SimCity 5 if I could. But I always find myself going back to the roots of it all once in awhile, and boot up SimCity 4 and have some fun in it. And when I'm on my old laptop instead of my gaming PC, it makes a great pastime since my old laptop can barely run Cities: Skylines, with single digit frame rates.

Would I recommend buying this at full price? No, not for a 17 year old game. But if it's 75% off during a Steam sale? Then absolutely you should scoop this up for some nostalgia goodness! Explore what I would consider to be the best SimCity game of a previous era, one that EA has simply never been able to match since 2003.
Be mindful the game is old and has a lot of glitches. Sometimes it leaves you wondering if it's even worth it to go through 10 errors to play, but once it works it is fun.

As someone who played this game a LOT as a kid, I've come back to it every now and then because of how good it still is. Obviously not as graphically impressive as something like Cities: Skylines, but that just means more power can be used to properly simulate a realistic city population without setting your gaming laptop on fire. I'd argue the terraforming terrain tools are almost just as good, and you can even drive cars around the streets of your city AND add your own custom music in the menus. You can pretty much make your own GTA with this game.
There's no integrated workshop for addons, but I strongly recommend checking out places like Simtropolis.com and SC4Index to properly pimp out your game with loooooads of great mods.
BE WARNED THOUGH: SAVE OFTEN. As much as I love this game, running it on newer Windows systems tends to spontaneously hard crash the game. From my experience the frequency of crashes seems to vary from computer to computer.

Sadly it crashes a lot, but I found a way so it doesn't as often. It's a classic you gotta buy it if you are tempted. Yeah the graphics suck, but this game beats all the other city simulators out there.

I played this game 17 years ago when it first came out. I was mesmerized then...just like I am now. It hasn't lost its allure. Incredibly complex and difficult to master, this game is legendary and deserves people taking the time to experience it.

This is the best game in the SimCity series.  It's the most complex and most realistic.  It gives the most freedom to build entire regions of cities and has tons of great mods,

Love the planning and the variety of things to think about, making it your ideal world....but that doesn't work!! Love the complexity of factors and options, not an easy one to crack, but it doesn't matter!!

Probably the last quality SimCity to come out of EA. The gameplay still holds up to today's standards and you can easily get sucked into building all the cities within your region. Would highly recommend.
It's old and the graphics aren't that great, but with all the 3rd party add-ons and designs, this is the best version of the franchise. Recommended for true simulation enthusiasts.

Thinking what to say about one of the masterpieces in the history of city building... I guess all I can say is that this game is tricky one, it's not a type of game had played before. You need to think, try and execute! Every city is a new struggle, every game is a new start that requires hard work, strategic thinking and a patience.

Rome wasn't built in a day :)

This game is great however I suggest you only get it when it's on offer. £17.99 is far too much for a game that was made 16 years ago but luckily I managed to buy this during the steam sales for £4.99 during a sale. You can't beat the original SimCity series and 4 is the last and most comprehensive version. I just wish they made a SimCity 5...

A great game, a lot of space to build cities, fairly simple and straight-forward to learn and get used to. If you are looking for a game to help you pass some time, then this game is a great time waster. The vanilla game is great for hours and hours of city building and then, let go with a tornado, riots in the streets, or even a ufo invasion.

You can make your city look just like your hometown or stuff all of the monuments of the world in your city. It really is up to your imagination.

A classic -- has both strategy/math/world-building for those who like that, and driving
missions for those who want more of a video-game feel -- and early/intro Sims as people
(which dominated later).  Great for relaxing/nostalgia/simpler-times.
I still have the physical disc release for Deluxe sitting around. An ancient game that still runs well off of Steam, solid pick for anyone enjoying early 2000s game era stuff.
One of my all time favorite games.  After a while you can kind of figure out what combinations work to keep your Sims happy and building, but I just like building cities.

This game is what we call infinite single player, the endless chase of building a city and perfecting every street and class to the endless potential of your city, your region and your taste. I got this game free from steams 5$ drop 2019 and can't complain. Would have chose nothing else for 5 on it m8s!

This is my favorite city building game, and for good reason. It's rare that a game can endure longer than 10 years, but this is one of those games that I keep coming back to again and again. This is one of my all time favorite games.

Steam only displays 6 hours. I have more like 600 and that isn't including friends and family that played it on my PC's over the years. This game's mechanics still hold up and numerous imitators still haven't nailed what this old game has. 
I own the CD but also grabbed on steam to have a digital copy as well. Silly? Perhaps. I got on deep discount so I didn't care.
This game covers it all and then some and can be a little hard to figure out how to get started. But building a bustling city in real life is no easy feat! Great game!

Abhorrent plague of imperialistic suburban spread..
gave way more detail and time to suburban infrastructure than urban.
the basis of the lego movie hit song everything is awesome

city planner game without all the knowledge base that Civ games offer.

The granddaddy to city builders, this is the 4th installment of the amazing SimCity. This is perhaps my favorite of the series.

I'd suggest you download some mods for this, that way your cities can be better unique and more fun.

Also, it has the classic Maxis humor that we all know and love.

Old, but still good, and once you get the hang of it, it becomes extremely fun to try new techniques, ultimately you'll find out that the sick evil mayors get the best populations to maintain well, and the let's have a nice city doesn't come as easy. :)

Highly recommended, but watch a YouTube tutorial first, I recommend looking up Rob Simcity 4 on there.

Still holds up, even years later. Very solid, intricate mechanics and huge region maps will keep you playing for hours. Add in the Network Addon Mod, and hours turn into days as you strive to not only design your dream city, but also ensure that most (if not all) aspects of it remain functional and, perhaps most importantly, profitable. Every mistake teaches you a lesson on what to do (and what not to do), and there is much to learn.

I could go on for hours, but I'm not going to waste your time with a lengthy review. SimCity 4 is relaxing and rewarding, and well worth your time and money.

Thanks for reading.

Its a great game, but save every 10 minutes and build from one short edge to the next. Keep your industrial and power separated by agricultural, then residential or commercial. Pollution is difficult to mitigate once a system is built. and always stay on top of water, garbage, power, train, and commercial freight. It's a great game!

These kinds of games aren't really my type, but I did have fun with this one. It's really simple, a lot is done for you, and it's easy to just jump in and start building a city. I'd say if you want to get into this genre, this is a good place to start (I had also tried Cities Skylines, but getting the power, plumbing, etc all connected to every building just seemed like a bit much for me)

Gioco veramente fantastico a differenza di Simcity 5 (2013)
Regioni ampie e possibilità di personalizzarle come si vuole, meccaniche fantastiche e non mancheranno i soliti problemini da sindaco, che, col tempo e con la pratica risolverete in poco tempo.
Certo, il gioco è vecchio e la grafica lascia un po' a desiderare, ma se si ha un computer scarso è una valida alternativa a Cities:Skylines, in quanto non dovrebbe presentare molti problemi vista la grafica molto semplice.
L'unico difetto (Opinione Personale) è la mancanza di un sistema Multigiocatore. Anche se, vi è possibile tramite l'uso di qualche modifica e di qualche programma giocare tramite la vostra connessione internet con i vostri amici.
Lo consiglio veramente.

Super engaging for those who were a fan of the Roller Coaster Tycoon style simulation games! However, I do think that the learning curve in this game will steer many away from playing and enjoying it to its fullest. Graphics are typical of the early 2000s so don't expect glistening smooth textures or crazy special effects. Overall this can be seen as one of the better classic simulator titles.

Fun game play....as long as it doesn't crash

A good update from Simcity 3000 (for the most part, I do prefer how ordinances and advisers worked in 3000). Improved graphics and mechanics for regions are welcome updates for this game. However I am not a fan of the auto-pan feature for disasters as this has destroyed several zones I was in the middle of building. While it is cool to be able to move in sims and see their commentary, I miss the citizen comments from simcity3000 as they could have special interactions such as enact an ordinance (also more in line with actual city hearings, if you are a policy nerd like me). The god feature is kind of sadly lacking in the simple design. 

But more importantly, this game has constant crashes. Save often. The game now just wigs out when I last attempted to play (all the tool bars just keep flashing) so I have now had to uninstall, which is too bad.

While it is a fun game, I cannot recommend something that simply will not play.

To me, Simcity 4 Deluxe represents the ultimate experience regarding city building. It's a true reference and even Cities Skylines can't match it. 

Good Points: 
*Unlike CS, you don't have to spend more money on DLCs as the only one extension which has been released for SC4 is included in this Deluxe Edition.
*The extremely resourceful SC4 modding community which offers you thousands of free content even today allowing you to build a very personalized city.
*Very reliable game which works on every machine even the ones which are not made for gaming.
*Bugs occur very rarely 

Less good points:
*Graphics are pretty low regarding today standards even if it adds some charm to it.
*The weather doesn't change but it can be fixed with mods.
*Mods are pretty voluminous and often require to download extra dependencies to work correctly so be sure to have enough space on your hard drive if you choose to use mods.

Enjoy!

I recomend this game to people who can live without Nam but with Update 37 out I would say the one qaullity of life mod will make the game unplayable. Its still a fun game and you should still give it a go.

One of the greatest Tycoon Games i ever played
its funny, exciting and there is always something to do
the missions where you drive a vehicle are my favourite part of the Game :D
Brought me back to the good old days of Sims 1. I really enjoyed playing. It's like city skylines, but overwhelming difficult to start off to make a city succeed. I love how challenging the game is!

An old game that aged well. It is still rather fun to play, works smoothly in linux with proton and the graphics just happened to be made in a way where it doesn't hurt to look at even today. Old games can age quite great when devs focus on the gameplay experience instead of putting all their resources into cutting edge graphics and cool new technologies that won't be relevant years later.

I love this game. One thing I would mention though: you're definitely going to want to install some mods. The steam version does not include widescreen support, and the base game has some pretty irritating bugs. EA is done updating this, but thankfully the mod community has stepped up to fill the gaps. There is STILL a somewhat active community for SimCity 4 modding (as of 7/1/2020). Reddit and Simtropolis can guide you.

I highly recommend using the Network Addon Mod (NAM). It drastically improves your sims' transit ai and provides so many other transit options that the base game feels incomplete without it.

If your buying this game for mac i would very much recommend it as that game version is very stable and reliable with very few crashes. If you are buying this for windows i cannot recommend it as that game version after alot of play time crashes quite often and gets worse the more you play till eventually it becomes unplayable. This game is a classic title and very much a defining game of my childhood, the only negative thing i could possibly say about this game is the crashing issues with windows 10 and the in game demand issues which are fixable with mods other than that this game is a must have for any sandbox and tycoon players.

Ive played Simcity since day one. I bought this cheap to play it once gain for the first time in 5+ years and this version is not playable, it crash's all the time. This is the only game that has crashed on this PC in 4 years and its pretty consistent.

I love this game and would recommend it to anyone as the quintessential city builder. It's still head and shoulders above its competitors. Although its not perfectly suited to modern computers, this problem is easily fixed by changing the launch options. Theres some good advice on how to do it on simtropolis.
its a fun, technical and highly complex game. however certain mods and patches are needed for it to function as intended due to the nature of how E-vil A-dministration and Maxis left it unfinished

I bought this game because I saw it on steam and remembered playing it about 10 years ago so I bought it. It has some bugs and crashes every now and then, but I still managed to binge it for 6 hours straight after getting it.
Though it's an older game, there is a lot of user-generated content to keep things fresh. I love this because it's easy to learn, but provides an infinite amount of replayability.

(ENGLISH)
A little about SimCity.  It's a strategy and building game.  You play as a mayor and you are in charge of building the city.  The game looks ridiculous at first and discourages with its graphics or age.  The game was released in 2003. I was surprised when I turned on the tutorial and saw so many options and things there.  SimCity pulled me in, and only during the tutorial in which I spent an hour.  Gradually, I learned all the things and I still don't remember anything about it and I'll have to start it again.  There is a very elaborate economy in the game, which I did not expect as much elaborated in detail as, for example, paying taxes, paying rents from citizens and others.  The game is simply great and every builder will love it.  Some + and -  
----------------------------
+ Price (you can buy a key from the internet for less than 3 euros) 
+ many options and thing 
+ creating your own terrain for the city 
+ real economy 
+ mods 
-------------------
 -It takes until you learn to build and control properly.  
-bugs but 2003 :) 
- can become boring 
- problems on newer computers 


7/10

The best city builder out there in terms of looks, especially with the right mods. The isometric artstyle aged like fine wine, and the detail really makes it.
The gameplay is relatively simple, it becomes a casual game once you learn the economy basics. Still the rules aren't there as complex mechanics, but rather as guidelines for your bonsai-handcrafted-miniature to look realistic enough.

i love this game. so  much to watch and do. you build a city and watch it grow. i love when thing happen and you have repair your city. i love the many building that appear. so very cool. also you never will run out of cash if you do this game right. i am good at small to medium cities. but the Pros can make million sim cities no pun intended lol. also if you do this game right you could get 1000s or hours of enjoyment. :)

A classic city simulator. It gives me great nostalgia. Used to play it on CD. Definitely not as advanced as some of the more recent variations of simulators, but certainly worth it if you enjoy these types of games from the 2000s.
It doesn't quite rival SimCity 3000, but I love it and played it hours on end back in the day nonetheless.
Recommend getting it when it's on deal, but if you enjoy sims, I don't think it will disappoint.

Its simple to understand, has a ever active modding community, looks great and still runs great for its age, and has endless replay value. Make a small farming village or an industrial mega city; the choice is yours.

I had this game back in the day on my mum's old work computer running Windows XP. Considering that was over 10 years ago i was very surprised to find out that it still holds up in my mind. I would pay a lot for a remaster of this masterpiece.

I wish I could combine the mechanics of this game with the mod support and graphics of Cities Skylines. This an all time great City Builder and every time I play it, I weep for Simcity 5 and its tiny cities.

Sim City 4 is amazing! It's harder than Cities Skyline and brings a lot of memories, but it CRASHES like the other Maxis' games: when you're vulnerable and saved your game for the last time 2 hours ago.
I strongly recommend the nostalgia and frustration!

I've been playing this game since its release, never mind all of its predecessors. No game series has been as addicting to me in my life than SimCity, and 4 is one of their best installments. If you're interested in playing a game that rewards your compulsion to build and create balance -- or chaos -- this is a good place to find those.

Love this version of Sim City, best variety of structures and personally prefer grid squares over parametric curing streets. It also allows for user mods which is great. There are a lot of building model/texture packs out there. It does have one weakness. SAVE OFTEN, I think the game has a memory leak. It crashes intermittently despite having 64 Gigs of RAM, a i7 5960x, and a 2070 Super GFX card.

my fave part has to be how often the game crashes. it helps limit for how long and how often im willing to mess with it. my second fave part ... even after you close the game it actually stays running in the backrgound. you wouldnt notice that if you dont open task manager. ive owned this game on other machines and it was fine so i actually think the problem is steam. all my steam games run fucked up unless i close the bootstrapper and disconntect from the internets. i notice a HUGE difference playing these games based on whether or not i closed the bootstrapper and disconnected from the net. i HATE that steam is part of this equation and im an accidental customer. the first time i bought a game i was waiting for a disk in the fuckn mail and if i knew it ws cloud based i would have NEVER been a customer. now im stuck and locked in. or i can piss the money away i spent. if it had been more clear i owuld never have signed up for this fuckn worhtless bullshit. god damn assholes!!

Bought this game in Fry's long ago when I was a teenager, still have the CD-ROM.
Any person obsessed with the perfect city should play this, city regions are way bigger than Sim City 2013, allowing you to create 100M metropolis in a region. In a nutshell the game is really good despite the 2.5D graphics.

Classic game that's still good today. Totally worth the price. Was my first city building game from way back when and i'm still loving it. This and Cities skylines are probably still the best two out there.

Oh, the nostalgia. I have been playing this gem since it was released in 2003, only now I actually understand how to balance the finances and don't have to *always* resort to destroying my bankrupt trash city. (Sometimes we just do that for fun anyway amirite?) Thanks, adulthood!

It's a nearly 20 year-old game, but the extensive number of mods and additions available from a venerable fan community keep this game fresh and interesting. This game has retained its play value much more than its 2013 successor.

Great game that you can play for hours non stop or leave it for a month and jump right back into the world you were creating. You can be as detailed as you want in the game. If you wanted, you could spend a few hours making one neighbourhood or get a whole city up and running in the same amount of time.  The graphics are simple but I find myself waiting to see what new building will be built in my city.  I would recommend the game. I know I will play it for years to come

I just purchased and I have not played any version before, my usual games are Civ, Spore and those types.  If you like strategy games where you need to build slowly to keep profit over loss but also plan for future larger developments I would recommend this game.  If you are looking for a game to win there are missions that you may like but no end game scenario.

Played this game for years, it's incredibly fun and rather easy to build something amazing.  Fully customizable with mods, extensive game play, intercity co-operation, pollution doesn't leak into the next city.  Can buy/sell power, water, garbage to make your city pure.  So many features.

This is a classic game full of nostalgia. The game, as designed, is great! The resoution doesn't really translate to modern systems, though it is still pretty sweet! EA, it's 2020 and you are still doing the bare minimum! You ported this game to Steam, why could you take an extra hour of a developers time to store files in the Steam cloud storage?

This game is very fun to play and it is very addictive. The feature to drive vehicles, Planes, Boats, and even trains is mind blowing! I totally recommend this game for people who love to play a Run your own city game. I know that I have made a great purchase. 


                                                                                                                     -Mathew

You aren't the mayor this city deserves, nor the one it needs right now. But you are the one who can commandeer any civilian or military vehicle at whim and go storming through the streets in a nihilistic rampage. So there's that.

Best City Simulator on the planet.  This game has literally motivated people to purse urban planning & civil engineering as their careers.   Yes, it's THAT good, especially once you get into the Modding community which took over the support of the game from the long gone Maxis.
I can hear the background sound, but there's no sound effect playing on macOS Mojave 10.14.6, MacBook Pro 15inch 2019 with Intel UHD Graphics 630 1536 MB, 2.3 GHz Intel Core i9.

It's the classic city builder simulation game from my childhood. While I have been stuck inside due to Covid-19, this has kept me entertained. This game also has a surprising amount of depth for when it came out. The music and old school visuals are great. 8/10
Great Game, I loved it back in the day and still love it today! If only the game didnt keep on crashing, not autosaving anything and making me realise I lost 3-4 hours of gameplay

Once you figure it out the money is not an issue and there is really no challenge. Just the grind. It's essentially a sand box as there is no campaign option unless i missed it. It is fun for the first hour and then you are just plugging away.

Sim City 4 is far superior to its later iterations. 
It is addicting, built on solid mechanics, and in my opinion a challenge. 

I have so much fun building cities and trying to make them make ends meet.

This game definitely did not age well. I purchased it for the nostaliga factor and for what EA and Steam are charging for it, it feels like a total rip-off. In 2003 I may have recommended this game but in 2020 I most certainly say stay away from it unless youre trying to relive the nostalgic days of 17 years ago. I guarantee games like City Skylines are far superior even if this game was good back then there are more modern and immersive titles which are just simply better to play.
I am a planner.  I like creating the landscape without the nimbys.  I do have trouble with the financial aspect; trying to do too much before the revenue is ready.

It's a good play. I played this game so much as a child and nothing will beat the memories of growing up around the game. It helped me understand basic knowledge of how the world works at a young age and i couldn't be more thankful for that.

A great game. It is nice to have a digital copy of this game instead of the old CDs which get scratched easily due to my carelessness in simply stacking them on top of one another instead of putting them away properly.

The game is more challenging than other the other Sim City games that come before and after it. You have to manage a monthly budget instead of yearly, and even on Easy mode, you can run out of money if you're not careful.

One thing that is missing from this version of the game is an automatic region generator. It will take a couple hours to properly craft an interesting and diverse region, but I feel like it is more honest to use the pre-made regions than to craft your own.

When I make my own region, I set it up so it's easy to make ferries. In the pre-made regions, it's often a struggle to reform the land to fit the ferry buildings properly, so the cheap cost of the ferry compared to a bridge may be negated.

If you're looking for a fun and addictive game, I can't recommend this game too highly (meaning it's really good, not bad).

For me, this is the absolute best overall simulation city game, allowing me to dip my toes into the realms of neighborhoods, mass transit, urban design, economics and politics. While some may wish for a game that just focuses more on a few of these traits, this classic game seems to do a jack-of-all-trades sort of approach and does well in nearly all its intended niches.

An absolute classic. Spent many hundreds of hours on this game as a kid and its definitely the best simcity. Works fine on modern windows but beware of crashing. SAVE OFTEN. You can also fix the resolution for modern screens by using the launch options -CustomResolution:enabled -rWWWWxHHHHx32
Replace WWWW and HHHH with your monitors resolution and it'll look perfect. 

You should also look up the Network Addon Mod and how to install it. It adds a ton of new road and transportation pieces you can use or ignore, but most importantly it makes the roads and transit systems much more realistic in their capacity, meaning you won't have to build insanely unrealistic highway grids, subways and avenues for an 80k pop city.

Still great! been playing this game since 2007. Skylines is more of a game where as this one is more of a hobby. I mean that in a good way. Search google and you will find the communities that still actively make little pieces and parts to snap into your city. It's a lot like doing model train/town sets on the computer, especially if you decide to make your own buildings with the soft wear offered online.

Other than improving the graphics and the UI for today, can't think of a thing I'd change.  It is the perfect god game.   

You know how old someone is when you whisper EA Games....and they respond . . . Challenge EVerything!.

Its one of the games i wish it will be never boring but it is now. After 600 hours the fun is gone. Ive build the biggest map part full before only on dude was living in my city with riskymoney. Thats a way to play, that makes me addicted for this game. Just a tip. Very naise game. Bye bye SC4

This is the only city simulator where you can make cities true to scale. As great as other city sims (like Cities Skylines) are, this game allows you to create sprawling metropolises that really feel like metropolises. This game was so ahead of its time and it's a classic

Buggy, 17 years old, and finicky enough that it's tough to learn. But it is hands-down the best city-building sim there is. It blasts Simcity Societies and the reboot out of the water. Cities Skylines is a close contender but just doesn't achieve this level of complexity. 17 years old, and still the title-holder.

Amazing game, in my opinion has greater depth than the modern sim cities. Graphics aside it really was an amazing game for the time. If you had sims 2 it would port your character over to live and act as advisers on the area and tell you if it needed improving or not (I doubt this is implemented on this version).
Its down fall was grid locks, but rush hour came out and improved road options so much you could continue to push your city to greater limits. It was a add-on that made sense, it fixed the game and wasnt just an empty money grab like many add-ons today.
If you can stomach the old mid 2000's graphics and want to try or relive this game buy it. Its well worth it, great depth, a true feeling of running a city (most notably the traffic), and hours of entertainment. I doubt the hundreds I got when it new and fresh but certainly many hours of fun left in this classic title.
Obviously not worth $20, however if a good sale is going on and you don't mind looking for mods on the internet to fix some of the weaker features this game offers, it's one heck of a good time!

I have loved SimCity in all its versions since the 1990's! It's a great, single-user, city building game. It's not like Sid Meier's Civilization series because there's no need to worry about strategies and fighting and trading with other civilizations. It's just you, your income/budget, taxes, and creating beautiful towns, cities, regions. It's relaxing yet challenging and I love being able to find and create MOD's and building LOTs, etc. for the game. For those I go to Simtropolis.com which is only 1 community dedicated to this game. I highly recommend if you love a relaxing, yet challenging game that simulates realistic city building, including getting to drive around in the very cities you created!
I mean its a fun and classic game. Always the one or two frustrating things that happen when you play but that's what a real city government is like too.
This is a true classic. It's a masterpiece in its own right, and was ahead of its own time in some regards. If you love city building and management games, this is for you!

Excellent game for learning how a city runs. You are the mayor and you get to decide all aspects of keeping a city running. Keeping the city happy is your job while at the same time, balancing the budget and growing the city is the challenge. You control road, taxes, city zoning, police departments, fire departments, and parks.  Cities can be connected and make deals that help you raise money.
Brings back memories. Just sit and click and point and build a city. If you USED to play this start again, and if you are new and want an easy-going yet challenging simulation - try this!

I've been playing this game on and off for over 10 years and it is STILL the most wonderful city building game ever! The level of detail on the buildings, the maps, the customization! You can track where and how people travel from any building, any method! I am still amazed at this game in 2020 at how incredible it is.

By far the best Sim City game that has been released to date. This game may be 16+ years old, but has absolutely survived the test of time, so I would highly recommend this game for a great Sim City experience. Don't forget to check out all the mods and other extras out there as well. The only real problem is it may occasional crash by just randomly closing down the game (system remains fine). Therefore, don't forget to manually save as it only saves when prompted so only when going to the regional map.
game has stopped working on me multiple times. How are you supposed to play a strategy game when you have to save it every 10 min in fear of losing your work

Great game! It is a blast to play, especially if you want some mindless play time! I would recommend going through the tutorials though! My cities kept going bankrupt until I took the time to learn. Would give it a 4.5 out of 5. There is a glitch that is a bit annoying where crime is high near airports. There is no fix to this as far as I can tell.
easy to get the hang of, but still a challenge. very chill game to play, been one of my go-to's for about a decade now. still not tired of it.

I have a higher end computer that can run The Sims 3 with only minor fuss, but this game runs poorly. Graphical issues such as discolored tiles and blank black spots on maps, freezing, crashing, intense bouts of lag. Tells me its a poorly optimized game for steam rather than a computer issue.

Love Sim City. 4 is the ultimate to me, I know it's older and Cities Skylines is the new normal, but I just couldn't get into Skylines; don't know why. I did enjoy the townships of Sim City 2015? but it also lacked the subtlety I enjoyed about Sim City 4. In the 2015 I would just grid it out and fill each available place to the edge of the map: I felt I never truly understood the school system (like if I have mass transit or a fleet of local school buses, if I have bus stops why can't one school be enough so I can limit population, but also educate my work force.) It just never clicked for me, aesthetically it was nice to look at... but I'm getting way off point, SimCity 4 has everything I want and I always come back to it every four months for some reason.

Anyway, is anybody actually buying this game in 2019, ha.

I really enjoy this game. You will basically become the Major of a city and from there youll have to deal with almost all the aspects of life, health, mobility, police, industry, crime, education, etc... I really like it. Totally recommended.

This take took a long time to be able to fully understand and have fun with. Regardless, it was all fun gaming.
Take your time. It takes a bit to warm up to.

Don't let my hours fool you. I probably have like 2k hours in this game, however 99% of that was on non-steam versions. Anyways, I'll review this with my typical pro/con style to keep things simple.

Cons:

1. This game likes to crash, and this seems to be an issue that is exclusive to the steam version. Expect your game to crash every 2-4 hours regardless of the size of your cities. My advice, save as often as you can.

2. This is an old game, so it doesn't play nice with higher resolutions. This is a bit annoying as there are constantly black bars on either side of my screen because this game does not offer 16:9 aspect ratio. Again, this is to be expected as it is an old game. Supposedly there are some workarounds for this issue but I haven't tried very many of them myself.

Pros:

1. Mods!!! You aren't playing this game right if you don't have an account on both Simtropolis.com and SC4Devotion.com

2. Probably one of my favorite video game soundtracks of all time. Its absolutely perfect.

3. The community is still going fairly strong even in 2019. If you have any questions or technical issues with this game, there is no shortage of help to be found on the forums.

If you like city builders, do yourself a favor and get this game. Also, if you're curious as to what is possible with mods, head on over to the True Earth Journal on Simtropolis. It's truly mind blowing what people have accomplished with this game.

This is the city building game that outshines all others. I seem to recall they had one with an online component but I prefer this version. I have been playing Simcity for decades (off and on)... it is so addictive.

Look, yes, it's an old game.  But it's still the best city-building game there is next to Cities Skylines.  It's extremely detailed with a great soundtrack, good UI and good mechanics for building all the cities you want, though it's difficult to succeed if you've never played this kind of game before.  The fixed camera angles are a little annoying, but once you get over that it's a game you can sink many hours into.  (I've played much, much more of this game than Steam knows.)  Would recommend.

There is a way to create a city in this game that never dies (with a low ranking cheat +1000cash). You basically build a city and lots and lots of trees and a trash recycling that burns trash and makes lots of pollution but build lots and lots of trees to absorb the city's bad air and make everything last 'for a very very long time'. Then just watch the city go on... you can make this city go on theoritically for over 100000 years...

Best city builder. Haven't found one that compares, even though this is a glitchy mess that doesn't allow for different city types. It's either go big or go home. Still, really love this game. Maybe it's nostalgia talking.
I still enjoy this game after so many years, but the other reviews are correct.  The random crashes and other bugs still exist, and will never be fixed.  So save often lol.

While quite old at this point, it's still a solid citysim experience. And it's the last classic Simcity game before EA done fucked them up. The biggest downside is that all cities look like they're from the USA. No postclassical buildings here, no old town city centres. It's all just modern styles (well, except for the landmarks). Then again, there aren't many citysims that include that anyway, so meh.

Generally, what's fun in this is that you do get to build relatively realistic and detailed cities. Yes, Cities Skylines is way better at that, but it was also done with much more modern technology. This came out in 2003 after all. But you have three zone types (Residential, Commercial, Industrial) with three degrees each (Light, Medium, Heavy), except for Industial, which also includes Agricultural zones as a separate one. You get to choose between a decent variety of power generation, water, and waste disposal facilities, and also have to think about providing educational healthcare, security, and firefighting services for your citizens. Parks and beautification has tonnes of options, whether parks of various kinds, plazas, or recrational facilities like ball parks, tennis courts, playgrounds, or even beaches and marinas, listed from smallest to biggest. Public transportation is an option for those who want in, with the classic bus/train/subway options available, as well as larger scale alternatives such as ferries, cruise ships and aircraft available as well.

It's got most of what you want, and what these categories don't include, you can receive as rewards for achieving certain milestones or completing certain missions (you can drive cars around your streets and roads!). This includes universities, military bases, research facilities, highsec prisons, administrative buildings, a statue of yourself, you name it. Naturally, SimCity 4 also comes with its fair share of Landmarks, buildings you can plop down anywhere that will generate some tourism for you. These have a bit more stylistic variety, drawn (mostly) from all over the developed world. The range of available buildings, however, feels much more limited than in SimCity 3000, sadly.

If you get bored with building and managing your citizens, you can always send some natural (and some unnatural) distasters their way. Complaining too much? Send a meteor strike, a tornado, an earthquake or a volcano to ruin their day right back. Or if you're feeling like adding that little extra, you can always send flying saucers or a giant space robot (i.e. Servo from The Sims 1) to blast them to smithereens. Sometimes, it's intensely enjoyable!

All in all, the limited features compared to Cities Skylines makes this game definitely show its age. Still, this is one of those big classic games that set the bar back in the day, and it's certainly the best among the SimCity series. If you're into management games, I can wholeheartedly recommend sinking some tens of hours into this game, if just to experience it, as an extra alternative to the other management games you might have.

Even 16 years after its release, there has never been another city building simulator just like Sim City 4, whose sophistication and complexity was well ahead of its time. Offering unlimited replay value, flexibility and accommodation for play-styles, while at once having a high skill ceiling, this is the perfect game.

The moment when you unpause after carefully laying the roads and zones and watch the buildings rise is pure bliss.

But, beware, Sim City 4 will test your sanity as you fight to enforce symmetry and order upon the land.

This Lovecraftian Horror shall shatter your insignificant hairless ape mind as you gaze into the impossible alien geometry.

If you're a classics fan, for sure you will still like this game. It's difficult to review it almost at the end of 2019. Basically, you build cities, you can connect the economy of a city with another: have a city where you only build factories, and a city with people who can go work for the factories. This way, your city with people is not polluted, you can also have a very rich city where you just sell resources to other cities (like water, power, garbage space).
I believe for its time, and beyond is very well taught. I have looked at new city building games, and other than the graphics, they haven't impressed me with cool mechanisms.
You can also have missions to help your citizens escape the city (after winning some money). You also get a chance to build a casino by doing these missions. There's also the option to be the police and catch the guys. This won't give you any money, but at least you will make people happy and like you as a mayor. Depends what you need: the votes or the money?
When the game sees that your funding is going down, you receive buildings which bring profit. But don't place them near your population, they bring pollution and unhappiness to your citizens.
It feels good to be the mayor, organize different cities for economy, population, resources. The building is not very complicated, but if you want to make a beautiful city, I recommend some tutorials or just investing some time to discover the tools you need.
Overall, it's a very good and simple building game. The graphics are outdated, of course, but the gameplay offers the satisfaction of winning over your cities.

SimCity 4 is an aptly named old classic and revolves around its take on the city-building, simulation category. Though not without its faults, the game does keep one entertained in creating and governing a city, or several cities that are interconnected on the regional map. The game has aged quite well and the graphics looks pretty decent given that the game is over fifteen years old at the time of this writing. If you were one of those kids that played with building blocks or used a lot of imagination, then you'll likely find something here--it's almost cathartic watching how your precious city and the countryside that you've created come alive in the game. Observe how your masterpiece grows and becomes populated by Sims as they go about their daily lives, and act accordingly! The level of detail--visually and managerial--is honestly quite good. Later on, you can even take a short break from the city-building aspect of the game to do optional missions within the city such as flying a medical helicopter to save a citizen's life, wrecking havoc like a lunatic in an army tank, or evading the police in your hijacked car with its indecent bumper sticker. It's like GTA-lite.

Nostalgic as the game is, the game has several flaws. It could mar your enjoyment of the game momentarily or it could become an exercise in frustration. An accidental misclick or two could be quite disastrous--and there is no Undo! (Hoped you saved.) Getting objects to align and orient correctly is sometimes difficult. Made even more difficult for certain users (i.e., some laptop users) who must use a combination of keys to click Home and End (which rotates objects) while attempting to hold down the mouse key without movement in their click-and-drag operation. (Go where I want you to go, dangit! I need an extra arm!) The tutorials within the game are, frankly, inadequate. What they do cover, they do well. However, given the range of tools you have on-hand in building your city, it falls woefully short. For example, the game's tutorials nor its manual cover anything about how to properly connect highways to your city's existing infrastructure; and mistakes while figuring things out like this if you don't know how beforehand can cost you dearly. (Nooo! Don't sink that entire city block into the sea...) And unlike other versions of SimCity, including older iterations, there are no random map generators nor challenge scenarios, and one wonders why that's the case. Heck, you cannot even simply load new regions into the game without some legwork outside the game. That's an outright fail. Fortunately, there is a vibrant community of mapmakers for SimCity 4, and there are programs and guides that makes things easier. Despite a number of hassles and issues like these, the game does fulfills its aim at being a great city-building, simulation game.

Some Helpful Links:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=279736936
Guide to play SC4 if you're having trouble getting it to run.
This is what I used in my command lines (and it's a nice reminder for myself): -CPUCount:1 -CPUPriority:Low -CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -w -intro:off
The resolution bit is important to keep Windows from screaming at you, lol.

https://community.simtropolis.com/
http://www.sc4devotion.com/forums/
A couple of communities that has everything from new regions (maps), to building guides, and new assets to modify your SC4 gaming experience.

TLDR: Franchise that gave birth to the genre failed to bring it to the modern age. Play Cities:Skylines instead. Dated UI and primitive engine here. 

Management games are complex things, under the hood, and often in operation as well, finding games that can marry that complexity, while offering all the wealth of details to the player while not hurting the learning curve or interactivity too hard is a difficult balancing act. 

The Sim City franchise set up the foundations, but somewhere along the lines became as much about its own brand name than the genre itself, and it ended up getting outcompeted.

This game is stuck somewhere between WIndows XP and Windows Vista in terms of user interface and game design conventions.

 Removing permanently for declutter.

Holds up to the rigors and tests of time, which is more than I can say for this game's predicessors. That being said, 2000 will ALWAYS hold a special place in my life and heart (as it was on PlayStation when I didn't have a computer and the music on PSX was WAAAAAAY cooler than PC). I played SimEarth on SNES and SimCity on the same, I then played 3000U on PC. I loved that game, it helped me to waste away staring at a computer screen and satiate my need/desire for micromanagitis. Sim games are a dime a dozen, GOOD sims are rare. This one - having rather nice expansion packs (now-a-days called DLC *groan*) such as Rush Hour, and the classic Maxis SimCity music - most of it done by Jerry Martin and other very talented artists - is a great upgrade to 3000U. The Simnation alone had me sold. The ability to have more than one city on a massive nation-map blew me a way. I felt like this game was far ahead of its time and felt like the next step, where 3000U felt like 2000 with pretty graphics and a few new things, and whatever the new SimCity game is - it feels like a gigantic step backwards and sideways into microtransactions and the obvious advantage-taking of a fanbase that EA aquired - one that Maxis earned. This is the last great SimCity game, for me, and will remain the last one I play. (Cities: Skylines is fantastic, and a season pass plus game equals a complete-feeling experience). I still show people this game, and introduce them into the world of SimCity (Maxis) and this is the end-all for them and me.

The game has its drawbacks, bad spots and sore points -not being able to rotate a building you are putting in, the reluctance of people to take any kind of mass transit unless you make it impossible for them to drive (thus limiting your own capabilities in missions), the way some missions are designed or end up generating due to RNG fails (Don't get spotted by an ice cream truck.. by the way, 2/3 of the cars are now ice cream trucks, Drive the train from the station here to the one behind you... by the way there's no reverse, Catch the robber before he drives out of the city.. by the way we're spawning him 10 seconds away from the edge of the city), but really... there is no perfect game and overall, these are fairly minor problems.

If you're after a decent city-builder with a bit of nostalgia and still use Windows 7... this is a good game to look into -as long as it's under $10 (really... if it's over $10, don't get it. I bought this exact game -with Rush Hour and its other expansions-  on CD for $20 and that was 8 years ago... don't get it if it's more than $10).

Sim City games were a big part of my childhood. I played the SNES version of the first Sim City. Then I played Sim City 2000 and noticed the improvements. When Sim City 3000 was released, I remember being impressed by the more realistic looking graphics. Sim City 3000 Unlimited added more content too. I was excited about Sim City 4 because of the fact you can build a whole region of cities. In previous games, you only built one city and can only imagine what the neighboring cities looked like.

Anyway, I liked the options for this game and the improvements in the graphics (at that time of course). It was good seeing a series evolve over time. For example, I liked how they gave farming buildings its own separate category under the Industrial option. In Sim City 3000, you had to zone low-density industrial tiles and meet certain conditions, like no pollution, before farms will appear. It is the same deal with high-tech companies even though they still don't get their own category in Sim City 4.

Now some people have complained about Sim City 4 being too complicated for beginners or casual gamers, and so EA Games ended up releasing Sim City Societies and Sim City 5. Like Command and Conquer, Sim City was an iconic game during my childhood and teens before EA Games killed them off.

As far as new city building games go, Sim City isn't that impressive anymore. During the 90s, however, it did seem Sim City was the only fun city-building game that was available so I am happy we have more options now.

Next stop ooh la la estates, In my opinion this is the best city building game I've played. I think its better then the newer simcity games to be honest. Controls are simple, most of it is point and click. you have to work on a regions economy for larger city's to work better. You get to build your own regions from scratch.

SimCity 4 Deluxe may have some age to it, but its still a great gem to replay from time to time. The gameplay is easy to get into - the tutorials help a lot - and I like the region system in the game - you can make use of the pre-made ones in the game, create your own, or import one made by the modding community.

I love adjusting the map tile you choose with the terrain tools, plus deciding on the difficulty you want to play on when starting a city. The graphics are good, even on modern systems; although you need some patches to improve the screen resolution to higher ratios. I also love the reward system in the game and the driving missions - they're a nice diversion with the added benefit of unlocking rewards before you have the needed requirements for them.

The only issues I have with the game is the traffic mechanics are not great, and the game may crash without warning if not patched. That said, the modding community provides a nice selection of extra buildings, transit options and themes to use, and there are some tools available to help with region creation and refining.

Overall,  the game is still a wonderful one to play, and definitely should be in your collection, especially if you love Cities: Skylines.

This is hands-down one of my most-played games of all time. And I'm going to echo what many have said here already, but it's all true.

First, the game itself is really well-designed. I mean the core of the game. Building progression, fiscal system, neighbor and region dynamics, etc. It's really something to watch the local economy grow and connect with the regional market. Civic administrators can get really, really granular about the budget and infrastructure, enough to satisfy even the most hardcore micromanagers. The in-game missions for extra mayor points are so-so, but you can completely ignore them and do just fine.

But the REAL fun and creativity comes from the SC4K community. I mean, the sheer number of mods available are simply astounding and are a testament to the passion people have (STILL) for this game. Some mods are so useful, in fact, that I simply won't play SC4K without them: NAM makes the traffic simulation much saner than stock and I take great satisfaction in the aesthetic and functional enhancements the Road Top Mass Transit Addon give the game. But it doesn't end there: you can give your entire city a visual makeover, put your hometown city hall in the game, force all trains to go _under_ streets, give your city limitless power, or even have the trees change color with the seasons!

I've played this game to death, and I'll keep playing it as long as it runs on my computer. The Steam install is painless and it's very easy to enhance the game with start options to match modern screen resolutions.

10/10 have played, play and will keep playing again, and again, and again. :)

Even though it's now more than a decade old this is still my favorite city simulator and easily ranks in my top 5 games of all time.  Intuitive design, ease of use, and simple non-dramatic planning tools.  How do you not own and love this game?

This classic game holds up, in my opinion. It's the funnest never-balancing spreadsheet you'll probably ever find. One of the overlooked features is the ability to designate individual buildings so they'll never renovate, coupled with the ability to re-name individual buildings. I often save a little house or mansion in the heart of my city and rename it as a museum, community centre, clubhouse, or whatever, to give my cities some imaginary RPG elements as well.

This game being from 2003, has aged remarkably well. I still play once in a while working on a region with hundreds of mods installed. The parts of this game that make me love it are the isometric graphics, the free-drive mode, the music, the whole multiple city-regional gameplay aspect, and of course, the mods. SimCity 2013 was a major let down, and no other city simulator game has taken this one off the top of my list yet.

Still a great game nearly 15 years later. However, you will need to download the SC4 Launcher to utilize larger borderless resolutions and to set the game engine to run on only 1 core for modern, multicore machines to prevent crashes. I also recommend downloading the NAM and other related graphical mods/plugins from Simtropolis.

This game is timeless. I can honestly say I can see myself coming back to this one again and again in the foreseeable future, or at least until EA can provide a worthy sequel. And, while I know that there are similar games out there that improve upon SimCity 4's outdated graphics and aging AI, there is a certain magic in its complicated simplicity, its restrictive options, and its vastly customizable resource library.
There are aspects of the game that are well worth criticism. The AI is horrendous, especially on driving missions. I cannot count the times I've failed a mission because an AI car crashed into me trying to pathfind itself out of my way because of my siren. Or the times an AI car has magically appeared on top of me, making my vehicle exploed. Or the times I've started a mission that finishes within seconds because the AI target spawned right next to the city border. Or the train missions that were initiated on the wrong side of the tracks (how can I travel east if the train is spawned facing west on a one-way track?). Or the times I've failed a mission because I have angered Uncle Vinnie for no apparent reason.
But these results of the game's age should not and cannot discourage players away from the immersive city planning, the multitude of factors that influence construction, the possibility of building and terraforming an entire map from scratch, and, above all, the customizability of the game's resources that allows for stellar modding.
If you have lots of free time or you're just looking for some mindless yet mindful fun to relax after work or school, SImCity 4 is well worth its meager price. And, much like the hopefuls still expecting Half-Life 3, I will forever wait for that worthy sequel that will take the best elements from this game and dress them in modern graphics and intelligence.

This game isn't perfect. Being released in 2003 (14 years ago!) and having almost zero updates since then means that this game isn't really made for current machines. It still works, but there are resolution issues and some minor issues that might arise (I haven't had any on this computer, but my old one had some).

However, I whole-heartedly believe this is still one of the best city-builders out there. The graphics aren't amazing but they really let you appreciate the scale of the cities you can create. 

The terrain generator can take some practice to make interesting, natural-looking landscapes, but it is pretty deep and can let you create anything you like if you have the patience for it. 
The city-builder is where this game shines though. There's so much depth to it. You start off with an empty plot of land and can basically go nuts. It's so damn satisfying starting off with a small town and slowly growing it, zoning higher-density lots in the middle of town, and before you know it you've got a sweet city. With decent education, health and stuff like parks, richer people move in, and the inner-city shops are replaced by towering office blocks, and cheap apartment blocks are replaced by grand towers with beautiful gardens. It certainly rewards patience and careful planning.

But why stop there? Make another city in an adjacent block of land and build another! Linke them up with roads and railways, and now you have neighbour cities! Now you can specialise your cities. Don't want your cities to have all that power-hungry, polluting industry? Have an industry-only city and put all your residential in another! Neighbour cities share demand, and you can even share power, water and garbage disposal between cities so eventually it'll transform from several linked cities to one massive metropolis.

I could go on, but I'll leave it there.

If you love city-builders, this game is fantastic. An older game, but can still compete with the best games of today. Definitely recommend.

SimCity 4 is a classic city building simulator, representing the peak of the SimCity franchise and the foundation upon which Cities Skylines was crafted. SimCity 4 packages the series' trademark complex yet accessible simulation in a refreshed fully 3D world and expands upon its predecessors by offering multi-city region play and, through the Rush Hour expansion, a deeper, more realized traffic and mass transit management element. SimCity 4 is truly a gem in the crown of PC simulation games.

I'll admit I was late to the SImCity 4 party, playing this a good few years after it came out (this was before Steam existed, I think). I had played SimCity 2000 when it released (both on PC and Playstation 1, if you can believe that) and so I had some familiarity with the franchise. And yeah, it meets every little bit of expectation you could have for a city builder made by the guys who invented city builders.

So what is it?
--------------

SimCity 4 is exactly what it says on the box. It's a city simulator that puts you in charge of building a city. When I was a kid, I thought the goal of SimCity was to try to fill up the map as much as possible and call it good. Not the case. SimCity 4 was the game that taught me that these games require a lot of micromanagement, from regulating taxes to balancing a budget to ensuring that your virtual citizens are happy and content. It doesn't sound like a lot of fun, but the bare-bones description that I'm giving the whole process doesn't sum up the joy you feel when you finally see parts of your city develop and evolve as the game goes on.

Is there anything good about this game?
-------------------------------------------

There is so much good about this game, that this review would quickly devolve into the ramblings of a rabid fanboy. The ability to do what you want with the terrain, connect cities in the same region, and basically customize your map to how you see fit is something that makes each city and region feel like it's yours. And when you're done with it, you can select from a list of disasters to blow it all up and start over. Little things like this is what makes it easy to come back to SimCity 4 even though there are other excellent city builders out there.

The game makes building a city pretty easy, especially going through the tutorials. There's a little bit of a learning curve, and trying to rush out the gates is a bad idea. The game is about the journey, not the destination. Once you figure out how to balance your budget and take your time, your city will be growing in no time.

Is there anything bad about this game?
-----------------------------------------

The traffic, I guess. The base game starts to have problems when cities get too big. Bringing in mods help, but some of the traffic mods have a steeper learning curve than the game itself. Installing them can be a pain too, because there's no Steam Workshop for SimCity 4. Everything comes off of third-party websites.

The graphics also look dated, but then again, the game is over 10 years old. I wouldn't recommend graphics holding you back if city builders interest you at all. They can easily be looked past.

Let's talk about achievements.
--------------------------------

There are none. But the region screen is pretty cool to look at after you've worked on it for a couple of years.

So, overall, do I recommend SimCity 4?
-----------------------------------------

God yes. Even if you have Cities:Skylines (which is phenomenal, by the way), pick this one up as well. It's a little older looking, a little rough around the edges, but it's a super satisfying game to play as well. And you can get it for $5 most of the time.

How much do I love this game?  So much that adding it to my Steam library marks the third time I've paid for it.  Altogether, I wouldn't be surprised if I've got 10,000 hours into it.  I've been playing it pretty frequently since it came out in 2003, back when EA was still letting Maxis be Maxis and the dev team was so responsive that when the first update rolled out, it actually included UI improvements that I'd suggested.  Updates and the Rush Hour expansion improved upon its playability and it's among the earliest games I can recall that had great and easy to access community created content - they built upon the groundwork they'd laid with SC3000 and The Sims.  The version currently on Steam is the most stable one I've played and there's still a somewhat active community playing this game.  If you're having any trouble getting it to run, look up how to edit the launch options.  As far as I can tell, with a little tweaking it still runs on pretty much every machine.

A lot of people praise SimCity 2000 as the grand achievement of Maxis Entertainment. NAY I SAY! SimCity 4, I say, holds that crown (And definitely not because I'm too young to have nostalgia about the other one because it's 10 years older). SimCity holds a special place in my heart. From the day my dad bought me this on CD, until I bought it on Steam just for the hell of it, SimCity 4 has been the pinnacle of simulation games for me. But the fun of this game doesn't come from just nostalgia. Before handing the crown to City Skylines, this game offers some of the most diverse and intimate city planning while keeping the game difficulty below that of a real city planner. The game offers a well run city planner, allowing you to develop city a diverse metropolis while keeping you on your toes in difficulty. In reality, the games worth still lies in that same nostalgia. If you're looking for the best city planner right now, head on over the City Skylines, they've got all the upgrades that this game lacks due to its time. Anyway, if you're one who remembers this game from way back when or just someone interested in the SimCity franchise, this is your game.

👌 SimCity 2000 got nothing on this gem.👌

Better than SimCity 2000 ☑️
Very nostalgic game ☑️
Offers complex city planning ☑️
Difficulty easier than real city planning ☑️
The best, modern city planner is City Skylines ☑️

FYI:
Buy with the Rush Hour DLC. Makes the game much more enjoyable for its age.

LIke a blank canvas, Simcity 4 is a city-building/simulator game where you start from building a town and grow it into a metropolis like New York and London. You plan your road layout, where zones are located, where skyscrapers are allowed to grow and where houses are to be, you set your budget and taxation and watch as people move in to your city. And apart from the original Maxis buildings plus those in Rush Hour, you can also download mods such as the Network Addon Mod, which adds new road layouts and the RealHighway, an alternative highway system for the game, the CAM which allow super-skyscrapers to grow by unlocking building stages beyond what the game allow, RTMT which allows mass-transit stations to be placed roadside without taking additional space. Check out Simtropolis and SC4Devotion, the two main website for the Simcity 4 community.

And despite this being a 2003 game, the graphics are still realistic and detailed (see from the screenshots above) compared to modern city builders.

Overall, apart from the minor performance issues and occasional CTD's, Simcity 4 is a must-have game for fans of this genre.

Although by no means perfect, Simcity 4 is probably the best (read: most detailed) city building game ever made. It simply has all of the things that would make any particular city builder great all in one place. A [i]massive[/i] area for each city, tools for laying out your city that can be either very quick and easy to use or super detailed, numerous ways to tackle different problems, interesting rewards for progress, shit, this games [i]graphs[/i] are great. The graphics and soundtrack show their age but are still great, and the absurd level of detail in every conceivable place is the icing on top. Almost everything about this game is a model example of fantastic game design. Still, if poor preformace is a deal breaker for you then you may want to take a pass; the game doesn't run terribly well on modern machines, especially with as large of cites as are possible.

How many hours, no, days of my life have not gone into this game? I don't know, but it was a lot. SimCity 4 still is the best city planning simulator ever made. It strikes just the right balance between (micro) management and sheer fun. Most remarkable about the game is that it has this great flow: at times soothing and calm, then frantic and stressing. The jazzy/atmospheric music and the pastel colours all help in creating this atmospheric sense of timelessness and universality as you are working on your city. The soundscape of cars, planes, animals, accidents all help in letting your city come to life. Of course there are faults to be found and after hundreds of hours of gameplay the game's options and diversity have been all but exhausted. City building will then no longer provide a challenge, even on hard mode. But these points are just nitpicking because there was so much fun to be had. So much wonderful creations to be engineered. SimCity 4 is a great game that I still recommend anyone to play.

A lot of people overlook this game because the SimCity that tends to be nostalgically remembered is SimCity 2000, but even ignoring graphical improvements, this game is superior to all the earlier versions in mechanics alone. There's a mind-boggling level of content in this game (not even including mods available online), and it's just sandboxy enough to let you do whatever you want, and yet there are plenty of things you have to properly work for. You can be a bad mayor, a good mayor, a hilarious mayor, or an evil mayor , and the game works no matter what you do.

One downside is it takes a really long amount of time to get a city to a proper Manhattan level where you start getting skyscrapers and such, but a lot of people would just consider that as a plus anyway (As for me, I'm ambivalent about it).

The other downside is that even though there is way more content than SimCity 2000,  there are no arcologies. RIP space blastoff.

EDIT: If only it could stop crashing. It seems to have irreparable bugs.
