I find this game an absolute blast. The graphics, I guess, are a bit outdated, and I won't say that it's the ultimate city building simulation these days. There is a very heavy emphasis on micro-managing money - too much, maybe, but I quite enjoy it. Once you crack the game though, you will soon be stomping out sky scrapers all over the place. What I find most interesting about this game, is it's 'region' based approach, where you are effectively creating a host of cities in this one huge region. They are all your cities, and you make them cooperate by way of deals. You create road connections etc, so that the sims can travel around. Just sit back and watch as you see your rich people go to work in a neighboring city, changing the scape of both cities in the process. A lovely simulation that, to some degree, really is quite realistic.

Pros

- Mods available

Cons

For those looking to get into the finite details of their city the game is for you.  Those who want to build a simple city and have fun, then you’ve found the right game. The name is quite self-explainatory...
You build your own world and then cover it in cities. In building a city, you layout property zoning and manage the provision of civil services to make sure all the little people ('sim(s)') have what they need to be happy and healthy.

It does have some dissapointment to offer...
The game casts education, labor and wealth in a very narrow-minded way. Just about all of the civil services you have to provide your people are education-related, and the only incentive to give them education is to make them more successfull and promote wealth. More wealthy community = more features and money to play with. In reality education is a life-long process. You spend your whole life learning as much as you can (ideally). Posing education as all about wealth is basically saying life is about wealth. If that is all your life is about, you are indeed a pitiful creature. I wish the design of education in the game would have been done differently. The simulation aspect of the game is very rigid. For example, if you don't want your people being brainwashed, you can kick the church and military out of town, but it won't affect anything but your city income. In reality, that would likely improve the education and crime rates of your community, but the game does not simulate with that level of depth. Your choices do not affect the gameplay, it will always happen the same way in every city. Do it right = more money, not = game over.

... but it is still fun, and even at times exciting.
You really have to put some thought into how your city should be made. There are many basic principles you will pick up on early in the game, but every time you think you have it all figured out, you will discover new problems and reasons to re-evaluate your strategy. Every city will probably be better than your last, and the progress is represented graphically in the types of buildings your people construct. Early in the game you will get mostly little boring buildings, but as your population grows accross your entire region (after you make a few decent cities), the buildings get bigger and cooler and house more people/jobs. One BIG PROBLEM with this game though is that it is very crashy. If you don't save ragularly, you will likely find yourself losing decades of development quite often.

This is a very very good city builder with lots of mod-support. 
Tips and tricks:
1: Make sure to play the game slowly in the beginning, always try to keep a bit of profit.

2: Your sims do NOT need a firestaiton, policestation nor a hospital early in the game. theese are used mostly to make your sims more productive and making sure higher income citizens come to your city. if you put them in too early then it will leave your income well below red.

3: Why just one city? Building alot of cities and connecting them with rails, highways, ferry routes and so on is very important for the growth of not just your city but for your entire region. In this game building a verý succesfull city whitout neighbouring cities will be super hard of not down right impossible.

I cannot recommend SimCity 4 highly enough - it is an absolute must-play masterpiece for any city builder fan. Even after nearly 20 years, it remains one of the greatest examples of the genre.

The addictive, accessible gameplay makes it easy to lose hours constructing your ideal city. You'll delight in fine-tuning every little detail or just jumping right in and expanding rapidly - SimCity 4 works excellently either way. The flexible playstyles provide endless replay value.

The charming visuals and whimsical soundtrack are pure joy. This is a game oozing with personality and heart. It draws you into its toy-like, miniature world filled with possibilities.

Simply put, they don't make city builders like this anymore. The thoughtful balance of complexity and accessibility is sublime. Modern games sacrifice engaging gameplay for the sake of flashy visuals, but not SimCity 4.

Sim City 4: The game to buy when you were disapointed with the latest edition to the Sim City Franchise.

Sim City has been a game that I have grown up with, and will always hold a special place in my heart for. While the graphics are certaintly not up to todays standards, the game offers hours upon hours of fun and relaxation. 

In the game, you take on the role of the mayor of a brand new city. You have to then design and build this empty plot of land into a large, and busy city. The game is nice because it offers fun and enjoyment to all skill levels. For example, one could simply just build to build, or you could go into such minute details about your city, and try fixing all of the problems. 

I have poured many hours into this game, and highly recomend it.

But as a warning: The game does not support 1920 x 1080 res, and will occasionally crash (only crashed on my laptop, works fine on my tower).

Its still everything the latest SimCity release isn't. Mod it up with new buildings, roadways, better traffic AI, maybe a custom map layout, and you can still have a lot of fun with this positively ancient game.

Hard, but that doesn't mean not good.

while simcity 3000 will remain my favorite for the rest of the conceivable future, 4 has a certain charm and depth of mechanics that makes me itch for more.

the budgeting system has been overhauled allowing for much, much more customization and indepth management of your city's utitlities, waste management, and tax revenue. whereas in 3000 you could only manage RCI taxes as a sort of umbrella for each type, in 4 you can raise and lower taxes based on the pay bracket (for commercial and residential) or the subtype (industrial, separated into agricultural, dirty industry, clean industry and high tech industry). this management allows you to pinpoint taxes where you want them, potentially driving out a class of residents or commerce, or inviting in the same.

the zoning rules have changed dramatically. whereas in 3000 you simply designate a plot of land and let the sims do the rest, in 4 each zoned lot has a facing and transportation/utilities needs that have to be met before the lot will develop. designating a large area will automatically add roads so that you don't have to micromanage each lot's transportation needs for the most part.

on the topic of transportation, roads in general have recieved an overhaul, splitting them into four classes of road, with separate capacities for travel: streets, traditional roads, avenues and highways. while the avenue, the highway, and of couse the road were availabe in 3000, the avenue was constructed by putting two roads together, and the highway was bank-breakingly overpriced. the newest addition, the street, is a low capacity form of transport that requires very little maintenance.

coming back to utility management, each utility building (water pumps, power plants, landfills) has a seperate funding slider that can be adjusted to change the output or intake of the facility in question. such a mechanic can be used to set power systems into standby, or to limit usage of over-producing plants; all very useful for a city that has just begun.

the region system is where this game really shines, however. the ability to create dozens of cities and have them all work together is simply incredible.

in short, simcity 4 is a very deep, very complicated game, but the rewards are very high. the amount of fun I've had here despite losing is roughly .75 times what I've had in 3000, which is saying something considering how much I've loved 3000.

This game is, in my opinion, the best city building game out there, but I'm not going to talk about why, I'm sure other people could do a better job than me. Instead, I'm going to explain how to fully optimize this game to get the best performance and fix some common problems.

First of all, download the SC4 Launcher and the Network Addon Mod (NAM) from Simtropolis. These two mods alone will fix 99% of the game's major problems (crashing, poor performance, and poor traffic simulation).

Outside of that, a few more minor bugs (such as the Opera House & Grand Railway bugs) can be fixed with mods, and there's literally thousands of other free mods on Simtropolis ranging from new buildings, customizable parks/amusement parks, town cosmetics, and just about anything you could imagine. There's even a mod that changes the game to take place on mars! (Simmars)


[b]TL;DR: 99% of the games problems can be fixed in 5 minutes by installing the SC4 Launcher and the Network Addon Mod (NAM) from Simtropolis, allowing better graphics, smoother gameplay, and a ton of bug fixes.[/b]

You must try to outweigh your expenses through manipulation of taxes, spending, laying things out in an expense-minimizing and/or profit-maximizing way, and provide for the needs of the city--electricity, water, smooth roads, well funded law enforcement and fire department, etc. Lower some commerical taxes, and you will probably entice more high wealth businesses to set up shop in your city, which in turn gives you more money. Lower funding to a hospital if patient capacity is rather higher than the amount of patients for now. That sort of thing.

It has been a long time since I wanted to get a SimCity game past Classic, so when I saw SimCity 2013. I got it. Too many problems, so I returned it. 

Then I saw this one on Steam, so I got it, hoping that it'd at least be able to run smoothly. I was not disappointed.

To me, it took a while to adjust to the new things that needed to be managed (like supplying water and spamming the city with parks and trees and etc.) compared to SimCity Classic. Now, I can say that I'm doing a decent job running a city.

Lots of thinking and planning is involved to make a good city. It takes some time to get to that but it's rewarding once you're there. Some of the guides found online can help a lot.

[h1]Still [u]the[/u] city simulator after a decade[/h1]

First, this is a [u]really complex[/u] game, similar to how running an actual city is really complex. If you don't like managing a lot of detail, then this game isn't for you. There are a lot of zones, utilities, civic structures, and transportation systems to build. It's a bit overwhelming at first, so make sure to go through the tutorials and [u]start small[/u] (e.g., low-density zones, no education system, no hospitals, and no water system). While the complexity makes it a bit hard to get into SC4, it's the same thing that's missing in SimCity Societies and SimCity (2013).

Second, unless you're playing on a Mac which gets the updated port by Aspyr, you'll have some [u]technical problems[/u] to deal with. Basically, you have to add command line parameters to tell the game to use only one of your CPU's cores and to use resolutions that didn't exist when SC4 was released (like 1920x1080). [u]Search the forums[/u] for details on recommended parameters. Once you've gotten that figured out, you might want to fiddle a bit with the graphics options (I think I reduced the shading/shadow effects to minimum). With this sorted out, the game runs pretty smoothly for me and only crashes every few hours on average. [u]Save often[/u] to be safe. I have no idea if Aspyr's planning to release a Windows version of their Mac version, but when/if they do, these technical problems should pretty much disappear.

Third, there are some [u]issues with game mechanics[/u] that make it hard to build big regions without mods. While you can do a lot without adding mods, I strongly recommend using the Network Addon Mod (NAM) and Colossus Addon Mod (CAM), at least after you reach the point where things stop working correctly. Even if you don't enable any of the NAM's custom transportation systems, it's worth it for the improved traffic simulator alone. There are [u]lots of mods[/u] for fixing other things and adding pretty much everything, so use your favorite search engine and explore. There's still a [u]really active modding community[/u] after a decade.

Overall, SimCity 4 is a great game once you put in the time to learn it and work around the technical issues. It has what's missing in the newer SimCity games and doesn't force you to be constantly online. [u]It would be really awesome if Aspyr ports their Mac port to Windows (and Linux!)[/u], fixing all the technical issues. Until then, I recommend waiting for this game to go on sale before buying it here. I got it for $5 in early 2014 to replace my CD copy that finally broke.

Sim City is always a good buy.  I truly feel that Sim City 4 brings the total experience of what it means to be a mayor or governor.  There are advisors and citizens you must deal with.  You are the executive power in almost every arena that the city can be managed in.  I bought this game because I have always been a fan of all the Sim style games.  They are very addictive and the gameplay is very creative oriented.  Plan your city's infrastructure, budget, make deals with neighbors, and even impliment policies that can better prepare your citizens for random disators.  This game has everything that could go right or wrong with a town, all the way from tornadoes to UFO invasions.  I will mention this, it can be a little glitchy on Windows 8.

It might take a little while to learn. Its got great features and animations, however, playing with some mods like the Network Addon Mod (NAM) greatly improves gameplay.

Amazing game. Graphics are outdated but the amount of things you're able to do and hours of fun you will have steamrolls any other game in the genre. If you care more about gameplay than graphics and want to build your own city, buy this game right now. Do it.

SimCity 4 is the king of the City builders. While it does have its glitches here and there, they are minor once you get them ironed out. Its best feature by far is the ability to campaign map and build a massive connected metropolitan area of multiple cities. This feature gives it strong replayability as you always want to build new ones to make your first ones better, and thus retrurn to periodicaly. Unlike SimCity 5 - this game is worth its money.
An excellent city building game and as far as I know, still the best around 10 years later. If you can get over a somewhat steep initial learning curve, you'll sink a lot of hours into this.

If you like creating things and watching them grow then here you go. A great classic they have done a great job with. This, and the 2000 versions are the two I play. The amount of customization that can be done wtih this version, in particular, is excellent. I always come back to Sim City.

I manged to get pulled into this game so badly that within a few weeks I have racked up 200 hours. I don't know how it does it, but it is quite an enjoyable way to waste some time.

I'm not sure any Sim game can beat the experience of the original, which most of us came across on a computer in study hall in our middle or high school. It isn't about features, graphics or customization - just one of those times when the first iteration of a game is the most enjoyable, no matter how vast the improvements since then.

I commend SC4 for even coming CLOSE to that experience. Despite the it's not the original feeling I do find myself getting wrapped up in creating my perfect city. This game has everything you'd want out of a city builder, complete with a street view and dispatching fire trucks. 

Graphically it's pretty good. It's not awe-inspiring or offputting, just good enough to not be a distraction - which is exactly the pocket a game like this should fit into. After all, there are plenty of games to be visually struck by, that just isn't the point of a city builder. Options and control are far more important, and it exceeds expectations in leaps and bounds.

One thing I always wished was possible was differing time periods - being able to make a town with a 60's feel, or the Old West - presenting a lot of different problems, using different buildings, etc. I watch Back to the Future a lot (a lot!) so perhaps I'm alone in that. Either way, SC4 is moddable.. so if you're good at that kinda thing you might be able to create an even better experience for yourself.

Video is extremely buggy.  If I try to run it at my monitor's native 1080p, the screen flashes constantly and is unusable.  If I set it to the game's highest default resolution, I end up with huge black bars on the sides of the screen.

Always been one of my favorite games since it's first release. Also wish they would make a SimEarth again! Pretty please!

For those who are disappointed with the graphics try this guide before deleting the game!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=114840389

SimCity 4 had a lot of great things going for it at the time. It still has that spark from the 2000's, but you can't help but ask yourself 8 hours in, What's the point?. In the end, there is almost no point to any video game, but the point to SimCity is still kind of sharp. 

I value it at 14.99$
Having not played any SimCity's in about 10yrs I saw this was on sale and just had to get it.  Addictive game, several hours will pass in what seems like minutes.

It's pretty fun, but the tutorial is lengthly and boring. Such from that some of the aspects of the game is hard to understand besides the base idea of; get money, build a city and just play around a little to understand it more. I haven't played the game that much recently, but when I did, I remember it being pretty enjoyable. Though a few additions I would like to see isn't included, but nothing to big. Overall I would say I give it a 7.5/10.

Game is fun but with newer computers it ssems graphically the game is unstable. I am running on dual 780's and an i7 processor and I consistantly get frame tearing, low fps and graphics are bad but this game did come out in 2003

Although the game is pretty fun, I've lost every city I've made due to random game crashes.  Upon doing a little research, I found that this is a reasonably common problem.  I may put in more effort to find a solution, but losing town after town has put me off from the game for a while.  If they would fix the game, I'd definitely give it a thumbs up.  But it's pretty clear they aren't planning on supporting it to any significant extent.

The game doesn't support 1920x1080 resolution.  Age of Wonders 1 supports 1920x1080 resolution and that game is old.  Why haven't this company followed suit and upgraded their old junk?
I only recommend this game if you have basically nothing else to do, or if you like building cities! Its a pretty good, cheap game to play especially if you loves strategies!

As much as I like the idea of city builders the visual glitches I keep getting for this game are making it more or less unplayable right now.

The tutorial I've done so far is helpful, I don't know maybe I'll try and play it again but not being able to see the squares you're placing is a pretty big hinderance so far.
Loved this game back in the day, and it still absolutely holds up today. In my opinion this is still one of, if not THE definitive city sim. I literally cannot fault it.
Loved this game when I was younger, and now that I can finally play it on my mac, I can have a bunch of fun building my own city again!

Apologies for making it so short, but yes, I recommend this game without a doubt. The gameplay has some iffy spots here and there(e.g.: 90% of the population trying to commute with cars instead of by walking despite the workplace being a mere two blocks away), but the base gameplay is amazing and so are the numerous community mods that range from bug fixes to extra road and building types. I admit I haven't played the new SimCity, but from what I see, this is the superior SimCity game.

This is probably my most played game ever. Completely rediscovered it thanks to the release on Mac and have been enjoying it as much as ever. It may be over a decade old, but it is still amazing, the soundtrack is especially great. Overall, I cannot think of anything much wrong with this game!

One of the best game in the series. The simulation is realistic, with the mods developed by the community, the game becomes well balanced, correcting some flaws. So the mods are required.
Traffic is a real problem you have to deal, really boring. The pollution is also a problem, but there are a lot of ways to handle it.
You have to develop the cities in the region, because one city influences the neighboring ones.

Largest city sizes in any Simcity Game. Also features the most mods and addons of probably any game ever. At least any city builder game.

Seriously good, probably invested 1000's of hours into it since I got it back in 2004. Buy it

It's 99% fantastic on my Win7 PC, ramps up at a good pace, classic play, just enough 'simulation' to make me believe I'm controlling hundreds of thousands of little folks and getting them to build bigger and better buildings, and that the parks I place around town really do suck up the pollution nearby.

There's an occasional freeze/bug where I have to fire up Task Manager and put it in its place, but this very rare, and virtually never for a city I've had going for a while.  An acceptable level of downtime for something I keep running alongside while I do my work.

If you find it on a holiday sale for, oh, $4.99, I'd say I've gotten more enjoyment out of this than a venti mocha from that one infamous green and white coffee shop franchise.  I'd for sure recommend this to any one who got burned by SimCity5 :)

Ok, so you know how good those freshly baked choc chip cookies from your grandma are, ey? Well this game is that good. Actually no, it's better! (Yes I just went there). If city building is your thing, in this case it's mine, this is the game for you! The amount of gameplay you can experience is amazing, and you can expand your game so much with mods made by communities til this day! 

I have played this game for over 400 hours, which is cool and kind of scary at the same time. I'd call myself a SimCity veteran even though I'm just 17.

Besides all of that, this game is worth every penny and has the best replay value of all the games in my library. Try it!
Stay cool dudes
AJ

I have 113 hours on record. I still have no idea how half of the transportation in the game should be utilized. Is that bad? No, the game just sucks you in so much into managing your town, keeping up on money, trying to get those skyscrapers going, making sure your roads don't suck, that you may overlook some of the stuff because of how much fun you are having making your town EFFICIENT. You know you can do better than your current towns crumbling economy? Prove it! You think having a military contract will help? SCREW YOU BUDDY CRIMERATE IS UP FROM HAVING MILITARY DO WHAT THEY WANT THE DON'T NEED NO MAN. Take it slow, watch what you pay people, keep it in the green and keep developing and moving on education because if you stop too soon, your maintenance gets costly, you'll start running into that red, and one last tip, make sure you have a good amount of water, old buildings burn fast!
It is the best city builder i have ever played and it is really fun and worth the money because you get the game, sim city, and the rush hour DLC it is really fun.

Sadly this is the last SimCity I will recommend even though it is now more than 10 years old.  SimCity 4 will always be a classic for anyone who likes creating in an open world with lots chalenging twist and turns.

Love it. Its a game I've spent hundreds of hours on. You'll want to make sure you download a few mods, like the Network Addon Mod. 

I had alot of fun with this game by using a rough multiplayer setup with a friend using a dropbox account.

There is no official support through this game. You'll have to get help from the community.

I really wish I could buy a Simcity 4.5 that would fix some of the lame issues the game has struggled with since its beginning. But ten years later and no sequel probably means this is the end for this city simulator. Enjoy it while you can.
I got this game while it was on sale. Surprisingly it has its times that it can be addicting while also it can be very frustrating. If it is on sale and you want to be a mayor pick it up

Ever since I switched to Mac I've been wanting to play this. It really does work, and it's awesome to play this game with the highest graphics settings and no lag--something that never happened when I was a kid. I would like to see a steam workshop for this in the future.

This game is basically classic EA/Maxis, back when the sim games weren't a disaster like now. If you are looking for your first Simulation game, its alright to go back in time, cause these ten year old games still are better. Also, UFO's and giant robots.

Love it. Great classic game, but it crashes in the middle of play sometimes its 5 minutes other times 7 hours, great still but would enjoy it more if i didnt have to worry about  it crashing at any moment.

Although I love the game, the Mac version of this does not seem to contain the latest Maxis-released updates to the Rush Hour expansion. This version still has various bugs. Although, it's wonderful to have a game at all, and one that doesn't rely on the Mac App Store's restrictions. 

Please update the game to the latest version and allow for the NAM!

Sick game if you like City Planning and Sandbox games.
There is alot to learn at first but after the tutorials, a little reasearch on strategy 
and a few Practice Citys you get the hang of it fairly easliy.

  I've got to admit. If you fit into the esoteric group of gamers who 
enjoy this type of gameplay you'll get pretty addicted fast.
I'd hate to say it, but sometimes making the right choice isn't always what is ethical.
You might just learn something by playing this game.

Graphics - 8.5
Sound - 7
Gameplay - 8
Replayability - 8

Best city-building sim of all time, and it's not even close. The network add-on mod alone gives more content than most stand-alone games. And considering how EA has run Maxis into the ground, this SC4 will likely stand as the best city-builder for a while.

I highly reccomend this! this game is not your typical action packed, gore filled, triple A game. This is a relaxing (ok thats a lie this game can make you extremely frustrated) and time consuming game. The game has nice graphics (make sure to go into your graphical settings and set them to high or you will be disappointed in this game) I love simcity games and have been playing them since simcity 2000

To all residents of BCIVille:

It has come to my attention that a number of you have filed complaints regarding increasing numbers of traffic collisions, crimes and pollution. Rest assured, as mayor I am hard at work on a plan to solve all of our great city's problems at the same time. I cannot say too much right now as it's still in the planning phase, but the general idea of the BCIVille Renewal Project '14 includes an aggressive strategy of tax breaks, industry subsidies and strategic nuclear strikes in the worst areas of the city. 

As well I'm considering the possibility of using new, exotic materials to simplify our existing infrastructure in order to save our public works departments millions of dollars per year in materials compared to what we've been doing until now. I've discussed the effectiveness of this plan with my advisors and a number of constituents and they all agree: this will work. According to official reports from the BCIVille Department of Quite Reliable Statistics, we should expect to see a 58% increase in cromulence by the year 2016.

I understand some of you may have questions or concerns, and believe me, I need your input as citizens to perfect BCIVille for all of us. If you want to volunteer, please address your opinions to the following mailing address, located conveniently next to our city's landfill:

BCIVille, SimNation 66986
